LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to tender its stock in the British mutual fund that used to be headed by Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen Wall Street investor. The Leucadia National Corporation, a New York holding company, has already acquired 73 percent of the voting securities of the mutual fund, Cambrian & General Securities P.L
LEAD: Bernard Pagezy, chairman of Compagnie du Midi, France's second-largest insurance company, lost out today to Claude Bebear, Midi's vice chairman, in a battle for control of the company.
LEAD: New York State lawmakers and the Cuomo administration are considering a proposal to add a state tax to interstate and international long-distance telephone calls.

LEAD: Lintas: New York has announced an ad campaign for a new cold cream. The cream, called Difrinse, is the first water-rinsable cold cream developed by Noxell. In a new television spot, a clown is depicted taking off its makeup as a narrator notes that the cream rinses off with water, leaving ''softer, cleaner skin.
LEAD: Angna Enters, a dancer and mime, painter and writer, died on Saturday at the County Manor Nursing Home in Tenafly, N.J. She was 82 years old.

LEAD: A defense attorney yesterday sought to have the former sports agent Lloyd Bloom tried separately from his colleague, Norby Walters, on Federal charges including racketeering and extortion. Both men are accused of using cash and threats to line up college athletes as clients. At a brief hearing, United States District Judge George Marovich said he would rule on the motion today before empaneling the jury.

LEAD: Total spending on broadcast television advertising almost reached $25 billion in 1988, the Television Bureau of Advertising said yesterday. Advertisers spent $24.9 billion on the medium last year, the highest amount ever and an increase of 7.1 percent over 1987.

LEAD: Having been turned down three times in its efforts to build a new tower in the old South Street Seaport Historic District, Milstein Properties returned yesterday to the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission with a proposal that was lower - but not small enough to suit its many opponents.

LEAD: The offices of The Riverdale Press, a family-owned weekly newspaper in the Bronx, were heavily damaged by at least one firebomb shortly before dawn yesterday, but the authorities said the identity of the attackers and their motive were mysteries.

LEAD: THE scene: The women's locker room of the Vertical Club, one of the more fashionable midtown gyms. The time: A few days before Lent. Dramatis personae: Lorinda Ash and two women whose heart-to-heart conversation she overhears. The women, it soon becomes apparent, are: single, middle-aged, a tad overweight, as well as unhappy with their romantic involvements, their too-small apartments, the high cost of living in New York, their unrewarding jobs.

LEAD: Dancegoers who saw Bryan Hayes's ''Crossing Slowly,'' as performed by Bryan Hayes and Dancers Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio might have found themselves wondering not what time it was, but what century. LEAD: If Richard Green has his way, there will come a day in New York City when no schoolchild is ever again guilty of calling a library a ''liberry.'' LEAD: Nearly 250 years ago it was a Spanish fleet of 30 ships at the mouth of the Frederica River that threatened Fort Frederica, then the southernmost outpost of the 13 original colonies. It was near the fort, sandwiched between Spanish and English settlements in a buffer area called the ''Debatable Lands,'' that the English fought and defeated the Spanish in the Battle of Bloody Marsh in 1742.

LEAD: A farce should be cleverly built, energetically directed and buoyantly acted, but there is one thing it absolutely must be: consistently funny. As staged by Jerry Zaks and performed by a cast led by Philip Bosco and Victor Garber, ''Lend Me a Tenor,'' the jolly play by Ken Ludwig at the Royale, is an impeccable example of how to construct and mount a farce -up to a point.

LEAD: Too few people know Jean Helion's work, but those who do tend to think of it as a puzzlement. LEAD: One week after two women said he had fathered their children, Steve Garvey, the former major leaguer, has resigned as a trustee at the University of San Diego. Officials at the Roman Catholic university released a statement yesterday confirming Garvey's resignation but gave no reason. Dan Petrie, a spokesman for Bishop Leo Maher, chairman of the university's board of trustees, said Garvey attended the board's annual retreat at La Quinta, Calif., last weekend and turned in his resignation after a talk with the bishop.

LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that the futures exchange in Paris had agreed to join Globex, the after-hours trading system recently approved for financial futures markets.

LEAD: In the early hours of Nov. 11, the police arrested a Queens woman, saying she had planted a bomb at the Norwalk headquarters of the United States Surgical Corporation. The bomb plot - called a protest against the company's use of dogs in surgical training - was quickly condemned by the company as an example of growing fanaticism in the animal-rights movement.

LEAD: Premier, RJR Nabisco's smokeless, ashless, tarless cigarette, has gone up in smoke. Sales in two test markets fell far short of expectations and the financially pressed tobacco giant was unwilling to risk millions in search of a market.

LEAD: New York's Department of City Planning proposes to close a loophole that has allowed builders in all boroughs but Manhattan to fudge on floor area allowances. It's a misguided move; for the sake of expanding the housing stock, the loophole ought to be held permanently open, not closed up.

LEAD: In an effort to slow the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug abusers, Federal health agencies yesterday proposed a major liberalization in the availability of methadone to addicts seeking treatment.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant misstated the position of the New York Power Authority trustees. They are not in favor of the Governor's proposal.

LEAD: Like so many artists who emerged in Europe and the United States around 1960, Hermann Nitsch has based a career on taking the action in action paintings to extremes - on canvas, in performance and in real life. In 1959, when he was 21 years old, this Austrian artist christened his activities the Orgies Mysteries Theater, making the announcement in a rented beer hall in Vienna to an audience of one.

LEAD: The father stood a few feet away from the son, who stepped to the top of the pitcher's mound, stared toward home plate and then heaved one pitch after another to a man wearing a catcher's mitt. The father neither moved nor spoke. Sunglasses hid his eyes and his emotions. After a few minutes, he walked away without a word.

LEAD: JOE the barber is gone. He left town before we were able to say goodbye. He has given up his tiny barber shop in suburban Westchester to seek a new life. To quote the grandmother in ''Crossing Delancey,'' he's gone ''to live in Florida with Red Buttons.''

LEAD: There is nothing subtle about Joan Jett. At the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, where she is winding up her latest tour with a five-night stand, Ms. Jett and her band, the Blackhearts, simply pounded out song after song whose titles tell their stories - ''Bad Reputation,'' ''Do You Wanna Touch Me,'' ''I Love Rock-and-Roll.

LEAD: A congenital heart defect caused the death of Bob Satterfield, a reserve offensive and defensive back on the Notre Dame national champion football team who collapsed and died suddenly at a nightclub in Niles, Mich., Jan. 19, a Medical Examiner's report said.

LEAD: When I was a young girl, my favorite afternoons were spent at the counter of the local drugstore. Sipping away on ice cream sodas, I read romance novels and gossiped with my friends. The stools in the drugstore are long gone, but my desire for those perfect ice cream confections remains.

His Third Congressional District takes in some 500,000 residents in coastal Monmouth and Ocean Counties, from Keyport to Seaside

LEAD: The Pacific Basin works like a mirror. The United States looks across it and is reminded of its own decline. Japan looks east, sees a wounded giant, and wonders if it is looking at its own future.

LEAD: Sunday lunch or Sunday dinner: something easy to shop for, easy to prepare, easy to eat and satisfying in winter's brisk weather. Here is a recipe that is as easily done as said. And below it there is a game plan to help.

LEAD: There is actually good news concerning the alternative minimum tax, namely the A.M.T. credit, which goes into effect for the first time this year. With careful planning, professionals say, it could significantly reduce many taxpayers' liabilities. The bad news is that, with the restructuring in tax rates, the alternative minimum tax will apply more broadly than ever before.

LEAD: Thank you for running Carl C. Icahn's ''Case for Takeovers'' (Jan. 29), in rebuttal to the article by Robert Reich on leveraged buyouts. It is interesting to note that Mr. Reich is from Harvard's school of government, not its business school. That might explain his comfort with keeping incompetence in companies.

LEAD: The engagement of Leeanne Chari Olicker to Dr. Joshua Port, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Port of Altoona, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Olicker of Williston Park, L.I. A May wedding is planned. Ms. Olicker, a legal assistant at Tighe, Evan & Ehrman, a Pittsburgh law firm, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: RESILIENT floor tiles made of vinyl, asphalt or cork are easier to apply than many other types of finish flooring. Little skill is required to attach them, and, because the tiles are manageable in size - most are 12 inches or less on each side - trimming is less of a chore than it is with sheet vinyl or carpeting.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The aroma of exotic coffees rises above the hum of conversation and soft music. Cigarette smoke curls toward the ceiling.

LEAD: PAUSE BETWEEN ACTS. By Mavis Cheek. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) When her trendy television-director husband leaves her for another woman, Joan Battram finds, to her surprise, that she likes living alone. Her problem is that no one will leave her alone. Though this London schoolteacher strives mightily to discourage them, her neighbors and acquaintances insistently invite her out, her parents fret and phone, a muscular young colleague pursues her slavishly, her ex-husband changes his mind and, finally, the famous, meltingly handsome West End actor Finbar Flynn stumbles into her life.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. John Fitzgerald of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ellen Fitzgerald to Jeffrey Scott Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jones of Bethesda, Md. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Once again, Hanson P.L.C. has Wall Street guessing. And with Cummins's shares trading in the mid-60's, up from $50 in mid-December, before Hanson began its purchases, Wall Street sniffs a takeover battle - although

LEAD: Investing and taxes used to be a simple matter. If taxpayers made money on investments, they paid a tax. If the money was made by selling a security held longer than six months, the profit was considered a long-term gain and they paid a reduced tax. And if they borrowed money to pay for the investment, they generally got to deduct the interest.
LEAD: One way to bring a vague yearning for an unusual fishing, camping or hunting trip to fruition is to visit any of the several outdoor-oriented shows that bloom in late winter in the Northeast.

LEAD: In a conclusion that seemed foregone long before the season began, Kenny Anderson of Archbishop Molloy in Queens has been named high school basketball player of the year by Parade Magazine. The 6-foot-2-inch guard, who has announced he will attend Georgia Tech next year, also became the second three-time member of Parade's all-America team, joining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who was known as Lew Alcindor when he attended Power Memorial High School in New York 25 years ago.

LEAD: Fifty years ago a social visionary named Austin Tappan Wright dreamed up a Utopian community named Islandia, which he placed through a series of writings somewhere in the southern seas near Antarctica. Then, 25 years ago Levitt & Sons built a 500-house community in southern Long Island, and, borrowing from Wright's fictional ideas, named it Islandia.

LEAD: A discography on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the pianist Vladimir Feltsman misidentifies the orchestra and conductor for a Prokofiev series on CBS Masterworks, and the works involved. The recordings, of the First and Second Concertos, are by the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas.

LEAD: If ever a show had competition, it is ''Cezanne: The Early Years 1859-1872'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The competition in question is not from any other artist, but from Cezanne himself - or, to be precise, from the supreme importance of late Cezanne in the accepted hierarchies of art.

LEAD: WHEN the buzzing began under my bed in the middle of the night, I thought at first that my dreams had been enriched by a new realism. When the buzzing continued and I realized I was not dreaming, I thought I had left the telephone off the hook. When I found the receiver in place, I became, in quick order, annoyed, mystified and a little unnerved.

LEAD: The tape-recorded threat, apparently from a left-wing group, arrived at the radio station here and was quickly broadcast: Unless the right-wing Mayor resigned within 48 hours, he would be killed.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with enjoyment and a sense of familiarity Carol Asher's article ''Abroad and Barely Bilingual'' (Travel, Dec. 25). I share her sense of adventure in trying to decode and use an unfamiliar language, but an additional interest is the insight it gives into ambiguities that are generally overlooked in everyday use of a familiar language.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the reaction of American Muslims to the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' referred incorrectly to the position taken by a group of American writers. They favor further publication of the book by Viking Penguin.

LEAD: At an emotional rally in the small textile town of Lanett, Ala., last fall, the chairman and chief executive of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the area's largest employer, vowed to keep his company out of the hands of a certain Northern industrialist: William F. Farley.

LEAD: Usually the first thing that will strike a listener making a historical survey of opera recordings is the increasing prominence of the orchestra. These days, in fact, record buyers building an opera collection on CD have become accustomed to the ear-catching sonics that only a prominently recorded orchestra can provide.
LEAD: ''WE'RE doing the best that we can under the most difficult of circumstances,'' says Christel, ever the pragmatist. ''And everyone does his part for the greater glory of the Reich.''
LEAD: POLITICAL division along racial lines is hardly unique to Chicago.

LEAD: James W. Gaynor, a former New York State Commissioner of Housing and Urban Renewal, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the Palm Beach Gardens (Fla.) Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Tecuesta, Fla.

LEAD: Conflict. The theme prevails throughout baseball, and spring training has hardly begun. It comes in an assortment of sizes and kinds. It always has, always will.

LEAD: IN the war against chemicals that cause cancer, most of the attention has been on man-made substances like pesticides and preservatives. Increasingly, however, some scientists are arguing that the public has been infected with a bad case of chemophobia. Most cancers, they say, come from natural causes - the food, sunlight, plant poisons, tobacco and other things people encounter every day.

LEAD: Plastics may well have shaken their image as cheap and tacky materials. But now, with mounting concern over the heaps of plastics piling up in the country's landfills, manufacturers are struggling to deflate the notion of plastics as polluters.
LEAD: WITH the caution induced by things strange and new, Tunisia's opposition parties are looking forward to an election that they depict as a test of a kind of North African glasnost.

LEAD: In social games, using either four-deal scoring or the traditional rubber bridge scoring, it is common for a player to fail in a part-score contract by three or more tricks. The opponents are left regretting that they failed to pull the trigger, doubling to collect a large penalty instead of a small one.

LEAD: When a worried Iraq sought Western intervention against an intolerant, revolutionary Iran, it advertised itself as a moderate, civilized society. The West stepped in, for its own good reasons, but few were fooled by the Iraqi masquerade. Saddam Hussein's Baghdad dictatorship is one of the world's most barbaric tyrannies.

LEAD: Robert B. Reich's article ''Leveraged Buyouts: America Pays the Price'' (Jan. 29) says all the things that my friends and I - people of average income and investment - have felt about this legalized thievery for years. The biggest crime is that the brokerage houses, the executives settling gently to the ground in their golden parachutes and the huge law firms who do all the paper shuffling are the only winners.
LEAD: STANISLAVSKI By Jean Benedetti. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Routledge. $25.
LEAD: The trouble with the sports agent industry is that the foxes are in the hen house.
LEAD: Even before the fashion powerhouses show their fall collections in the coming weeks, more than 100 young contenders have had their say at last week's Fashion Coterie in New York.

LEAD: If gambling fever made Darrell Waltrip and his crew take the chance that won the Daytona 500 last month, the man they may have caught it from was Gary Nelson, a former crew chief for Waltrip's teammate, Geoff Bodine, and someone always willing to go the extra mile on fuel consumption.

LEAD: Because of what he described as a lifelong dream of playing in the National Football League, Timm Rosenbach, the nation's most efficient passer while at Washington State last season, has decided to forgo his final season of college eligibility to pursue a professional career. ''I have weighed all the facts and I'm confident that I have done what is best for Timm Rosenbach,'' he said in announcing his intention of making himself available for the N.F.L.

LEAD: MY first great architectural encounter beyond American shores took place on an autumnal weekend in the Loire Valley in France. Silhouetted against a gray sky was the majestic roof line of the 16th-century Chateau of Chambord, with its symmetrically massed turrets, towers and cupolas. It made a lasting impression on someone reared on the simplicity of American Colonial architecture.

LEAD: We think that the acquisition of Kiki Vandeweghe will not substantially help the Knicks. The Knicks are a fast-breaking, pressing and trapping team that has good shooters and doesn't need another shooter to mess up the chemistry.

LEAD: Chinese Cloisonne enamels - wildly colorful, frequently outsized and embellished with gilded dragons, elephant heads and mythical beasts - represent an imperial taste rarely exhibited in New York. A comprehensive selection of 80 fishbowls, urns, vases, candlesticks and incense burners, assembled over 40 years by Pierre Uldry, a Zurich banker, is on view at the Asia Society Galleries, 725 Park Avenue (at 71st Street), through May 16.

LEAD: Last summer's drought left a legacy of poison that threatens the country's food supply. Dry weather spurred the spread of the fungus that makes aflatoxin, a highly potent inducer of liver cancer. Dangerous amounts of aflatoxin contaminate a fifth or more of the Middle West's 1988 corn crop, much of which is still in storage.

LEAD: AS a teacher of poetry in the schools, a kind of itinerant salesman of a rather dispensable commodity, I travel from district to district. This gives me an unusual opportunity to fathom the character of nondescript places like Elwood, Medford, Selden, East Northport; large expanses of development laid out in rectilinear grids, with a main artery of shopping malls.

Gary Hogeboom, the former quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys and Indianapolis Colts, has agreed to contract terms with the Phoenix Cardinals.

LEAD: Bob Probert, the troubled Detroit Red Wings forward, was expelled from the National Hockey League yesterday, two days after he was arrested and charged with smuggling cocaine.

LEAD: A reversal of a decision by the officials in the waning seconds of overtime helped St. Peter's reach the final of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament today with a 77-76 triumph over Iona.

LEAD: Beethoven: Diabelli Variations Sviatoslav Richter, piano. Philips CD 422 416.

LEAD: A courageous but obscure traveler from named Nathaniel Bishop from my hometown of Medford, Mass., rowed a small boat called a ''sneakbox'' 2,000 miles from upper New York State to New Orleans in 1877 or so. When he got there, exhausted, and tied his boat to a jetty, a group of young drunks congregated and threw bottles at him.

LEAD: We take issue with the individuals who expressed their distasteful view of the Canada geese in the Long Island parks (''Canada Geese: Thriving Immigrants Prompt a Backlash,'' Feb. 19). We look forward to feeding these beautiful, fascinating creatures each weekend, and find the droppings a minor inconvenience that we tolerate so that we may share their park.

LEAD: JUST how tap dancing soothes ragged nerves, no one could quite say. They were getting exercise and that was important, too.

LEAD: Each time Kathy Conway, a real estate agent, sells another house in Queen Village she feels as though she were selling her soul. LEAD: MY DOCTOR put me on a beta blocker,'' a friend told me last week. ''I hate the side effects, but I couldn't argue with him.'' Many, perhaps most, patients feel that way: they don't really have much say in the matter. Yet, according to a famous New York Court of Appeals decision in 1914, ''Every human being of adult years and sound mind has a right to determine what shall be done with his own body.

LEAD: WERE you, like me, among the adult populace who tut-tutted over the failure of our youth to understand basic economics, as disclosed in a recent national survey? More than half of the 8,000 high school students tested could not define terms like profit and inflation.

LEAD: What makes people contribute to a charity that offers no glitz or galas or personal recognition? The question arises because of the remarkable course of the 77th annual appeal on behalf of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund collected over $4 million - which exceeds even last year's record by more than $250,000.

LEAD: As the filing deadline approaches -April 17 this year - taxpayers are finding new complexities. A special section on problems from Form 1040 through retirement strategies. Pages 15-27.

LEAD: George Bush now has on his desk a little noticed executive order that threatens to revive one of the excesses of the McCarthy era. The order, prepared in the final days of the Reagan Administration, would scrap the appeals process for Federal security clearances. This, in turn, would allow the Government to deny clearances to Federal workers or to the employees of Government contractors, without any explanation.
LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization today rejected warnings by the United States against further attempted guerrilla raids on Israel.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Abroad And Barely Bilingual'' described my delight mixed with trepidation when among strange tongues where I make it a rule always to carry a piece of paper in my pocket bearing the name of my hotel. This served me well in downtown Tashkent when boarding a trolley I learned by agitated gestures of the ticket taker after reading the name of my hotel, that I was on the right trolley going in the wrong direction.

LEAD: Intel plunges boldly into the world of reduced instruction set computing. THE Intel Corporation has introduced a new chip, the i860, that is believed to be the first commercial microprocessor to incorporate more than a million transistors on one piece of silicon. It is also the first to handle data in 64-bit chunks.

LEAD: Walt and Joyce Bialkowski are not students. They are members of the Ku Klux Klan, though, and they wanted to be heard on WHRW-FM, the student-run radio station of the State University of New York at Binghamton, after reading that it had a history of airing unpopular views.

LEAD: Even Mr. Robinson's friend might marvel at just how prevalent plastics have become since his prediction about their promising future in ''The Graduate.'' Last year, sales of resins - the raw materials that plastics are made from - grew to $28 billion. That was up 30 percent from 1984.

LEAD: A WHILE BACK, PEOPLE IN the hi-fi trade jokingly referred to LP turntables as ''dinosaurs'' - a species about to become extinct. But they mistook the nature of the beast, and nothing of the sort has happened.

LEAD: THE quasi-Colonial decor may be a surprise to those crossing the threshold of Casagrande, but it should not dilute one's enjoyment of this northern Italian restaurant in Wallingford, just off Exit 66 of the Wilbur Cross Parkway.

LEAD: If a Ford Edsel could be rolled and smoked, it might be called the Premier. The ''smokeless'' cigarette that the R. J. Reynolds Company spent $325 million to develop and promote was taken off the shelves last week after a notably cool reception from smokers and the heated opposition of health groups.

LEAD: In a move that could provoke a sharp reaction from Catholic colleges and universities, the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith has published an oath of fidelity to all official church teachings that will be required of teachers of Catholic theology as well as church officials.
LEAD: Two pieces of postal history - one a rare Italian folded letter from 1825, the other a common United States postal card from 1887 - tell two tales of tragic women and their families.

LEAD: SOONER or later just about every traveler buys a package or tour. Even diehard solo travelers are tempted by the variety of arrangements offered by tour companies and airlines. Today the package need not shape a vacationer's entire trip, locking him or her in a mobile cocoon. It often offers a compromise, mixing hotels and local transportation with freedom to explore, dine out and take side trips.

LEAD: Walter N. Thayer, a lawyer, partner in the Whitcom Investment Corporation and former president of The New York Herald Tribune, died of pneumonia yesterday at New York Hospital. Mr. Thayer, who was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan, had been admitted to the hospital more than three weeks ago. He had suffered from emphysema for several years.
LEAD: AMID heightened concern over the condition of aging commercial planes, aircraft manufacturers and the airlines are developing a new approach to maintenance.

LEAD: Under a new municipal system, a citizen here with access to a computer can send an angry letter electronically to City Hall, see whether the library has a certain book or check the bus schedule.

In testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady asserted their beliefs that Wall Street's enthusiasm for the leveraged buyout has reached its peak.

LEAD: A brief cautionary tale: one day some years ago, after I had published a book, I was asked for permission to excerpt a piece from it in an anthology. Delighted, I wrote back. As it happened, I used this anthology in a course I taught. I admired its selections, and found the study questions helpful.

LEAD: EVERY year, the J. Richards Gallery here has what it calls a ''masters show.'' The gallery, at 64 East Palisades Avenue, is a brightly lighted storefront, and its masters are strictly 20th century.

LEAD: Cablevision's positions in the MSG dispute are defenseless. MSG is not ''expensive'': including the new Yankee contract, it costs less than $1 per month per subscriber. It is also not ''specialty programming'': 9 of the 10 most-watched cable programs in 1988 were sports.
LEAD: After three years in decline, gypsy moths, which have devoured millions of acres of foliage in past years, are expected to return in strength this spring to plague the trees of the Northeast.

LEAD: Once every 15 minutes the smiling face of Bob Mirsberger, Manhattan director of the I.R.S., flashes on an electric color billboard over Times Square with an enthusiasic exhortation to ''Make Your Taxes Less Taxing By Filing Early & Electronically.'' LEAD: THE last time I took an auto trip around France, 25 years ago, we usually stayed in the local Hotel de la Poste, or above the restaurant where we ate, picking a more expensive place every couple of days to take a shower. But since then, chains of motels, have created new choices for the budget-conscious.

LEAD: THE official birth of photography took place in March of 1839, when Louis Daguerre revealed his daguerreotype at a scientific convention in Paris. Six months later, details of the process had reached the United States and within a couple of years there were daguerreotypists at work the world over, producing mirror images of people and places on silvered copper plates.

LEAD: Warner Communications Inc., born in the Hollywood of the early 1920's as Warner Brothers, today is the largest record and television production company in the United States and one of the biggest film production companies in the world.

LEAD: For This Week: Prune, prune, prune, everything from grapevines, to summer-flowering shrubs to overgrown hedges to small trees; leave the tending of large shade trees to professional arborists who have the ropes, saws, equipment and knowledge to tend them. Keep up with seed planting indoors. Finish planning the garden.

LEAD: That there exists continued difficulty in providing adequate housing for the homeless should not come as a surprise (''State Plays Bigger Role for Homeless,'' Jan. 22). There is clear precedence for this problem. Historically, there have been enormous problems coordinating and centralizing social services, including housing, for former psychiatric patients, many of whom are represented in our homeless population.

LEAD: ''What's done is done,'' Darryl Strawberry was saying, after his one-day exile was done. ''I'm back.'' He was back, all right. With flourishes, a hug and a kiss for Keith Hernandez and a mighty three-run home run for the Mets, he was back today, ending his walkout, burying his contract blues, turning boos into cheers and even stealing the show from Tommy Lasorda and his ''team of destiny.

LEAD: FEMALE artists from Connecticut and throughout the country will dance, recite poetry, display paintings and sculptures, give music recitals and deliver comedy routines as the New Haven Women in the Arts celebration gets underway this month.

LEAD: Islamic militants have threatened to kill Wole Soyinka, the author and Nobel laureate, for his defense of Salman Rushdie and the British author's right to publish ''The Satanic Verses,'' according to diplomats and news reports here.

LEAD: SHARE OF HONOR. By Ralph Graves. (Holt, $19.95.) From 1942, when the Philippines fell to the Japanese, until Douglas MacArthur led the liberating invasion in 1944, America's principal colony lay under harsh, often brutal occupation. Ralph Graves, Time Inc.'s former editorial director, who grew up in Manila as the stepson of the United States High Commissioner and took part in the liberation of the islands as an Army Air Forces sergeant, uses the occupation as the framework for his first novel, ''Share of Honor.

LEAD: To the Editor: We were planning a two-week vacation in Costa Rica this winter with about half of our time on Isla Jesusita, a small island off the Pacific Coast scarcely mentioned in guidebooks. For three weeks we and our travel agent tried to call the 800 number for the Costa Rica National Tourist Bureau in Miami.

LEAD: ''A sham,'' ''ludicrous,'' and ''kabuki theater'' are some of the ways service personnel characterize the battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense. But while a sampling of attitudes at posts around the country shows differences of opinion, it shows no strong support for the former Senator.

LEAD: An oil tanker that ran aground off the Hawaiian island of Oahu floated free Friday night after salvage workers lightened the ship's load to prevent more crude oil or fuel from spilling into the Pacific Ocean and washing up on Hawaii's beaches. The 800-foot Exxon Houston ''suddenly just started floating,'' a Coast Guard spokesman said, and the ship was towed to deeper water.

LEAD: AT first blush, a loft building on East 22d Street that has been converted into a residential co-op has little in common with a privately owned country club and golf course on Staten Island.

LEAD: March 5 - An artistic sampling of what the Millay Colony for the Arts is all about will be offered at a benefit reception at the Victoria Munroe Gallery, 415 West Broadway (near Prince Street) from 4 to 7. The colony, the former home of Edna St. Vincent Millay, is a 600-acre retreat in Austerlitz, N.Y., where artists can spend a month without cost working at their craft.

LEAD: The National Economic Commission, a bipartisan panel appointed by the President and Congress in the aftermath of the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, failed to come to an agreement last week on a blueprint for cutting the Federal budget deficit. The failure of the commission means that next October it is more likely that Congress will be forced to accept the automatic cuts of the Gramm-Rudman Act, a process known as sequestration.

LEAD: When Jack Pointeau came from his native France eight years ago and eventually settled in this small west Texas town, he did everything by the book. He applied for an investor's visa, which is granted to people who intend to invest in the local economy. He renewed that visa every year. He opened a business and paid his taxes.
LEAD: ONE of the most rewarding aspects of the season at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is that it always includes a world premiere.
LEAD: More than 4,000 South Africans have died in politically inspired violence in the last four and a half years, according to statistics released this week by a university research group.

LEAD: As a political crisis deepens in the Sudan, Egypt, its northern neighbor and onetime ally, has broken publicly with the leadership in Khartoum and wants to see it replaced by a new administration ready to talk peace with rebels in the south, according to highly placed officials here.

But since there are no words in this ''dance opera'' except a minimal vocal score in Greek provided by Elizabeth Swados, what eludes the eye often escapes comprehension and baffles the emotions.

LEAD: The University of Texas is considering including mandatory steroid testing in a new contract for the Texas-Oklahoma football series, DeLoss Dodds, the Texas athletic director, said today.

LEAD: In an article last Sunday about ''Day One,'' a TV drama about the building of the first atomic bomb, James F. Brynes was misidentified, and his involvement in the decision to drop the bomb on Japan was incorrectly described. He was Secretary of State under President Truman and argued in favor of using the bomb.

LEAD: IT is an image branded on our minds and memories. Gary Cooper, in the movie ''Sergeant York,'' is silhouetted against an evening sky, sitting on a ledge studying the Bible and trying to make sense of a world torn by global conflict.
LEAD: A movement is under way to preserve the home of a pre-Civil War black man whose violent death went unpunished because of discrimination.

LEAD: A crowd of Hasidic Jews surrounded and beat a black teen-ager who they believed had just slashed a Hasidic woman and her son during a robbery in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn Friday night, the police said.
LEAD: ABOUT 890,000 people are on New York City's welfare rolls, more than half of them children. But the statistic is only part of the picture of city poverty, and the whole is decidedly unclear.

LEAD: WITH Manhattan office users slowly absorbing a wave of new construction, the owners of less-than-stellar older buildings are coming under intense pressure to renovate their space, sometimes dramatically, to compete in a sluggish rental market, industry professionals say.

LEAD: If life were as easily controlled as a movie on the VCR, who could resist the urge to toy with those buttons? Reverse and fast forward would probably get the most play, though an occasional Faust might opt for the stop mode or at least the slo-mo. Looking back at the new productions offered this season by the Metropolitan Opera, I myself find the erase button most tempting.
LEAD: There could not have been more than two dozen spectators in the stands when Ron Guidry walked from the bullpen to the mound and made his pitch to win a job with the Yankees today.

LEAD: Almost a decade after the faculty of Harvard University applauded a report saying the school hired too few women and members of minority groups, a new study has found little progress, according to a report issued here.

LEAD: KILL THE POOR. By Joel Rose. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $8.95.) Sharp, savage and extremely well written, this provocative first novel examines a politically troublesome and ethically troubling issue - the gentrification of impoverished urban neighborhoods - with the stylistic flair and easy nihilism characteristic of New York's downtown scene.

LEAD: When he went back to Canada from the Seoul Olympics last October after testing positive for drug use and being stripped of his gold medal for winning the 100-meter race, Ben Johnson said he did not knowingly take drugs.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Donaldson Jr. of Millington, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Donaldson, to Dr. J. Michael Haering, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Haering of Bethlehem, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: There will be a tax bill this year, but it is unlikely to involve any major overhaul of the tax code or substantial new tax increases. So goes the prevailing wisdom among tax policy makers and lobbyists as the Bush Administration and Congress take their first tentative steps toward negotiation on the budget for the 1990 fiscal year.

LEAD: Some people who are contributing to the support of aging parents or disabled relatives can look to basic tax devices to cut their costs. Someone who furnishes more than half a family member's support can claim that person as a dependent and take an additional personal exemption, provided that person's gross income does not exceed the amount of the exemption, $1,950 this year.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane was an enigmatic player in the Iran-contra drama. A former Marine Corps officer who became national security adviser to President Reagan, he led a secret mission to Teheran in 1986, with a cake and a Bible signed by the President, in a fruitless quest to trade weapons for hostages.
LEAD: To the editor:
LEAD: WHEN we talk about pressure in our lives we often put it in terms of our jobs. Our work creates lots of pressure.

LEAD: Maybe you were in this world in a previous incarnation, and maybe not. If you were, you were undoubtedly royalty, or one of Napoleon's generals, or a famous courtesan who had only to be seen to be desired.
LEAD: THAT SINGULAR PERSON CALLED LEAR A Biography of Edward Lear, Artist, Traveller and Prince of Nonsense. By Susan Chitty. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

LEAD: FIFTY YEARS OF ETERNAL VIGILANCE: And Other Stories. By Carolyn Thorman. (Peachtree, $14.95.) The characters in Carolyn Thorman's first collection of stories are quirky Lithuanian- and Polish-Americans with varying attitudes about the benefits, and costs, of assimilation. They wouldn't understand the word, but they know everything about the idea.

LEAD: There's more to education than classroom learning and career potential. Several hundred students at Fordham University have been demonstrating that to such an extent that a national organization for community service has chosen the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx as the site for a conference this week.

LEAD: As if getting good grades were not hard enough, sometimes just finding out what grades you got when can be a major achievement. Not at Boston College, which has installed a machine that dispenses academic records the way an automated teller machine dispenses cash.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. An October wedding is planned. Miss Galvin is a clinical research associate at Pfizer Central Research, a division of the Pfizer pharmaceutical company in Groton, Conn.

LEAD: About four years ago, Judy Smilow took a course by the designer David Tisdale at the 92d Street Y. The subject was anodizing aluminum for use in jewelry. ''I liked the idea of combining the precious with the not-so-precious, like diamonds and aluminum,'' said Mr. Tisdale, recalling the course Ms. Smilow took.

LEAD: IN what Rutgers is calling the most broad-based effort ever to address the concerns of homosexuals on an American campus, the university is examining virtually every facet of campus life, from curriculum and living arrangements to bereavement policies and health benefits, to assure the safety and rights of its gay students and faculty members.

LEAD: For the Rangers, the injuries have hit hard and often recently, depleting their defense and disarming their attack. Their consolation has been that for all their recent injuries, there has been almost no damage to their position in the Patrick Division.

LEAD: Kiki Vandeweghe will both help and hurt the Knicks. Kiki is a great shooter and will pour in the forward points that the Knicks have sorely missed. He and Johnny Newman will divide the playing time and both will get their share of time and points.

LEAD: I like Lucinda Williams's eponymous album on the Rough Trade label as much as the next person: This is serious, satisfying singing and playing and composing in a gritty folk-blues-rock idiom. But even her most fervent admirers concede that she sounds familiar; indeed, her very familiarity in this slick, syntho-pop era seems deeply comforting.

LEAD: Physicians treating a snake-bite victim whose need for rare medicine prompted White House intervention received the serum from Iran today, but a hospital spokesman said it might not be used.
LEAD: At least 5 people were killed and 80 injured today when two passenger trains collided south of London, sending several train cars plunging down a steep embankment, the authorities said.

LEAD: At first glance, it all looks terribly proper: the early 19th-century secretaire topped with a pair of terra cotta busts; a William IV sofa in front of windows facing the street, and a simple mirror over the fireplace. On closer inspection, however, these rooms have a special brand of humor, an eccentricity and flair that is completely personal.

LEAD: A crowded ferry capsized today in southern Bangladesh, and least 23 people were drowned, news reports said. Many other people were missing. Three bodies were recovered from the hull of the ferry after rescue teams hauled the boat out of the swift currents of the Kancha River, the United News of Bangladesh said.

LEAD: WE'RE NOT HERE. By Tim Mahoney. (Delta, Paper, $7.95.) Many Vietnam novels stagger out of the souls of American soldiers who can describe their suffering but have trouble getting beyond it. Tim Mahoney's second novel is a compelling exception - a Vietnam story so good that it rivals what is still probably the best Vietnam novel, Graham Greene's 1955 work, ''The Quiet American.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY co-op boards have traditionally enjoyed the right to screen incoming residents and even restrict occupancy to shareholders and members of their immediate family. That right was always underscored and confirmed by the terms of the proprietary lease.

LEAD: On a fringe of mainstream rock, a new style is coalescing. The loose network of college (and a few commercial) radio stations, rock-club disk jockeys and active music fans that sent R.E.M. into the Top 10 has nurtured an ''alternative rock'' that's more melodic than post-punk hard-core rock yet looser, more unruly and less formulaic than big-budget productions such as Bon Jovi.
LEAD: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has announced that 1990 has officially been designated ''International Literacy Year.''

LEAD: Striking machinists, joined by pilots and flight attendants, all but paralyzed Eastern Airlines' operations yesterday, grounding nearly 90 percent of its planes and stranding passengers at scores of airports across the nation and in Latin America and the Caribbean.

LEAD: WENTWORTH T. PHILLIPS said he had always banked on simple basics like self-sufficiency and knowing the skills of the laboring class to make it in life. Based on those tenets, he founded the Bloomfield Farm Implement Museum in 1980. As he will explain over and over, he started his museum with ''the kids, the kids, the kids,'' especially inner-city children, in mind.

LEAD: CIVIL TO STRANGERS: And Other Writings, by Barbara Pym. Edited by Hazel Holt. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) This posthumous collection of unpublished fiction includes the title piece, a novel written in 1936, about an exotic Hungarian whose arrival shakes up a quiet Shropshire village. The blimp, which will be nearly the size of three football fields, will, when fully equipped, cost $170 million.

LEAD: Few phrases cause as much terror as ''tax audit.'' It conjures up visions of sinister agents disallowing deductions and imposing penalties and back taxes that rival a New York condominium in cost.
LEAD: Per usual, the American child this spring is being offered a panoply of designs and colors uniting fun and comfort.
LEAD: BREAD is more than the staff of life. To diners at a restaurant, it is a preview of the meal to come.

I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over.

LEAD: Lisa Amy Stern and Craig Steven Lax are planning a September wedding, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Martin T. Stern of Manhasset, L.I., have announced. Mr. Lax is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Lax of Englewood, N.J.
LEAD: He's the best pitcher not enough people know. Mark Langston works for the Seattle Mariners, so he toils in obscurity. Almost in exile.

LEAD: New York State has a new law intended to give buyers of new homes increased protection against defects such as leaking roofs and faulty plumbing by defining the legal responsibilities of contractors. While state law already had held contractors liable for deficiencies in new homes even in the absence of a formal warranty, the law that went into effect Wednesday defines what is included in the implied warranty.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders and the National Football League reached a settlement today in the multimillion-dollar antitrust suit involving the league's efforts to block the team's move from Oakland in 1982.

LEAD: TELEVISION magnifies reality, and the image on French television screens a week ago was shocking. In the heart of Paris, at the Place de la Republique, some 1,500 Muslims, many of them Pakistanis, screamed into television cameras for the death of Salman Rushdie. With close-up camera work, the smallish crowd suddenly seemed to represent a fanatic Islamic fifth column that had surfaced in France just as it is celebrating the 200th anniversary of its republican, anticlerical revolution.

LEAD: Methadone, a drug that blocks the craving for heroin while allowing the addict to lead a normal life, has suffered controversy since the 1960's. A new Federal decision to make it more accessible could strike a blow against AIDS and drug abuse.

LEAD: Vocal music will hold its own against the instrumental competition this week. The options range from grand opera to a pops songbook, not to mention a recital by Roberta Peters combining both.

LEAD: It is not hard to imagine what so impressed Stravinsky when he heard Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire'' for the first time in the winter of 1912. Three-quarters of a century later, a listener can still be made to feel unsettled by the music's urgency and strangeness.

LEAD: John McEnroe shook off the fatigue of a four-set match he played only 12 hours earlier and earned a record fifth World Championship Tennis finals title today with a methodical 6-3, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Brad Gilbert.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Shining Path guerrillas killed 37 men in a rural village by cutting their throats, and shot to death a mother and her baby when the woman tried to flee, a Peruvian military official said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Call it beginner's luck, or maybe just precociousness, but in only two semesters Anne Sclater has mastered an art her peers typically spend years cultivating: the search for the perfect ''gut.''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garrett Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Clare Carruthers Franklin to Victor V. Duran, the son of Victor Duran Acosima of Mexico City and Janice Duran of Potomac, Md.

LEAD: Throughout the 1980's, promising young jazz musicians have been looking back. Defying the notion that music evolves in one immutable direction - that as one era's style succeeds another, there is inevitably progress in art - they devote themselves to the jazz approaches of the 1950's and 1960's. Recent albums by or featuring Ralph Peterson, Wallace Roney, Marcus Roberts and Mulgrew Miller show a generation mastering one of the most complex musical languages ever conceived.
LEAD: Because of the changes wrought by the 1986 tax act, William H. Sterling and his wife, Marion, can no longer deduct the $4,000 they contribute each year to individual retirement accounts.
LEAD: ''The negotiators are en route back to Miami, if they can get a flight.'' - Robin Mattel, chief spokesman for Eastern Airlines. [ 26:1. ]
LEAD: The Bush Administration expects to complete arrangements to extend an emergency $450 million loan to the Government of Venezuela ''in a few days,'' a senior Treasury official said today.
LEAD: A retired Air Force sergeant insisted he saw Mr. Tower under the influence of alcohol. Page 34.
LEAD: WHEN I FIRST SAW THESE mills, I thought they were too big.''

LEAD: ON Friday and Saturday nights, a few Sparta police patrol cars head out from the heart of this 38-square-mile rural township in search of teen-age drinking parties in residential neighborhoods. The police hope to head off problems before they happen.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Track and Field World Marks Tumble: Paul Ereng of Kenya, the Olympic champion, broke Sebastian Coe's six-year-old world mark in the men's 800 meters yesterday, and Javier Sotomayor of Cuba set a world record in the men's high jump at the world indoor championships in Budapest. Two other world marks also fell: Elly van Hulst of the Netherlands slashed nearly six seconds off the women's 3,000-meter best and Kerry Saxby of Australia lowered the mark in the women's 3,000-meter walk.

LEAD: These days, the country's No. 1 high school basketball team is St. Anthony of Jersey City. Who says so? The sports editor of the LaPorte (Ind.) Herald-Argus. His name is Dave Krider, and he has become the nation's basketball star-maker, even though he rarely sees any of the teams he selects.

LEAD: ''Someone had to use the product for at least a week to get used to it, and that's an extraordinary requirement for a consumer. We live in the world of instant gratification.'' Lawrence Adelman, analyst at Dean, Witter on the smokeless cigarette.

LEAD: Born in 1921 in Robinson, a small town in rural Illinois, James Jones was a curiously American phenomenon: the great novelist who comes out of nowhere, equipped only with talent and a fierce determination to write. Jones's love of literature was untutored, innate. Without money for college - his father was an alcoholic dentist whose fate is described in these letters - and without prospects, Jones enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1939 and was shipped off to Hawaii.

LEAD: Unlike the atomic bomb whose creation it chronicles, ''Day One'' doesn't get the Geiger counters clicking. Tonight's play, at 8 on CBS, is not without force, particularly toward the conclusion, when scientists, military men and Washington officials come into conflict over the rush to ready a bomb to drop on Japan.

LEAD: Before she became the wife of Mao Zedong and, subsequently, the most powerful woman in China, Jiang Qing was an actress. One of her favorite roles was Nora in ''A Doll's House,'' which she played in Shanghai in 1935. Beginning with these facts and Jiang's trial as one of the notorious Gang of Four, Leslie Mohn has created an irreverent, freewheeling political escapade titled ''White Boned Demon.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE BLACK HEART: A Voyage Into Central Africa. By Paul Hyland. (Holt, $22.95.) Late-19th-century notions of Central Africa, revealed to us in Joseph Conrad's ''Heart of Darkness'' and in journals and popular accounts of such explorers as Stanley and Livingstone, have attached themselves to the Western imagination with all the tenacity of myth.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Gill of Rochester of the engagement of their daughter Denise Elizabeth Gill to Douglas Hazzard Nash, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Clyde L. Nash Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The couple plan to marry in July.
LEAD: Carl Icahn's rhetoric belies his actions. In 1987, he attempted, unsuccessfully, to take over USAir, the most consistently profitable and well-managed airline in the industry.

LEAD: Risa Meryl Klein, the daughter of William Klein of Sands Point, L.I., and Cynthia Blueweiss of New York, and Robert Andrew Greene, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Greene of Basking Ridge, N.J., plan to be married May 6. Miss Klein, a graduate of Brandeis University, is in the account management department of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, a New York advertising agency.

LEAD: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls. I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over.
LEAD: IN the name of agricultural self-sufficiency, nations pay a high price in the form of farm subsidies, foreign trade restraints and the stockpiling of mountains of grain.
LEAD: There has been little snow pack this year, and gardeners are worried. What does a dry winter mean for plants?

LEAD: Plastic producers have had a tough time shifting out of low gear as they try to sell Detroit on the plastic car. Over the last decade, auto makers have increased their use of plastics in car interiors and in small parts to make them lighter and more fuel-efficient. But they have been unable to justify plastics for body panels and structural frames because in large-scale production they cost more than steel.

LEAD: Acting as his own negotiatior, Alan Trammell agreed yesterday to a $6.5 million, three-year contract extension with the Detroit Tigers that runs through the 1992 season. In a five-minute session, Trammell suggested a figure to Bill Lajoie, the Detroit general manager, who agreed and shook hands on it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A retired Air Force sergeant continued to insist today, despite efforts by some senators to discredit him, that the dignitary he saw under the influence of alcohol on two occasions at an Air Force base in Texas was John G. Tower.
LEAD: It is clear that Anthony DePalma is one of the few who flourished in the Catholic school system; however, I find his nostalgia infuriating.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came under attack last week from state officials who accused him of holding up funds already set aside for AIDS services and postponing programs planned to begin this year.

LEAD: There are a fair number of new skyscrapers in this growing city, including one by the slick New York firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox that endeavors, with mixed success, to give distinction to this city's skyline. It may be the best new tower in town, but it cannot, alas, hold a candle to the two buildings that mark Nashville as truly special: the Parthenon and the Opryland Hotel.

LEAD: AS MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV AWOKE ONE morning from uneasy dreams, he found himself transformed in his bed into a Broadway actor. And even though he was afraid, he liked what he saw. He liked it even better than ballet.

LEAD: When 2,000 Princeton University alumni returned for the annual Alumni Day lunch last month, they were greeted by students passing out literature describing a ''movement towards student empowerment.'' That was three days after 40 of the students held an all-night sit-in at Nassau Hall, which holds the offices of top administrators.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Yesterday, five minutes after I read the article concerning the car-theft situation at Green Acres Shopping Center [ ''Car Theft Fraud Rampant at Nassau Shopping Mall,'' Feb. 19 ] , our family left for the Roosevelt Field movie complex, discussing your article during the entire trip. We realized we'd not patronized Green Acres in years, and felt doubly secure in sighting two mounted policemen on horseback as we arrived at Roosevelt Field.

LEAD: Topping the 1989 GTE Academic all-America men's basketball team are Michael Smith of Brigham Young University and Alec Kessler of the University of Georgia. Smith, a 6-10 senior center from Hacienda, Calif., averaged 26 points a game and Kessler, a 6-10 junior forward was the leading rebounder in the Southeastern Conference with an average of 10.1 a game as well as averaging 20 points.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about efforts to prevent bias on college campuses incompletely identified a participant in a training program. Renell Jackson is a 28-year-old student from Yonkers in his second semester at Westchester Community College.

LEAD: For the first time since Japan's ever-widening political scandal came to light eight months ago, it is threatening Japan's two best-known political figures: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and his predecessor, Yasuhiro Nakasone.

LEAD: The Jubal Trio has, for the last 14 years, extended the comparatively limited repertory for flute, harp and soprano by commissioning new works and rescoring the accompaniments of standard vocal literature. The trio - Christine Schadeberg, soprano; Sue Ann Kahn, flutist, and Susan Jolles, harpist - brought some of its recent endeavors along these lines to Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening.

LEAD: To the Editor: The story of the journey to Rike's grave in Switzerland (Travel, Jan. 1) brought back memories of a similar pilgrimage I made as a Texas schoolgirl years ago. Lacking a car, I asked in Zurich if a train conductor could make a special stop for me, and if I could then reach the church by foot.

LEAD: WHEN Ruth Bocour of New York took an economy-class flight to California some years ago, her leg began to hurt and she thought she had a charley horse. Mrs. Bocour, a former professional dancer who now helps injured people improve mobility, said that when the plane stopped in Las Vegas, she ''walked around like crazy'' and tried to exercise the leg to get the cramp out, but to no avail.

LEAD: Sears began its new life as an ''everyday low prices'' retailer. All 800 stores were closed Tuesday to mark down the prices on 50,000 items. The change was heavily promoted, and Sears store managers said that when the doors opened at midday Wednesday the crowds were bigger than during the Christmas season.
LEAD: In preparation for the Middle East negotiations that led up to Camp David and the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty, I tried to learn as much as possible about the Moslem faith.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schafhauser of Summit, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lydia Eva Schafhauser, to Harry Charles Sangree, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sangree of Craigville, Mass. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: Residents of New York City still have the unenviable distinction of paying the highest combined Federal, state and local tax rates in the nation - 41 percent for those in the 33 percent Federal bracket and 36.6 percent for those in the 28 percent Federal bracket.

LEAD: Dogs, not diamonds, are a man's best friend. However, men are not immune to the lure of a few appropriately placed baubles. From cuff links to tie bars to collar pins, masculine details that once were traditional have returned in force to business and formal dressing.

LEAD: In pursuit of a painless method for containing hospital costs, American industry now has a new white knight: utilization review. A rapidly-growing breed of cost-management companies - under contract to employers and insurers - that decide if hospital admissions are justified, monitor length-of-stay and carry out other cost-containment functions.

Ratings - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

LEAD: The Knicks aren't just winning without a 30-point-per-game forward; they're dominating. I don't know what Rick Pitino or Al Bianchi studied in college, but it sure wasn't chemistry. CLIFF COURTNEY New York

LEAD: Among contemporary American writers there are many accomplished stylists, for ours is an age of intense literary activity, much idiosyncratic virtuosity and invention. The general assumption may be that ''realism'' is not an experimental literary convention but simply ''the way things are''; but practicing writers know that all genres, all visions, all artful employments of language are conventions, freely available to the virtuoso.

LEAD: IN 1985, President Reagan declared that terrorists who harmed Americans would have to answer for their crimes in Federal court. In Clint Eastwood style, he warned the airplane hijackers, hostage takers and truck bombers of the world, ''You can run, but you can't hide.''

LEAD: Improper and careless management of chemical and oil wastes on Alaska's North Slope is seriously damaging the delicate tundra environment there, according to an unpublished draft report by the Environmental Protection Agency.

LEAD: A BAY WINDOW overlooking the Supreme Court park is a pleasant place to sit at breakfast, especially early on a holiday morning, when Constitution Avenue is devoid of traffic. At times like this, Capitol Hill is so quiet you can hear your heart beating, and if you are lucky enough to have a great glossy pine growing close to your house, you will sometimes catch another sound, the purest in nature: wind hissing through needles.

LEAD: FOR a few months every four or eight years, career civil servants demonstrate that the machinery of Government works well in many respects when nobody is quite in charge. For day-to-day operations, a Cabinet seems unnecessary: Social Security checks are issued, taxes are collected and research on AI

LEAD: Manufacturers of plastic products say the shortage of qualified polymer scientists and engineers is hampering their ability to compete with foreign rivals. Only a dozen graduate-level programs offer polymer studies in the United States, and the lack of professors prevents them from being expanded, said Frank N.

LEAD: Icy winds blew in from the north, but the costumes and dancing at the American Museum of Natural History matched the party's theme, ''A Hot Time in the Tundra.'' The occasion was the Junior Committee's annual fund-raising event late last month. A few penguins and a Santa Claus roamed through the crowd, but most partygoers came to the Land of the Midnight Sun in sexier dress.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was at Chartres last June 23 and was able to see the labyrinth uncovered for the first time in many visits. This was due to the presence of members of a Druid cult who removed the chairs.
LEAD: The acquisition of Kiki Vandeweghe by the Knicks is a two-edged sword.

LEAD: NOTWITHSTANDING all of the dollar's pirouettes over the past year, Americans traveling to Europe this spring or summer will be delighted to discover that their vacation money will buy more baguettes, bratwurst, paella and pasta than it did last year.

LEAD: After a lifetime of ignominy in his homeland and anonymity abroad, the late Soviet choreographer Leonid Jakobson is being rediscovered by American audiences. Last month, in a special gala performance honoring the New York Public Library's dance collection at Lincoln Center, Johan Renvall, an American Ballet Theater principal, performed Jakobson's virtuoso solo ''Vestris.

LEAD: To their utter astonishment and consternation, Mexican immigration officials have in recent days apprehended Nicaraguans, Salvadorans and other Central Americans swimming across the Rio Grande from Texas.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Stratton-Crooke of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Diana Stratton-Crooke to Edmund Murphy Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Kelly of Scarsdale. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: Hamburg is a city best savored in the evening fog, when its crown of thin spires shimmers through the branches of great oaks leaning over the Outer Alster, the larger of the two lakes around which the city lies, and gulls swoop low over the rowing shells gliding silently past.

LEAD: Working together to create the world's largest media company, the chief executives of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. sought to insure that the merger would cause little of the turmoil that has accompanied many mergers and acquisitions in the 1980's.
LEAD: Former Mayor Mike Boyle, defeated in a 1987 election on the issue of removing him from office, has announced that he will run again for the city's top job.

LEAD: Donnah Ellen Brown, a daughter of Sara Jane Drescher of Hollywood, Fla., and Robert S. Brown of Hamden, Conn., was married in Hollywood last evening to Mark Alan Winger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Winger of Elyria, Ohio. Rabbi Robert Frazin performed the ceremony at Temple Solel.

LEAD: MORE and more, I find myself using olive oil for cooking instead of butter. For someone raised in the English tradition of butter on everything - even baked beans - this is something of an accomplishment. But nowadays I find that I like olive oil even on something as butter-prone as a baked potato.

LEAD: When the pianist Vladimir Feltsman arrived here from the Soviet Union in August 1987, New York's music professionals advised him not to procrastinate. He had a year, they said, to warm himself in the spotlight of international politics. Then the light would go out with alarming suddenness, leaving only his talents at the piano to sustain him.

LEAD: High school athletics have become the latest entree on the American sports menu, served up to help satisfy the voracious appetite of the fan. As a result, scholastic athletes are on the verge of becoming as important to the billion-dollar sports industry as their college brothers and sisters - and just as vulnerable to big-time exploitation.
LEAD: LOYALTIES A Son's Memoir. By Carl Bernstein. 262 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: Hair Wild, Eyes Naked

LEAD: JUST two years ago when 31 nations met in Montreal and agreed to cut the production of chlorofluorocarbons in half by the turn of the century, the accord was hailed by environmentalists as an unprecedented example of international cooperation. Now, with evidence accumulating that the chemicals are indeed eroding the protective ozone layer, the United States and the members of the European Community are rushing to impose even more drastic measures.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having spent time in Oaxaca nine years ago, I read with interest your story (Travel, Jan. 1) about the decision of the Mexican Government to expand tourism in that mountainous state.

LEAD: Sylvie Guillem, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, has joined the Royal Ballet of London for three years as principal guest artist. She is expected to dance at least 25 performances a year, beginning with ''Swan Lake'' on April 15. She will do guest appearances in Paris.
LEAD: In office almost 11 months, Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita is at a point where most postwar Italian leaders have begun to reach for their coats and head toward the exit.

LEAD: Although they share a surname and a reverence for the American West, one would be hard pressed to find two more dissimilar landscape photographers than Ansel Adams and Robert Adams. The widespread popularity of Ansel Adams's pictures is rooted in a purposeful exclusion: he photographed primarily in wilderness preserves and eliminated all signs of human presence.

LEAD: Once upon a time, a giant roamed a vast kingdom, telling tales that made people laugh and cry, and helping merchants peddle their wares. But after a slew of little fable makers appeared, telling tales just as the giant did, he was forced into battle to reclaim his treasured place in the kingdom.

LEAD: COUSCOUS is the kind of dish nouvelle cuisine set out to defy. No matter how it is judged - by sheer volume, by the ferocity of its spices, or just by the whole ceremony of eating it - the North African specialty built on mounds of semolina, vegetables, lamb or chicken is not for the faint-hearted.
LEAD: A Supreme Court Justice today blocked at least until March 17 the partial merger of Detroit's two daily newspapers. The merger was to have begun Monday.

LEAD: The sun will be partly obscured for millions of Americans Tuesday morning, the United States Naval Observatory reported Thursday. People in Hawaii and most of the western two-thirds of the United States and Canada will be able to see the eclipse as the new Moon passes between the Sun and the Earth.

LEAD: A taxpayer's home is still where the deductions are. The tax laws, which have squeezed out ways to cut taxes in most other areas, still grant beneficial treatment to those with shelter, including a second home.

LEAD: A GROWING number of consumers are questioning whether the blemish-free fruits and vegetables at their supermarkets are as good for them as they look. Concern is rising about pesticide residue on produce, and the merchants responding to the concern are not just health or specialty stores.

LEAD: The anchorman of the weekly Soviet television news program ''Good Evening, Moscow'' has been saying ''Good afternoon, Madison'' all semester. As a visiting Fulbright scholar, the anchorman, Boris Notkin, has been teaching a course here on ''Mass Communication and Glasnost.''

LEAD: FRIENDS of Robert D. Turner are fond of saying that the 43-year-old Yonkers police and fire dispatcher was ''born in the wrong century.''

LEAD: In a country inured to trauma during 14 years of war, several events in recent days have given rise to guarded optimism here that the barriers that divide the capital and the nation may be breached.

LEAD: Dancers explored the mysteries of space in ''The Weatherfields,'' which Steve Krieckhaus, a Philadelphia-based choreographer, presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. LEAD: AT DUSK, WHEN ALL THE WESTERN relief workers have left for the day, blue Chinese-made trucks drive up to Site 8. Nudging the Thai-Cambodian border, Site 8 is run by the Khmer Rouge. LEAD: A year ago Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., apparently set a world record for the oldest winner of a substantial competitive event of any kind. Playing in Pittston, Pa., with Edwin Utan of Scranton, Pa., he won a two-session Open Pair Championship at the age of 95.

LEAD: The University of Oklahoma is still reviewing an incident that led to the arrest of the Sooners basketball star Mookie Blaylock, and won't make any decisions on him before the investigation is completed, Donnie Duncan, the athletic director, said yesterday. The police in Norman, Okla., said they arrested Blaylock, 21 years old, on a charge of public intoxication outside a convenience store Sunday following an argument between Blaylock and a female companion, who also was ar-rested.
LEAD: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke ended a political standoff in the Republican Party and a weekend of intense speculation by announcing today that he intended to seek re-election this year.

LEAD: Robert M. Stutman, head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in New York, said yesterday that city school officials were dragging their feet in putting together a city-wide drug education program.

LEAD: When Kenny Anderson was asked to summarize his basketball career at Archbishop Molloy High School, the high-scoring all-American from Queens offered a penetrating insight into the current state of high school sports. Reflecting on the hours of study, practice and competition he had put in during his four years, Anderson concluded that his experience had essentially been like work.
LEAD: India agreed today to provide what a Government spokesman described as humanitarian and technical aid to President Najibullah's Government in Afghanistan, the Press Trust of India reported.

LEAD: NASA today postponed the launching of the space shuttle Discovery, planned for Saturday, for at least two days. The postponement came because of failure of a system that separates the booster rockets and fuel tank from the orbiter.
