LEAD: Since 1950, China has shown Tibet the rawest face of imperialism - destruction of thousands of monasteries, suppression of the Tibetan language and culture and widespread settlement by Chinese colonists. This has resulted in the death of perhaps a million Tibetans.

LEAD: Meyer Feldberg, president of the Illinois Institute of Technology and former dean of the business school at Tulane University, has been named the dean of the Columbia Business School, effective this July.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation will sell its magnetic tape manufacturing building and equipment in Tucson to the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the companies said. The 3M Company will supply tape cartridges for I.B.M.'s 3480 magnetic tape subsystem, to be sold under I.B.M.
LEAD: The Whiteness of Bones By Susanna Moore 277 pages. Doubleday. $17.95.
LEAD: After more than 100 years of semi-isolation, the United States has finally joined in a major international agreement that safeguards the integrity of literary and artistic works.
LEAD: South Africa's governing National Party today offered President P. W. Botha a facing-saving solution to the leadership crisis but failed to persuade him to yield power.

LEAD: When the game was over and nobody had managed to win it tonight, Coach Al Arbour angrily blamed his team's inability to post a 4-3 regulation victory and its ensuing submission to a 4-4 overtime tie with Philadelphia on a poor performance by the referee Don Koharski.

LEAD: Edward Powers, the Federal agent who helped solve the $2.2 million Brinks armored car robbery in 1950, died Tuesday in Fort Myers, Fla. Mr. Powers, who was later chosen to manage the first modern American lottery, was 75 years old.
LEAD: A Federal court jury was urged yesterday to acquit two New York City transit police officers who are charged with falsely arresting eight people in the subways.

LEAD: ''I TRIED this experiment with my kids,'' Tony Schwartz, a media consultant, said yesterday. ''I would burn toast in the morning, and with a stopwatch I'd tell how long it took the children to tell me the toast was burning. Then I would burn toast on another day when the radio was playing, and it took much longer for them to tell me about the toast.
LEAD: The new French film ''Chocolat'' is so fine that a lot of people may want - or assume - it to be about more things than it is.
LEAD: ABC canceled its second show in a week yesterday, announcing that ''Murphy's Law,'' ABC's 10 P.M. entry on Saturday night, would end after the broadcast of March 18.

LEAD: When Capt. Ghulam Siddiq first glimpsed Kabul today from 24,000 feet, the loss of a leg to a guerrilla rocket in Afghanistan's 10-year civil war was momentarily forgotten. Reaching between the rows of seats on the TU-154 airliner that had carried him from Moscow, he squeezed the arm of a fellow passenger and grinned.

LEAD: In the sense that both groups perform 20th-century music nearly exclusively, the Arditti String Quartet is the British equivalent of America's Kronos Quartet. But there are big differences, as indicated by the Arditti's marathon three-hour-plus concert Wednesday night at Town Hall.

LEAD: Where is Bruce Gehrke now that we really need him? For those who never had the pleasure, the late Bruce Gehrke was a legend at Mineola High School on Long Island, a winning coach and a zealot about protecting athletes from outsiders, namely me.

LEAD: International A3-13 In Poland, a tentative agreement on restoring Poland's second chamber of Parliament was reached by the Government and the Solidarity union. Members will be chosen in open and free elections. Page A1

LEAD: A defense lawyer yesterday sought to impugn the credibility of a former crack-using prostitute who had provided important evidence against four men accused of murdering a police officer in Queens.
LEAD: Edward Gaylord's attempt to acquire a majority interest in the Texas Rangers was rejected yesterday by American League owners meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

LEAD: Secretary of State Baker has agreed to go to Moscow in May to discuss the resumption of strategic arms limitation talks. He will get the most promising response then and in the later negotiations if he states a U.S. position that includes:

LEAD: In a move to expand its international presence, the U S Sprint Communications Company today announced an agreement to buy a 50 percent stake in the first private telecommunications cable linking the United States and Europe.

LEAD: Just before takeoff, the flight attendants dutifully repeated the standard safety pantomime with seat belts and safety information cards. But this morning, the performance was before 158 empty seats and just 19 passengers.

LEAD: Robert H. Morosky helped build the Limited into a major chain of women's clothing stores, but he did so as No. 2 to Leslie H. Wexner, the chain's chairman. Now he wants to build a chain of stores that sell auto glass, and he wants to do it as No. 1.
LEAD: * Campbell-Mithun-Esty, New York, owned by Saatchi & Saatchi, will handle a national awareness, membership and fund-raising campaign for Boys Clubs of America.

LEAD: A Federal agent who was killed last week while on a narcotics investigation on Staten Island was simultaneously involved in an undercover operation to determine whether corruption existed in an early-release program for prisoners, Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: The pianist Eddie Palmieri is leading his Latin-jazz group tonight through Sunday at Indigo Blue, 221 West 46th Street (221-0033). Sets tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., Sunday at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum.
LEAD: Opening a new effort to publicize the nation's drug problems today, President Bush renewed his call for a mandatory Federal death penalty in cases where law-enforcement officers are killed.

LEAD: New differences between the Commerce Department and the Pentagon over safeguards for technology are delaying Bush Administration agreement to cooperate with Japan in developing and producing an advanced version of the F-16 fighter.

LEAD: A Federal judge declared today that multiple punitive damage suits against manufacturers and distributors of harmful products were unconstitutional. Repeated punishment for a single course of conduct violates the right to due process, he said.
LEAD: Taking the story of one of the most notorious liars of legend, Terry Gilliam, the director and a member of the Monty Python troupe, has made ''The Adventures of Baron Munchausen.''

LEAD: This being a pledge week, public television is turning more than ever to adorable animals and soothing nostalgia. Those are the commodities, programmers insist, that most inspire viewers to become subscribers. This week, we had separate documentaries on cats and dogs. This weekend, Channel 13 is focusing on the popular music and stars of the 1930's and 40's.

LEAD: David Goodman, a lawyer who practiced real-estate law in Manhattan for more than 60 years, died of heart failure Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Corinne (Cybill Shepherd) and Louie (Christopher McDonald) are madly in love, which is unhappy news for Louie's best friend, Philip (Ryan O'Neal), since Philip loves Corinne too. But as the lovers are celebrating their first wedding anniversary, Louie is hit by a car. After this, he is gone but not forgotten, since Corinne spends the next 23 years mooning over Louie's memory (''My psychiatrist says I suffer from the halo effect'') and leaving little snacks beside his picture.

LEAD: EASTERN'S BANKRUPTCY Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in an attempt to conserve cash and to gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work. Meanwhile, Eastern continued to operate limited flights. [ Page A1. ] Thousands of Eastern ticket holders, confused and angry, turned travel agents' offices into chaos.

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of 45 insolvent savings and loan associations with assets of $13.6 billion today, bringing to 118 the number of sick institutions that it has seized in accord with President Bush's savings bailout plan.

LEAD: Anyone who is interested in the social as well as in the esthetic history of 20th-century painting should drop by the Spanish Institute, where a well-chosen retrospective of the Spanish painter Ignacio Zuloaga (1870-1945) fills two floors with paintings and drawings. These are works that in their day enjoyed an exceptional apotheosis in this country.

LEAD: The Circle Line sightseeing boats begin their 1989 season of daily three-hour sails around Manhattan today. LEAD: Robert Dick and Marielana Arizpe, two flutists, are to play new-music solos and duets at 9 P.M. tomorrow at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Tickets are $6.

LEAD: David Amram, the composer, will present a concert of his music at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 97th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program includes ''Zohar,'' for unaccompanied flute; a Wind Quintet; the New York premiere of ''Blues for Monk,'' for unaccompanied horn, and ''Native American Portraits,'' for violin, piano and percussion.
LEAD: Feature-Film Debut ''I have incredible trepidation,'' said Gary David Goldberg.

LEAD: Herman Kogan, a writer whose books celebrated the personalities and institutions of Chicago, died of a heart attack Wednesday while walking near his home in New Buffalo, Mich. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: ''This exhibition represents the highlights of the perhaps 1,000 instruments we have acquired since 1980,'' said Laurence Libin, the curator of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's musical instruments department, as he removed tissue paper from a group of clarinets made in Greenwich Village more than a century ago.

LEAD: Physically, Harlem has been a symbol of urban ruin. Its decline over 70 years from a masterpiece of urban elegance and lucid city planning to a ruinous array of broken buildings and garbage-strewn lots could not have been more complete if it had been legislated or decreed. Yet the paradox of Harlem is that even in the midst of what has become a physical wasteland, there is a creative energy that is alive and palpable.

LEAD: Judge John Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in New York may have a strong complaint against prosecutors appearing before him in an ongoing drug conspiracy trial. But by scolding them out of turn he has embroiled himself and news organizations in a needless confrontation over the right of the press and public to know how justice is being dispensed.

LEAD: Deutsche Bank A.G. of West Germany said Wednesday that it planned to make a friendly takeover bid for the Banco Comercial Transatlantico of Barcelona. The Deutsche Bank already owns 39.05 percent of the bank, known as Bancotrans. Terms of the possible bid were not disclosed.

LEAD: The Vice President of the United States makes one of the more important and sensible speeches on the Middle East heard in public for a long time. The country reacts pretty much the way the farmer did when he saw a camel for the first time. He shook his head, said there was no such animal and walked away.

LEAD: Several suburban cable companies yesterday added Yankee broadcasts to their basic package on the Madison Square Garden Network, which includes Knicks and Rangers games. John Malone, head of the group that signed the deal, said there would be ''a modest basic subscriber rate increase.''

LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due 1990 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes were priced to yield about one-half of a percentage point more than two-year Treasury notes. Underwriters said the issue is noncallable for one year.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in Federal court yesterday in an effort to conserve cash and gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work.

LEAD: With some of the nation's top black politicians acting as mediators, students and officials at Howard University reached an agreement early today that ended a five-day campus protest over the management of the predominantly black school and the appointment of the Republican national chairman to its board.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about nutrition labeling carried an incorrect description of an inquiry involving the Campbell Soup Company. The company has not been fined by nine state attorneys general over health claims made for its products. The issue is still under investigation in the nine states and by the Federal Trade Commission.

LEAD: Robert H. Bork says the Senate's questioning of him was a Supreme Court nominee in 1987 set a precedent for the treatment John G. Tower received in confirmation hearings for Secretary of Defense.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 458 money market mutual funds rose by $1.2 billion, to $295.24 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $39.6 million, to $72.69 billion. The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $19.9 million, to $95.14 billion.

LEAD: FOR some Americans, Brazilian music means Afro-Brazilian carnival processions and sambas in the street; for others, it means the whispered vocals, sly harmonies and delicate guitar work of the bossa nova. Still others are catching up with the tropicalia movement of the 1970's, when young, politically progressive Brazilian songwriters reacted to the broadening of rock with their own electrified pop; a selection recently appeared on ''Beleza Tropical: Brazil Classics,'' compiled by David Byrne of Talking Heads.

LEAD: Several left-wing members of Parliament along with leaders of the Peace Now movement will take part in a symposium in New York this weekend that will also be attended by members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LEAD: A brief article in Business Day on Feb. 28 and an article last Monday, both about mutual funds, misstated the net cash flow into equity mutual funds in January. The Investment Company Institute says the figure, not including reinvested dividends, was $72 million.

LEAD: In the large, darkened spaces of ''Laments,'' Jenny Holzer's new installation piece at the Dia Art Foundation, the artist's hauntingly pessimistic words flow between floor and ceiling in columns of moving colored light. The same phrases also sit, stately and still, carved into the granite and marble tops of 13 stone sarcophagi.

LEAD: As the son of an architect who wrested soaring shapes from steel and concrete in structures like the Gateway Arch, Eric Saarinen is a likely candidate to tinker with commonly accepted ways of presenting cars in television ads. In a new ad for the Acura Legend Coupe, the younger Saarinen shows an appreciation of elegant shapes.
LEAD: * Harvey Hoffenberg, has been named an executive vice president and executive creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

LEAD: When Brazil's armed forces toppled President Joao Goulart in 1964, they were no less intent on ousting the powerful man behind the throne, Leonel Brizola, a crowd-pleasing Socialist who had dreams of succeeding his brother-in-law in elections the following year.

LEAD: Thanks to a philandering husband and a death in the family, a sensitive, boring Australian wife named Maria (Wendy Hughes) is given carte blanche to do what she may well have wanted to do in the first place. In ''Echoes of Paradise,'' Maria ventures to the turquoise waters and unspoiled beaches of Phuket, Thailand, for some much-needed respite.

LEAD: The Soviet Union strikes a blow for world law and human rights. Not many months ago, readers would have blinked in disbelief at such a statement. Yet Moscow now says it will accept the binding adjudication of the World Court in cases arising from five basic human rights agreements, including the 1948 convention condemning genocide.

LEAD: Last year, as the savings and loan crisis unfolded, M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, came under intense criticism from Congress, especially for underestimating the size of the crisis and for some of the billion-dollar rescues of sick institutions.
LEAD: Almost every day, it seems, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner finds his way onto a morning television program, a weekend broadcast interview or the nightly news.

LEAD: An American Archbishop who was at the center of an Italian banking scandal will step down soon as head of the Vatican Bank, and supervision of the bank will pass to a new commission of five cardinals.
LEAD: Happy Coats, Happy Staff

LEAD: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which found itself in a national spotlight yesterday as President Bush kicked off an anti-drug crusade, is the nation's primary agency - but far from the only one - in a diversified war against cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs.

LEAD: A partial eclipse of the Sun occurred Tuesday across western North America, where amateur astronomers gathered to view the event through telescopes.

LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi Promotions Inc., the promotions arm of the British-American conglomerate, said yesterday that it had formed a new division to generate promotional campaigns for entertainment and consumer product companies. The division will be called Saatchi & Saatchi Entertainment.

LEAD: Merce Cunningham observed recently that there seemed to be more and more dancers these days -and good ones. Technical expertise, and even bravura dancing, have become relatively familiar ingredients and may be enjoyed in diverse programs throughout New York City. But there are also dancers who, for all their virtuosity, draw the eye with some mysterious extra essence.

LEAD: Leonidas Kavakos hit his full stride late in the evening at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday, delivering a firmly shaped and atmospherically colored account of Ysaye's beautiful Fifth Sonata for Solo Violin. Here the young Naumburg prize winner consolidated his formidable technical skills and matched them persuasively with a sense of musical purpose.

LEAD: In a significant advance in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud, a former vice president of the Unisys Corporation pleaded guilty today to bribing a Defense Department official, drawing from a secret $5 million fund set up with Unisys money.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS,'' a musical by the Gingerbread Players, with book, music and lyrics by Carol Weiss, directed by Fred Guinther, music direction by by Ben Sloane, 7:30 tonight, 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Queens.
LEAD: A fire fed by a flammable liquid that had been poured on a stairway trapped and killed a woman and her two sons in a three-story frame house yesterday, officials said.
LEAD: Miracle Room, an avant-garde rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $6.
LEAD: A five-year state plan to combat AIDS could cost $1.6 billion, according to documents made public yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office.

LEAD: For the last six years, the Big East has brought its four-day tournament to Madison Square Garden with promises of unusual twists and outstanding competition. Without exception, the conference has kept its word.
LEAD: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, said today that she was an alcoholic and appealed to the news media to let her pursue her recovery in private.
LEAD: * Comfed Bancorp Inc., Lowell, Mass., a bank holding company, said Gerald Schuster had resigned as vice chairman.

LEAD: Testifying before a Federal jury today at the trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, two National Football League players admitted they signed contracts and accepted loans from the agents before their senior seasons.

LEAD: A dozen or more countries have established overseas volunteer programs since the United States created the Peace Corps in 1961, but there has been little interaction among the participants from different nations over the years. That is changing.

LEAD: The wizards at Sun Microsystems Inc., which makes engineering work stations, have long viewed the Macintosh personal computer of Apple Computer Inc. as a nice toy, not a serious machine. At the same time, the marketeers at Apple have long scoffed that they sell more machines in a month than Sun sells in a year.

LEAD: Oliver L. North's defense lawyer today hammered away at inconsistencies in the testimony of a fund-raiser who said Mr. North vowed to lie to Congress, even to go to jail if necessary to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: Bernard Arnault, the new chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, won a court battle today that is expected to speed his efforts to oust Henry Racamier as chairman of Louis Vuitton, the luggage maker that is an LVMH subsidiary.

LEAD: The United Nations Human Rights Commission agreed today to maintain loose surveillance over Cuba's human rights performance for another year in a decision that appears to fall short of what the Bush Administration was seeking.

LEAD: Alvin Robertson had 29 points, including 13 in a third-quarter stretch that broke the game open, as San Antonio took advantage of the Nets' season-high 32 turnovers for a 112-98 victory tonight.

LEAD: An article on the Consumer's World page on Feb. 18 about swimming pools misstated fencing requirements for outdoor residential pools in New York State. Barriers at least four feet high are required by state law.

LEAD: Spokesmen for Poland's Government and the Solidarity union said tonight that they had reached broad tentative agreement on restoring Poland's second chamber of Parliament, with members chosen in open and free elections, and on instituting an office of president with broad powers for foreign and security affairs.
LEAD: Mayor John C. Hatcher Jr. of East Orange was indicted today on charges that he and another man took at least $75,000 in membership and rental fees paid to the city-owned golf course.

LEAD: At the age of 31, after 218 home run in 10 major league seasons, Bob Horner announced his retirement yesterday in Miami, where he had been trying to catch on with the Baltimore Orioles as a free agent. The right-handed power hitter, who slammed four home runs in one game for the Atlanta Braves July 6, 1986, said his left shoulder had not healed sufficiently from an operation last Aug.
LEAD: The Senate today rejected President Bush's nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense, the first time in 30 years that a President was denied his choice of a Cabinet member.

LEAD: Robbie Davis is riding again, having accepted two mounts at Santa Anita Park Wednesday almost five months after riding the horse that trampled and killed a fellow jockey, Mike Venezia, last Oct. 13 at Belmont Park. Davis, 27 years old, was so upset by the accident that he would not return to the race track and considered retiring after having won 1,357 races and earned more than $37 million.
LEAD: Johnny Carson is to stay on as host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC for at least another year - his 28th -through Sept. 1990.

LEAD: The setting of ''Measure for Measure'' is a city teeming with vice. Prostitution and alcohol plague the populace, unchecked by the state's lax law enforcement. Although the city is Vienna, we recognize the scene from closer to home. The questions raised - primarily, Where does justice intersect with morality, and how can it be obtained?

LEAD: The Tony Awards administration committee ruled yesterday that ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' is eligible for the award as best musical. The decision makes the show, at least for now, the prohibitive favorite in a category that carries the potential of millions of dollars in ticket sales.

LEAD: In a move that might mark a significant shift in strategic alignments in Africa, Nigeria's military Government is considering restoring diplomatic relations with Israel, according to diplomats and news reports here.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Henry Thomas Burns, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist who practiced for many years in New York City, died Monday at his home in Dorset, Vt. He was 95 years old and had also lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.
LEAD: Army Maj. Gen. James H. Rumbaugh, commander of Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died after making a parachute jump in Honduras, the Pentagon said today. He was 49 years old.

LEAD: Joe Marsh of St. Lawrence was named ECAC Hockey's coach of the year and Lane MacDonald of Harvard was named the most valuable player on the eve of the league's tournament in Boston. Marsh coached the Saints to 27 victories, the most in that college's history. MacDonald led Harvard to a 26-2 record, the best for the Crimson in 52 years.

LEAD: Brian Mullen, still dazed after having been checked hard in the first period, probably had it easier than his teammates. For reality was a terribly painful thing to have a good handle on in the Ranger locker room tonight.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation's cruise missile guidance system was never properly tested, and many of the nearly 1,800 nuclear missiles aboard the United States bomber fleet may not work, according court papers unsealed today.

LEAD: Ellen Minsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Minsky of Brookville, L.I., and Richard B. Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Diamond of New Hyde Park, L.I., were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz officiated.
