LEAD: The Gap Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel retailers, is negotiating to acquire its first men's wear chain, American Eagle Outfitters, executives close to the talks said yesterday.
LEAD: The Unites States detained a Soviet military attache, accused him of espionage and said it was expelling him. Page A10.
LEAD: Dr. Harold S. Ladas, a professor of psychology at Hunter College, died of cancer Tuesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens begins a weeklong visit to the United States today with a heavy schedule of high-level meetings and a mandate to find out whether Washington expects Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to proffer a serious peace initiative when he visits the White House next month.
LEAD: James Satterwhite, a social worker and educator, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The countdown began early today for the nation's 28th space shuttle mission, scheduled for launching at 8:07 A.M. Monday. It is the nation's third shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster more than three years ago.
LEAD: John Tobin Cassidy Jr., a retired shipping executive, died of heart failure Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Fort Worth. He was 76 years old and lived in Fort Worth.
LEAD: The Dalai Lama appealed today to Deng Xiaoping, the senior Chinese leader, to use his influence to lift martial law in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, testified today that Ronald Reagan told him not to tell Congress about contributions to the Nicaraguan rebels from a third country.
LEAD: After flying virtually empty for a week, the Eastern Airlines shuttle was chock-full of passengers yesterday as thousands of riders took advantage of the airline's new $12 one-way fare.
LEAD: International

LEAD: A Cloud Nine Consort - Gary Trosclair, trumpeter; Alan Moverman, pianist and synthesizer player; Erik Friedlander, cellist, and Geoffrey Gordon, percussionist - is to perform at the Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, at 15th Street, tonight at 8 P.M. The program includes compositions by three of the ensemble's players, Mr.

LEAD: Christoph Koch of Northeast Louisiana, who has been throwing the 35-pound weight for less than two months, became the first winner of a final at the 1989 National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships today at the Hoosier Dome.

LEAD: A Soviet-American trade conference will be held in San Franciso on May 23 to discuss the development of trade between the West Coast and the Soviet Far East. San Francisco's Mayor, Art Agnos, said Thursday that the conference would draw high-ranking regional business experts and scientific experts from both the United States and the Soviet Union.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sometimes Seton Hall seems like a team on an eternal quest for respect. Last season the Pirates were obsessed with getting it; they entered this season trying to build on it. And even after Coach P. J. Carlesimo received his second straight Big East coach of the year award on Thursday, he hinted that the reason he got it was that people still didn't believe Seton

LEAD: Audi of America says it feels vindicated by a Federal study concluding that drivers' ''misapplying'' their feet to gas and brake pedals was the principal cause of sudden, uncontrolled acceleration in some Audi 5000's.

LEAD: There were bad omens both for the Republican Party and black voters in the resignation last week of Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman, from the board of trustees of Howard University. He quit in the face of a student protest that, he feared, might lead to bloodshed.

LEAD: Georgetown, displaying perhaps its most ferocious defense of the season, broke away early and spent the rest of the game swatting away Boston College shots last night en route to an 82-52 victory in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden. Dana Barros had predicted it.
LEAD: Coach Bernie Bickerstaff of the Seattle SuperSonics was reported to be in stable condition yesterday after he was hospitalized Thursday for exhaustion and dehydration.
LEAD: Thousands of commuters were delayed in Manhattan last evening after the Staten Island Ferry developed electrical problems in a landing slip and in one of its ferries.

LEAD: According to its stated credo, the Manhattan Class Company is ''dedicated to finding, developing and producing a new generation of playwrights and theater artists.'' Such goals and objectives are to be heartily applauded, but judging by Evening A of the company's 1989 festival of new one-acts, someone needs to organize a search party.
LEAD: ''So, honey, what's your name?'' the man in the soup kitchen asked in his version of a streetwise flirt.

LEAD: Vera Cecelia Vento, a psychotherapist, and Dr. Eugene Leslie Jacobs, a psychiatrist, both in private practice in New York, were married yesterday. Justice Stanley Sklar of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated in his chambers.

LEAD: The violinist Shlomo Mintz has been named music adviser of the Israel Chamber Orchestra, the Mayor of Tel Aviv, Shlomo Lahat, who is also the orchesta's chairman, has announced. Mr. Mintz, who was born in the Soviet Union and raised in Israel, said he would conduct, perform as soloist, and play in chamber ensembles with the orchestra.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II named three resident Bishops today for Soviet Lithuania, a step seen as an important symbol for Roman Catholics in that Baltic republic and also a hint that progressively closer relations may be developing between Moscow and the Holy See.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Rev. Jerry Falwell told the 2,000 employees of his religious network today that they would be required to be members of his church and donate 10 percent of their income to it.

LEAD: Waging war over water beds may not seem important. But if Charles P. Hall wins his forthcoming patent trial, the self-proclaimed father of the modern water bed could revolutionize the way inventors finance court battles over patent infringement.

LEAD: Reading the entrails before the season's first performance of ''Eugene Onegin'' on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Opera, even a cautious seer might have predicted a dire outcome for Tchaikovsky's beloved work. The scheduled Tatyana, Mirella Freni, had taken ill and gone back to Italy to recuperate.

LEAD: Among the leaders of the Islamic faith, there are some who, in their zeal and absolutism and loathing of Western ideals, seem products of another era. Ibrahim Dasuki, the new Sultan of Sokoto, is not one of them.

LEAD: For 3,000 bridge players, today was a beginning - the beginning of the spring nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. For a few, it was also an ending, the end of the Grand National Pairs Championship. It began last summer at the grassroots level and progressed to the final, played here Wednesday and Thursday.

LEAD: The wife of the captain of the U.S.S. Vincennes, the Navy missile cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet in July, escaped uninjured this morning in what Federal agents suspect was a terrorist bombing.

LEAD: As he ended eight days on the witness stand yesterday at a Canadian inquiry into drugs and sports, Ben Johnson's coach said he hoped his testimony detailing the use of steroids by the world's fastest sprinter and other athletes he trained would lead to a cleanup of track and field.

LEAD: Devotees of the five previous installments of the endless ''Police Academy'' series will probably like this new one. It has a few good gags and the same energetic, spirited silliness of its predecessors. But if you have found the others to be more predictable than clever, this new one, subtitled ''City Under

LEAD: Mark Macon of Temple, who last year was selected as the Atlantic 10 Conference's top freshman basketball player, was voted the conference's player of the year yesterday. Macon, the first player to receive both awards, finished his second season with 1,234 points and was joined on the all-conference first team by Steve Berger and Darryl Prue of West Virginia, Tom Hovasse of Penn State and Tom Savage of Rutgers.(

LEAD: An official of the General Accounting Office told a Congressional hearing today that the liabilities of the savings industry's insurance fund now exceed its assets by $56 billion, four times the total of a year ago.

LEAD: Cabin fever ends. Gardening begins again. What to do first? The yard needs a thorough spring cleanup: remove dead grass, leaves and twigs, dropped tree fruits and other debris of winter. Cut back overgrown hedges, shrubs and small trees. All this gives you a head start before planting, which won't start until next month after the soil dries out.
LEAD: The Government announced that the airport in a strategic contested city was open again today, just days after guerrilla forces said they had taken it.
LEAD: The contract of Coach Ron DeCarli, whose St. Bonaventure team had a 13-15 record for the second season in a row, will not be renewed, according to Lawrence J. Weise, the athletic director.

LEAD: The Constitution says that criminals may not be tried twice for the same crime. But is it unconstitutional for a corporation that has willfully manufactured or distributed an unsafe product to be punished repeatedly for it?

LEAD: A commission created by President Bush recommended several proposals today to tighten Federal ethics laws and regulations, including a uniform limit on outside income accepted by members of Congress and other senior Federal officials.

LEAD: Former supporters of Unita, the United States-backed Angolan guerrilla movement, have asserted that the group's leader, Jonas Savimbi, has ordered the torture and killing of high-ranking dissenters in his ranks over many years.

LEAD: Eagle Industries today dropped its $22.50-a-share bid for the Ransburg Corporation, an Indianapolis-based industrial equipment maker, after reviewing information furnished by Ransburg. A lower bid by Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $21 a share, or a total of about $170 million, will proceed, however.

LEAD: After an initial period of high excitement about the creation of a single market of 320 million consumers by the end of 1992, Western European politicians and citizens have started to register skeptical and even frightened accents as hard decisions loom on pivotal issues.

LEAD: A former Federal prosecutor was judged not guilty by reason of insanity today in an agreement with the Government over a case in which she delivered anonymous threats to herself and a Federal magistrate, while pursuing the extradition of two Sikhs accused of terrorism in India.

LEAD: About 15 years ago Evel Knievel, who used to break his bones for a living, came to Manhattan to promote his forthcoming attempt to raise motor sports to an unparalleled height. He would attempt to soar across the mile-wide, 600-foot-deep Snake River Canyon in a steam-powered, open-pit, rocketlike contraption called a Sky

LEAD: The Nissan Motor Corporation said it would raise the price of its two-door Pathfinder models by an average of $1,500 effective Monday in response to a recent Treasury Department ruling that the vehicle was intended primarily for commercial use and was therefore subject to a 25 percent import duty.

LEAD: Ingemar Stenmark, the slalom and giant slalom specialist who won a record 86 World Cup races in his 16-year career, retired yesterday after a final race. The Swedish star missed a gate just seconds after he started the first run of a World Cup slalom race in Shiga Kogen, Japan. But Stenmark, who turns 33 in a week, was not disappointed.
LEAD: The main Afrikaner church has for the first time unequivocally condemned apartheid.

LEAD: Brushing aside Congressional critics who say the Federal Government's policy of detaining Central American refugees is unfair and ineffective, the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service has warned that if illegal immigrants continue to cross the border he will house them in jails and military stockades.

LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf has always been good at assembling programs, and for his current subscription concerts with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, he has put together an ingenious one. The music is all from the 20th century, but conservatively so - nothing after 1942 or overtly dissonant, but two late Romantic scores along with two neo

LEAD: Last fall, University of Michigan anthropologists showed that human tooth size has been shrinking twice as fast in the last 10,000 years as in the previous 90,000. Why? One night a Neanderthal threw a flash-frozen hunk of mammoth on the fire and rendered redundant the kind of choppers one needs to make mincemeat out of raw flesh.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Fred Mogubgub, an artist and animator, died of bone cancer on Thursday at his home in Cliffside Park, N.J. He was 61 years old.
LEAD: The nation's unemployment rate dropped sharply in February, to 5.1 percent, as the economy continued to generate jobs at a brisk pace, the Labor Department reported today.

LEAD: Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School portrayed in the film ''Lean on Me,'' has been ordered suspended by the superintendent of schools because he arranged a school assembly at which strippers performed, officials said.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency, acting to reduce urban smog, announced new rules today to limit gasoline fumes this summer.

LEAD: Minutes after his team recorded a stunning upset in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, Coach Bob Wade of Maryland was stricken with chest pains and rushed from the locker room at the Omni to a hospital here.

LEAD: Because Medicare and other insurance programs require filling out complicated forms and following complicated procedures, the elderly, the very people these programs are supposed to help, frequently fail to take advantage of them. So medical-claims companies will step into the breach - for a fee.
LEAD: Prof. Albert Fein, a historian and an authority on the work of the landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58 years old.
LEAD: Egypt denied today that it had acquired Swiss technology to improve its ability to manufacture chemical weapons.
LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government announced today that it would pardon 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard by March 19.
LEAD: The unemployment rate in New York State rose slighty last month, and the New Jersey rate remained unchanged, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

LEAD: When the industrialist William K. Vanderbilt Jr. completed a 48-mile toll road from Queens to Lake Ronkonkoma in Suffolk County in 1911, his pet project became the nation's first modern parkway.

LEAD: The Labor Department has advised the trustee for the Polaroid Corporation's employee stock ownership plan that it should exercise its own judgment in deciding whether to tender the shares in the plan, an official of the trustee said yesterday.
LEAD: To most people, tires are boring. They are black. They are round. They hold air - sometimes - and they are just there.
LEAD: Acknowledging ''realities we cannot deny,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady today proposed a major shift in the goals of the industrial world's third-world debt policy.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the text of Treasury Secretary's Nicholas F. Brady's remarks today to the Brookings Institution and the Bretton Woods Committee conference on third-world debt:
LEAD: West Berlin's Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens reached a power-sharing agreement today that clears the way for the first ''Red-Green'' left-wing coalition to rule the city.
LEAD: Managua Prisoner Release

LEAD: In nominating Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming as Secretary of Defense today, President Bush picked a well-respected politician with a reputation for toughness and a powerful political resume, but with relatively little direct involvement in military affairs.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, replying to the complaints of a coalition of more than 30 Hispanic groups, will take steps to improve police services in precincts with large Latino populations, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday.

LEAD: Right now, there is no deal. The Mets and the Yankees met, talked, and drew up lists of players, but when the two sides emerged late this morning, they squelched any possibility that a trade might take place.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 32.

LEAD: N.B.A. Lakers 123, Hornets 90: Byron Scott scored 25 points for Los Angeles last night and James Worthy had 20 as Charlotte, playing at home, suffered its sixth straight loss. The outcome was never in doubt. The Lakers, who made 58 percent of their shots in the game, led by 37-21 after the first period and built their lead to 41 points early in the fourth quarter.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Moving swiftly to select a new Secretary of Defense after the Senate's defeat of John G. Tower, President Bush announced today that he would nominate Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, a popular and respected member of the Republican leadership.

LEAD: Under increasing international pressure, the Sudanese Government says it has agreed to large-scale deliveries of relief food intended to avert a repetition of the hundreds of thousands of deaths from starvation that occurred last year.
LEAD: A tug-of-war has begun between the pilots' union and Eastern Airlines for the loyalty of pilots in the week-old strike by machinists that has paralyzed the airline.

LEAD: Headlines on Thursday with a front-page article about a massacre of Polish officers in World War II, and with the article's continuation, located the Katyn Forest incorrectly in some editions. It is in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The Israel Philharmonic is a fairly frequent visitor to New York, but its concerts are always welcome. That is not because it is a brilliant virtuoso ensemble at the absolutely top international level. It is because, at its best, this orchestra offers deeply musical, songful performances that evince a spirit and a personality more important than mere virtuosity.

LEAD: Andrew J. Stein, a Democrat, has virtually abandoned his New York City mayoral ambitions for this year and is now seeking Republican and Liberal Party endorsements that would guarantee he is re-elected City Council president in a landslide.
LEAD: Brian Mullen, who was blindsided in the first period of Thursday night's 3-2 loss in Detroit, has been cleared to play tonight against the Capitals in Landover, Md.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The judge who presided over Joel B. Steinberg's murder trial derided Mr. Steinberg yesterday for asking for a Probation Department pre-sentencing interview after he had three times refused the department's requests to interview him while granting interviews to reporters.
LEAD: The United Nations Human Rights Commission ended its annual session today without making provisions to review human rights abuses by Cuba again next year, as the Bush Administration wanted.

LEAD: A brief article by Reuters in some copies yesterday about violence in the Israeli-occupied territories misstated the number of deaths. Two Palestinians died - one after a clash in Gaza City and one near Ramallah.

LEAD: Every arms control negotiation combines a concern with the details of what is to be agreed to and, since arms control is not an end in itself, the broader political purpose sought by either side. The negotiations on conventional forces in Europe that have begun in Vienna are no exception.

LEAD: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 11.50 11.50 8.50 DISCOUNT RATE 7.00 7.00 6.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 9.80 9.89 6.60 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 8.75 8.66 5.74 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 8.79 8.65 5.85 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 9.38 9.29 8.08 30-YR.

LEAD: An Army warrant officer who admitted receiving more than $100,000 from 1983 to 1988 to provide classified military information to East Germany and the Soviet Union was sentenced today to 40 years confinement and was fined $50,000.

LEAD: International 3-6, 28 Skepticism over a European market to be unified in 1992 is growing among Western European politicians and citizens as hard decisions loom on pivotal issues, like a European central bank. Page 1 Jonas Savimbi has ordered torture and murder of high-ranking Angolan dissenters for many years within the ranks of his U.S.-backed guerrilla movement, former supporters asserted.
LEAD: Six weeks after receiving the offer, the Illinois Central Transportation Company agreed today to merge with the Prospect Group for $20 a share, or roughly $435 million.

LEAD: While meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., with major league club owners for the last time before leaving office March 31, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday asked the 26 teams to impose a voluntary freeze on ticket prices for the next three years, which he said would amount to forgoing about $200 million.

LEAD: Dr. Frank J. Curran, a Manhattan psychiatrist, died Wednesday at New York Hospital after being hit by a car. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan. From 1945 to 1947, he was chief psychiatrist at St. Vincent's Hospital. He resigned from the post after Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, then a professor at Catholic University, denounced psychoanalysis as an escapist substitute for confession.

LEAD: For several years now I have thought on and off about writing a fan letter to Tatiana Troyanos, who gave a song recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. ''Dear Ms. Troyanos,'' it would say, ''thanks for showing up tonight and singing your part.'' It could come after any one of the dozens of Metropolitan
LEAD: Leslie Hansen Kopp has her favorite horror stories about the preservation of cultural history.
LEAD: After Pitt's coach got angry last night, the players got even.
LEAD: Top American trade negotiators met today with officials of the European Community for talks that are expected to focus on the contentious issue of farm subsidies.

LEAD: It isn't very often that the works of Doris Humphrey are presented in New York. And so we are in debt to the Philadelphia Dance Company, which performed on Monday night at the Borough of Manhattan Community College's Triplex Theater, in a program of three works by that pioneering American modern dancer as well as dances by Jose Limon and Eleanor King.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.
LEAD: A senior Soviet arms control expert told Congress today that the Soviet Union was engaged in the most sweeping restructuring of its military since the 1920's, and he provided some details.

LEAD: The Lindsay String Quartet, an ensemble from England, is to perform Haydn's Quartet in G (Op. 54, No. 1), Britten's Quartet No. 3 (Op. 87) and Beethoven's Quartet in F (Op. 135) on Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $12. Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, who was considered an early favorite in the 1990 race to succeed retiring Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, announced today that he and his wife are separating and that he will not run for governor.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had received permission from a Federal bankruptcy judge to continue paying its nonstriking employees, a corporate life-saving maneuver that permits the beleaguered airline to continue its limited flights.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Philip D. Reed, a former chairman of the General Electric Company and a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died yesterday at his home in Rye, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.
LEAD: As the number of Americans over age 65 increases, services to meet their needs are growing rapidly.

LEAD: Two aerospace engineers at Princeton University won a patent this week for a new supercomputer that they contend is 100 times as fast as the current state-of-the-art machines. The computer is a parallel processing machine, in which complex problems are broken down into component parts and solved simultaneously by separate processors.
LEAD: Edward H. Mahla, a lawyer specializing in maritime law, died of cancer Wednesday at Calvary Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury debt issues plunged after the Government reported an unexpectedly large increase in new jobs last month.

LEAD: When Long Islanders sweat in the dark during next summer's electricity blackouts, as now seems possible, they'll likely wonder whom to blame. The answers will be: (1) Gov. Mario Cuomo, (2) Suffolk County and (3) themselves.

LEAD: Growing old gracefully is costly in America, and it is becoming costlier as medical costs escalate and employers aggressively seek ways to control the costs of health-care benefits, particularly for retirees. Indeed, much of the Conference Board's 1989 Employee Benefits Conference in New York earlier this week was devoted to health care.

LEAD: Members of Housing for All demonstrating outside Low Library at the university yesterday. They were protesting the eviction of a former student, Irving Ruderman, from a university apartment on West 119th Street in which he had been living since 1971. A university spokesman, Fred Knubel, said Mr. Ruderman was evicted because he had not taken classes at Columbia since moving in.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Continuing the personnel changes that began earlier this year, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday announced new appointments and shifts in the operating structure of parts of the firm.

LEAD: A crowded Broadway-local subway train slammed into a parked revenue train on the Upper West Side of Manhattan early yesterday, jolting hundreds of passengers and transit workers, derailing both trains and halting subway service for 35,000 riders much of the day.

LEAD: This year's New York Flower Show, which has been brightening a Hudson River pier since last week and ends today, is bigger and prettier than ever. It also gives the visitor yet more cause to wish for big bucks. On display are a gazebo, a greenhouse, a conservatory, a lily pond, a Japanese tea house and a

LEAD: With the usual pomp and more than the usual respect, Hollywood crowded into a ballroom Thursday night to honor Gregory Peck, whose screen image - from his first starring role as a priest in ''Keys of the Kingdom'' to his Academy Award-winning role as a small-town Southern lawyer defending a black man in ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' - has been composed of equal parts of decency, virtue and moral strength.

LEAD: Kermit K. Beahan, who dropped the atomic bomb on Nagasaki, Japan, died of cardiac arrest Thursday at St. John Hospital in nearby Nassau Bay, a day after undergoing prostate surgery. He was 70 years old and lived in Clear Lake, a Houston suburb.
LEAD: Daughter of Destiny By Benazir Bhutto Illustrated. 411 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21.95
LEAD: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said today that the furor over the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' could be resolved by burning all existing copies of the book and banning it forever.

LEAD: At a time when their relations are strained, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have been thrown into the front line in a global battle to try to reduce the stock of debt, last valued at more than $1.3 trillion, that is crushing economies of the third world.
LEAD: Vermont, a sixth-place team in the league standing this season, upset Harvard in overtime tonight, 3-2, in the ECAC tournament at Boston Garden.
LEAD: ''I think it's time to let emotions heal now, let the scars begin to heal.'' - Senator Sam Nunn. [ 10:2. ]

LEAD: An investment group led by Andrew N. Heine, chairman and chief executive of Kinney System Inc., said yesterday that it had offered to pay $572 million for the DWG Corporation, which is headed by the Miami financier Victor Posner.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush and Representative Dick Cheney in Washington today when Mr. Bush announced his nomination of Mr. Cheney to be Secretary of Defense, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENTS

LEAD: Iowa's first television station, KWQC-TV of Davenport, has been offered for sale by Palmer Communications Inc. William Ryan, president and chief executive of Palmer, a privately held communications company based in Des Moines, said this week that Palmer had hired Howard Stark, a New York television broker, to sell the station.
LEAD: A committee of the Legislature has voted 7 to 3 to rename North Dakota just plain Dakota, junking an ''unimaginative, unattractive, ordinary'' word.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines spokesmen, travel industry officials and consumer experts yesterday began to provide some answers to the questions asked by the thousands of worried Eastern ticket-holders who have been swamping the offices and telephone lines of their travel agents, hoping for a refund or a flight on another airline.
LEAD: Personal bankruptcy may have lost much of its stigma, but a consumer counseling organization is warning in a national television ad campaign that it is has not lost all of its sting.

LEAD: Revising its earlier announced figure, the New York City Board of Elections said yesterday that 703 candidates had filed nominating petitions to run in the May 2 elections for community school boards.

LEAD: There are those who say that Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., should stick to the business where he made his reputation - corporate raiding. And there are those who say that for a corporate raider, he makes a pretty good airline man.
LEAD: The Zimbabwean Defense Minister said today that he would resign after admitting that he had lied to a judicial inquiry into a corruption scandal involving the sale of scarce new cars.

LEAD: Frederick R. Moseley Jr., former executive vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died of bone cancer yesterday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Jericho, L.I.
LEAD: Ever get to San Francisco and decide to visit a friend in Sausalito? How do you drive there?

LEAD: No sooner had the Famous Writers spoken out in support of the beleagured Salman Rushdie, and declared themselves outraged by an attempted act of international terrorism on the part of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini than the Insufficiently Famous Writers leaped to attack them.

LEAD: The idea of baseball players as boys is embedded in popular mythology, thanks to the works of Ring Lardner, who spent a lot of time with ballplayers a long time ago and was fascinated by their childishness.

LEAD: President Bush has acted quickly and adroitly to transcend the Tower fiasco by nominating Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming as Secretary of Defense. Mr. Cheney is smart, generally knowledgeable about national security, very conservative, a party loyalist, honorable and exceedingly popular among Democrats and Republicans.
LEAD: An Air Ontario jetliner carrying 69 people crashed in thick woods just after taking off in heavy snow yesterday from Dryden, Ontario, an official for the airline said.

LEAD: As Poland's Communists agreed Thursday to restore the upper house of Parliament, some may have wondered whether the move was an unwitting preparation for the party's ultimate political demise, or just a clever step toward co-opting an unwary Solidarity trade union.

LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation said today that a Federal jury in Beaumont, Tex., had awarded $345 million in damages from the Santa Fe Corporation and its Santa Fe Railroad Company in a lawsuit that accused Santa Fe of illegally conspiring to interfere with the construction of a coal-slurry pipeline by a joint venture Texas
LEAD: Gino P. Cofacci, a retired pastry chef, died of cancer March 1 in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Aides to William J. Bennett, head of the Bush Administration's anti-drug effort, have protested plans by the Department of Health and Human Services to support local programs that give drug addicts hypodermic needles in an effort to stem the spread of AIDS.

LEAD: The caterwauling battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Defense Secretary, which ended in the Senate's defeat of Mr. Tower on Thursday, robbed President Bush of precious political and governmental energy at a crucial moment.

LEAD: A group led by Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth investor, has acquired 2.6 million shares, or a 7.2 percent stake, of Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis-based software and data-processing concern, for investment purposes only. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it planned to hold talks with the

LEAD: The Bresler's ice cream chain has been purchased by an investor group including the division's president for an undisclosed sum from its parent company, Oberweis Dairy Inc. The Bresler's division, which will become Bresler's Industries, is the franchisor of more than 300 Bresler's Ice Cream and Yogurt Shops nationwide.
LEAD: Alison L. Gertz wasn't supposed to get AIDS.
LEAD: Thousands of travelers with tickets for Eastern flights are asking, and finally getting, answers to their questions about refunds. Page 8.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and New York Attorney General Robert Abrams, testifying publicly for the first time about their fund-raising practices, told a state ethics commission today that they deplored asking special-interest groups for money but felt they were forced to use such methods to win re-election.
LEAD: It took all the resilience Syracuse had to survive its Big East tournament opener yesterday against Providence.
LEAD: Eleanore Lucille King McGroarty, a Brooklyn philanthropic leader, died of a stroke Wednesday at Greenwich Woods (Conn.) Medical Center. She was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: The vast sculptural expanse of ''Tilted Arc,'' which provoked one of the greatest artistic controversies in recent New York City history, is to be removed today from the lower Manhattan plaza for which it was commissioned. It will be taken off to storage in Brooklyn.
LEAD: Robert B. Betts, former chairman of the William Esty advertising agency, now Campbell-Mithun-Esty, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Seven young men were arrested on robbery charges yesterday after they threatened employees and snatched merchandise from three Madison Avenue stores, the police said.

LEAD: ''For more than half an hour 38 respectable, law-abiding citizens in Queens watched a killer stalk and stab a woman in three separate attacks in Kew Gardens.'' - The New York Times, March 27, 1964 So began a story that shook this city's soul. Except for one man who called the police after the woman was already dead, none of the 38 lifted a hand for Catherine Genovese, Kitty to the neighborhood.

LEAD: Growing numbers of middle-aged Americans whose children have grown up and gone off, or those who assumed they would soon have an empty nest, are leaving the porch light on for offspring who are returning home to stay well into their 20's and 30's.

LEAD: Emerging from an unusual four-day meeting with the Pope and his aides, Roman Catholic archbishops from the United States said today the session had largely succeeded in counteracting misunderstanding between the Vatican and the American Catholic hierarchy.
LEAD: What happened to Pitt yesterday has happened to many teams confronted with Georgetown's suffocating defense this season.
LEAD: It's nothing to fall down laughing about, but a professorship in humor will move onto Brooklyn College's campus in the fall.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The man judged the International Federation of Body Builders' Mr. Universe for 1987 was arrested Friday at a hotel in Columbus, Ohio, on charges of conspiracy and trafficking in illegal anaebolic steroids, the United States Customs Service said yesterday. Luis O. Batista Freitos, 33, a Brazilian national who lives in Marina Del Rey, Calif., was arrested while he was in Columbus to attend the Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic contest.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ALTHOUGH quick to admire our modern city, more than a few of us in White Plains have begun to lament its meteoric growth. Downtown, imposing structures of shimmering glass and colored concrete have added the ''plaza'' or ''center'' to their new business addresses. A drive to the train station now winds you onto a approach similar to that of an airport.

LEAD: HAVE you ever heard the grass say ''Ouch!'' when you step on it? I have. In squeaky voices, the slender stalks of green shout in fragmented choruses, sounding much like the cacophony you hear when entering a large cafeteria, only octaves higher.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When the Metropolitan opera set out to cast the revival of ''Rigoletto'' that opens Thursday, a natural choice for the youthful purity of Gilda was the young soprano who had sparkled in recent seasons as Mozart's Susanna and Puccini's Mimi, Hei-Kyung Hong.

LEAD: PERVASIVE guilt over government's failure to adequately monitor the maintenance of nursing home standards, coupled with the realization that there is a rapidly increasing older population that will need institutional care, has motivated America to get busy and ''fix them up.''

LEAD: The Mets should trade Strawberry only if, after the 1989 season, he and his ill-advising adviser, Eric Goldschmidt, are unbudgingly determined to leave New York. No team can afford to lose a talent like Strawberry to free agency without first trying to get several good players in return through a trade.

LEAD: A caption on Feb. 12 on the Thursday Highlights page of the Television section, distributed in the New York region, gave an incorrect cause for the 1955 death of the actor James Dean. It was an automobile accident.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that its evidence pointed to a pipe bomb as the device used in the explosion of a car driven by Sharon Lee Rogers, the wife of the captain of the Navy cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet in July.

LEAD: Hilary Joy Frankel and Carl Loeb Kempner Jr. were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Mark Goldman at the Metropolitan Club in New York. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Frankel of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kempner of White Plains.

LEAD: MANY police departments in Westchester may soon join the ranks of law-enforcement agencies nationwide that are replacing the time-honored .38-caliber revolver with a 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol as a standard weapon. The change comes primarily because of mounting evidence that criminals - especially drug dealers - are better armed than ever.

LEAD: WITH his first book, ''Mayor,'' Edward I. Koch landed simultaneously on the best-seller list and in hot water, not that he seemed to mind. In a catalogue of confrontation and conflict that some found both mean and entertaining, Mr. Koch wrote of making President Carter turn gray, Representative Charles B.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: At the Swarthmore (Pa.) Meeting House, Kelley Lee Noyes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Noyes of Media, Pa., was married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony to William Chauncey Keator 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrit M. Keator of Pomfret, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt.

LEAD: WHEN I was growing up, Chianti meant Italian wine in basketed round-bellied flasks. Little did I know that one day the word Chianti would instantly evoke the most wrenchingly beautiful landscape I know.

LEAD: ART FROM DROSS Apparently, one man's garbage can be another's art. So today, the always-adventurous Islip Art Museum opens ''Dross to Art,'' a group exhibition showcasing nine artists who use dross - defined as ''refuse, rubbish, impure matter'' - to make their creative statements.

LEAD: THE fate of an 18-story condominium under construction at Forest Street and Greylock Place in Stamford - it will be the city's tallest and most luxurious apartment building - is being watched closely by local officials, developers and realtors who consider it a key component in creating an upscale downtown housing market.
LEAD: THE STOLEN LIGHT Continents of Exile. tr,br1By Ved Mehta. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: John Handy's first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night started out sluggishly; the rhythm section couldn't find a groove, and Mr. Handy, when he improvised, just added to the set's sullenness. About halfway through the second tune of the first set, Mr. Handy and the rhythm section found equal ground, and like an engine finally starting up in the cold, they took off.

LEAD: As a justice of the peace, I married a young couple fresh off the slopes, in ski clothes, last winter. No wedding party, no reception. They planned it that way the summer before. As far as I know, they went back, hand in hand, to wait in line for the chairlift after I pronounced them husband and wife in the Stratton Mountain Chapel,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lisa Bianco, an advocate for battered women who had been beaten for years by her former husband, took little comfort in his imprisonment for brutally attacking her two years ago. Instead, she lived in daily fear that he would make good his threats to kill her.
LEAD: The usual visitors to the Emerson Art Gallery at Hamilton College here are being joined these days by farmers, children, vintage-car buffs and people whose hobby is whittling.
LEAD: Youth has been celebrated at two events already this month, one for the Junior Committee of the Museum of Modern Art and the other for young clothing-design students.
LEAD: Johnny Carson is to remain the host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC for at least another year - his 28th -through September 1990, he announced Wednesday night.

LEAD: Presenting a whole series of exhibitions, movies, lectures, colloquies and (not least) a dance performance to mark the bicentennial of the French Revolution, the New York Public Library has grasped a nettle that other institutions have so far approached with leather gauntlets (if at all). It took thought, and care, and courage.

LEAD: THE influx of weekenders in the town of Washington is often cited for problems ranging from the high price of real estate to the lack of parking spaces in front of the local grocery. Now, a New York sociologist who is herself a weekender is trying to separate fact from fiction by studying exactly how weekenders are changing the nature of the small Litchfield

LEAD: TWELVE years after President Carter declared ''the moral equivalent of war'' against the waste of dwindling supplies of energy, the United States appears to have won a few battles and forgotten the war.

LEAD: Evander Holyfield won the Continental Americas heavyweight title tonight when he stopped Michael Dokes at 1:41 of the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout at Caesars Palace. It was a furiously waged punching match, with both fighters landing haymakers from the opening bell.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday of work by the photographer Robert Adams incorrectly named the artist who is the subject of the ''American Photographs'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. He is Walker Evans.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 2 2 2 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie.

LEAD: A pilot program is getting under way here and in three other cities to see whether foreclosed and vacated residential property can be transformed into housing for low- to moderate-income people.
LEAD: The wedding of Alice Bayard Forster and Robert Allan Griffin took place in New York yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frank of Englewood, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ellen Frank, to David Bick Edelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Edelson of Ridgewood, N.J. A May 6 wedding is planned.

LEAD: The proposed merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. will create a $15 billion media company - the largest in the world. Time-Warner will be a major force in cable television, movie production, magazines and book publishing. The merger still must be approved by the stockholders of the two companies and on April 4, the Senate Antitrust Committee will review the deal.

LEAD: The assets of the Harvard hockey team rarely accrue to an Ivy League sports component these days. There are two brilliant Olympic skaters in Lane MacDonald and Allen Bourbeau, two fine freshman goaltenders, Chuckie Hughes and Allain Roy, and three outstanding lines of almost equal scoring potency.

LEAD: Daniel T. Adams, a former executive vice president of Marine Midland Bank, died of heart failure yesterday at Mediplex Nursing Home in Westport, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived Wilton, Conn., and Manhattan.
LEAD: Charles E. McDonnell, a stockbroker, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: I was a sophomore at the Rutgers-Newark campus in the fall of 1966. My major was mathematics, and I was required to take a laboratory course in physics - one designed for physics and mathematics majors. I had already attempted this course as a freshman and dropped it when I realized there was no way

LEAD: Absolutely. Strawberry thinks his $7.2 million contract is an insult to himself and his family. If $7.2 million is an insult, I make the following appeal to Mets management on behalf of myself, my wife, and our two cats: insult us! insult us! MICHAEL KELLER Kew Garden, Queens
LEAD: INTELLECTUALS By Paul Johnson. 385 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.
LEAD: LONG Island's school districts, under increasing Federal and state pressure to upgrade their buildings, are preparing sweeping plans for improvements.
LEAD: THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL By Douglas Adams. 319 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: Like the short story, one-act operas require a concentration powerful enough to sustain single trains of thought over brief periods of time, rather than the long-range stamina needed to juggle many. Hugo Weisgall - who was born in Czechoslovakia in 1912 and raised in Baltimore -has made something of a specialty of the genre.

LEAD: Eugene Bondi, a cellist, offered an inconsistent but largely pleasing evening of solo and chamber music Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. It was evident that he had devoted time and care to considering the music's impulses, and that he had firm personal views about the composers' intentions.

LEAD: I find the letter by Leonard Garment, Robert McFarlane's counsel, morally offensive and, sadly, too characteristic of the Washington mindset (Letters, Feb. 12, in response to ''Bud McFarlane: Semper Fi,'' by Brock Brower, Jan. 22).

LEAD: Davis Love 3d shot an eagle 3 and a birdie 3 on the first two holes at the Bay Hill Club today, breaking a three-way deadlock for the lead. Then he continued on to a 5-under-par 66 and took a 2-shot margin over Tom Kite entering Sunday's final round of the $800,000 Nestle Invitational.

LEAD: The guerrilla rockets started to hit the eastern districts of this capital shortly after 3 P.M. today, sending great clouds of dust rising into the still winter air. At the Kabul Intercontinental Hotel, a man sweeping the tennis court paused for a while to watch, then calmly resumed his work.

LEAD: THE automotive industry accomplished a remarkable technological feat between 1975 and 1985 by nearly doubling the number of miles that cars and light trucks were able to travel on a gallon of gasoline. But now further progress is in jeopardy. At a time when oil imports are rising, domestic oil production is decreasing and environmentalists are warning of the need to curb atmospheric pollution, car makers are lobbying for relaxed fuel efficiency standards.

LEAD: A MATTER OF DAYS. By Albert Lebowitz. (Louisiana State University, $15.95.) Albert Lebowitz, an attorney who lives in St. Louis, has applied much ingenuity to fashioning an intertwined series of nine stories, each with the word ''day'' in the title, in which a small pool of characters make repeat appearances.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Heidi, the witty but spiritually wounded art historian in Wendy Wasserstein's play ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' opened on Broadway last Thursday. To most people who followed her travails during the play's sold-out run at Playwrights Horizons on West 42d Street, Heidi and her friends won't look much different at the Plymouth, a Shubert theater on West 45th Street.
LEAD: AN EXPOSURE OF THE HEART By Rebecca Busselle. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY has started taking inventory. Last November, city voters overwhelmingly approved what seemed to be a simple, not to say obvious, notion: a requirement that officials take an accounting of the badly aging infrastructure of roadways, bridges, parks and buildings, and draw up a plan for regular maintenance.

LEAD: Although diaper delivery vendors may have gained some market share from disposables last year, American producers of cloth diapers did not reap much of the benefit. A surge in imports from China in 1986 all but drove American cloth diaper producers from the delivery market. Imports of heavy-ply cloth diapers from China climbed to 1.06 million pounds that year, up from just over 82,000 pounds in 1985.
LEAD: Move over, NBC, ABC and CBS. Here comes HTV, Hofstra University's own television network.

LEAD: To the Editors: So six years from hence Joe Papp's to present To those who sat through His Shakespeare to-do A shirt with the scrawl Of ''I've seen it all.'' But one must rebut ''Except what was cut.'' THOMAS CARON Union City, N.J.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 2 1 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death.

LEAD: ''How picturesque they are, the missed trains!'' This line by the 19th-century poet Jules Laforgue set the tone for much of the modern poetry that followed him. At 10:30 on a Tuesday night, Grand Central Terminal seems to be filled with people who have missed their trains and who have given up the idea of transition or of making connections.
LEAD: The State Supreme Court has upheld an order prohibiting a divorced woman from having an unrelated man stay overnight with her in her home when her children are present.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Suzanne Powell Bishopric and Michael James Manning were married yesterday by the Rev. Susan Harriss at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The bride is a daughter of Anne Bishopric Sager of Venice, Fla., and Dr. George Andrew Bishopric of Sarasota, Fla. Mr. Manning is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J.

LEAD: Eddie Bert, a trombonist, brought a quintet to Birdland on Thursday night that included two musicians more familiar from old Miles Davis and Charlie Parker records than from recent appearances on New York stages: Davey Schildkraut on tenor saxophone (he played alto in the 1940's and 1950's) and Duke Jordan on piano.

LEAD: The engagement of Susan Marie Busch 2d to Hal Garwood Transou 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal G. Transou Jr. of Greensboro, N.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Susan M. Busch and August A. Busch 3d of St. Louis. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: IT has been almost a century since the Metropolitan Street Railway Company opened a power station at 141 East 25th Street with state-of-the-art conveyor systems to deliver coal and retrieve ash from immense boilers that gave life to cable cars traveling as far north as 105th Street.

LEAD: WEST GERMAN science passed a milestone of sorts this month when the Government's Central Commission for Biological Safety approved an experiment involving 37,000 petunias genetically altered to be pink when they bloom next May.

LEAD: Large numbers of Central American refugees continue to apply for political asylum in cities around the country, although on the Rio Grande at Brownsville, Tex., the Government has largely succeeded in stopping them.

LEAD: WHEN ''Gone With the Wind'' premiered in Bridgeport 50 years ago, it took me two weeks to persuade my mother to take me with her to see it. She and all of her friends were in various stages of reading Margaret Mitchell's novel. Unfortunately for me, Marion Bailey, among them, had finished it, and it was her cryptic four-word critique that sounded the death knell that nearly ruined my chance to view this spectacle at its first showing.

LEAD: The Jan. 29 article ''Bill to Arm Guards at Malls Is Debated'' raises a number of important issues concerning private security. By way of introduction: I retired as a detective lieutenant in New York City Police Department in 1987 and am currently involved in security management research and training.

LEAD: Internecine quarrels aside, what's a harmless little kiss? Does Mozart compose without a family? Does Picasso paint without being born? And haven't we all seen the torture of being born to a violent wind? New York lost an entire organization to L.A. Must we lose Darryl Strawberry, too? ROBERT GUADAGNINO $

LEAD: The Venice of the past was re-created briefly at the Waldorf-Astoria last week at a Venetian Masked Purim Ball to benefit the Jewish Museum. Drifting through the grand ballroom were gondoliers, minstrels and an actress who glided majestically on stilts.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, the Music View column on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the transcriptions of Wagner works performed in piano recordings by Glenn Gould. They are by Gould himself.

LEAD: FROM A BELVEDERE ON THE JANICULUM -that most verdant of Rome's hills, bounded on one side by St. Peter's and on the other by Rome and the world - the eye picks out, from among the gorgeous clutter of Roman roofs, two declarative edifices: the Pantheon, its gray rotunda looking from this perspective like a hovering spacecraft; and the great dome of the Temple, Rome's eclectic neo-Byzantine synagogue.

LEAD: Picture a fashion show by the hip designer Stephen Sprouse at a cavernous East Village club. Picture, milling around in the smoke, to the blasts of Metallica, the downtown New York art world in full regalia. A sea of black leather on black studded with hardware, micro-minis in eye-searing hues, leopard jumpsuits, mohawks, crenelated towers of hair to rival Louis Quatorze.

LEAD: TWO farmers in plaid shirts sat quietly through the entire meeting, just in front of Jan Thompson from the Save Our Swamp group of Paterson, an organization that was formed to defend a wetland called Dismal Swamp.

LEAD: For all that Seton Hall had accomplished in the last two years, including a school-record 26 victories this season, the Pirates approached yesterday's Big East Conference semifinal game against Syracuse as a litmus test, not so much of skill but of ingenuity and fortitude.

LEAD: Rose Parsons Lynch of New Canaan, Conn., and R. Vincent Lynch of Dallas, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Rose Peabody Lynch, to James Alexander Torrey, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clare M. Torrey of New York. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: It is probably true that the majority of entering freshmen in some colleges and universities in the United States know more than graduating seniors in others. The strength of American higher education is its diversity, which is characterized by widely differing standards and expectations at both the entry and degree-completion levels.

LEAD: Everyone has a bad-luck something in their wardrobe, a tie that's a magnet for food, a dress that has to go to the cleaner after every wearing, a hat that flies off when a breeze whispers, a pair of fragile shoes that guarantee, once out the door, that a beautiful day will turn into a sodden mess.
LEAD: The foreign policy reviews to provide the Bush Administration with a new look at the Reagan heritage are going on feverishly around the capital, despite many still-empty offices.

LEAD: SUMMER EATING MEANS dirty hands, and most people's fondest memories of hot-weather customs involve licking fingers clean of sticky crimson barbecue sauce or crisp bits of fried chicken batter, or running a thumb along a dasher for the first taste of ice cream that took forever to freeze.
LEAD: Television's version of the successful career woman, circa 1980, was a glamorous creature in a big picture hat, with huge diamonds sparkling at her ears and a fox boa draped around her neck.
LEAD: Read into it, whatever significance you will, but the Greek Games, a once-hardy perennial of Barnard College life, are returning to campus after a 22-year absence.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hard by the runways of Stapleton International Airport lies the strangest of environmental paradoxes: a blotch of grotesquely polluted land teeming with a profusion of wildlife that evokes comparisons to Yellowstone National Park.

LEAD: Nancy Elizabeth Orr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Orr of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday in Evanston, Ill., to James Marshall Shepherd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Shepherd of Indianapolis. The ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Evanston was performed by Pastor E.

LEAD: The centerpiece of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's current program - played Friday night and to be repeated this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall - is a new quintet by Ned Rorem, called ''Bright Music'' and scored for flute, two violins, cello and piano.

LEAD: It's a long season. At some point in June or July when Darryl comes to bat in a close game with the bases loaded, and radio announcers for both teams are discussing the possibility of an intentional walk, then all of his bad behavior of the spring will be forgotten. You just can't trade a player like that.

LEAD: I WAS SCARED. I KNEW SOMETHING WAS GONNA HAPPEN,'' HEATH Wilkins recalls. ''My life had become unbearable to me. It was the first time I was out on my own, the first time nobody was responsible for me - see what I'm saying?''

LEAD: THE average college student of the 1980's wants a secure, well-paying job with opportunities for promotion; his counterpart from the 1970's and 60's wanted to help mankind and change the world, said Douglas Daring, director of the Career Services Department at the University of Connecticut.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines sought protection in bankruptcy court as a week-old strike crippled its operations and cash flow. Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's corporate parent, the Texas Air Corporation, said the bankruptcy move would sharply reduce Eastern's expenses, which had been running about $4 million a day during the strike.

LEAD: The sold-out ''Tribute to Red Rodney,'' part of the Highlights in Jazz series at Loeb Student Center of New York University, was a relaxed, low-key variety show on Thursday night that culminated in a round of reminiscences by the drummer Roy Haynes and the saxophonist Jimmy Heath and in a set by Mr.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Cloth diaper producers and vendors of biodegradable brands are seizing on growing environmental concerns to chip away at the disposables' market share.

LEAD: ALBERT EINSTEIN, the world's most famous scientist and perhaps the greatest mind of the 20th century, lived in Princeton longer than any other place. But Princetonians scarcely knew him. He made only one public appearance in the town he called home for 22 years.

LEAD: THERE is good reason for music lovers in the county to go out this week. Great music arrives in Mamaroneck on Tuesday, when the Emelin Theater's ''Opera on Film'' series presents Moussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' (with English titles) at 7:30 P.M. Alexander Pirogov is featured as the tormented Czar, in the lavish production of Moscow's Bolshoi

LEAD: Not all diaper service vendors think cloth is the only way to address disposal problems associated with throwaways. Anderson Diaper Service Inc., a full-service supplier of cloth and disposable diapers to Seattle customers, figures that recycling disposables is part of the solution.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Wood of Mayfield, East Sussex, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Elizabeth Wood to Lucien Snowden Yokana Guthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Davis Yokana of Princeton, N.J. A May 27 wedding is planned. Miss Wood graduated from Worcester College of Oxford University.

LEAD: THE ROAD FROM KAM-pala first leads east, toward Kenya, and then, just before the border, turns abruptly north, toward the Sudan. Today we are driving north, straight into the lion's den -into rebel-infested territory.

LEAD: THE rhetoric on housing in Washington this year centers on homelessness and what the Federal Government should do about it. But when it comes to solutions that involve spending Federal money, it will be no surprise if the emphasis in Congress is put on how to make existing rental housing more affordable to low-income people.

LEAD: Suppose a company has a letter to send to the Electronic Mail Association. It can address the envelope to 1919 Pennsylvania Avenue N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20006, and whether it turns to the United States Postal Service, a bicycle messenger, Federal Express or any other private carrier, its letter will eventually arrive.
LEAD: TO be inscribed in the Suburbanite's Handbook:

LEAD: No matter what she danced, Sally Hess would surely be compelling. Yet simply because she is such a charismatic performer, she deserves to dance only works that challenge as well as display her interpretative powers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Carol Vogel spotted the unusual in wedding gifts in her article ''The Gifted''; however, she did miss one. When my husband and I married last spring, merging two households, there were few traditional gifts that we needed. So when friends and family asked what we'd like, we included in our list three specific charities to which donations might be sent.

LEAD: After leading throngs of clapping supporters in a martial campaign song called ''Tremble, Tremble Communists,'' Roberto d'Aubuisson took a machete from an aide and sliced a watermelon in two. The fruit, he told the cheering campaign crowd, represented Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Christian Democrats, whose party color is green - green on the outside, he said, but red on the inside.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH developers say there is a great need for additional hotels in central Nassau, the Town of Hempstead has halted such building because there is not enough water to provide the large volume required by hotels.

LEAD: The whole is not as good as parts of ''The Sunday Promenade'' by Lars Forssell, but the good parts make this strange play at the New Theater of Brooklyn an amusing evening. Mr. Forssell's imagination is more poetic than dramatic; he can make you find connections among wildly conflicting ideas and his dialogue often reminds you of the snipped and elliptical lines of song lyrics.

LEAD: A fugitive wanted on 14 kidnapping charges in the February 1988 takeover of a North Carolina newspaper office was arrested by Federal agents Friday after failing to persuade officials at the Soviet consulate here to grant him political asylum.
LEAD: Christ Church Cathedral in New Orleans was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Crystal Louise Moffett to Richard Wayne Perry. The Very Rev. David Lowry performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: A chart accompanying an article in The Week in Review last week on poverty in New York omitted an item from the household budget of a woman working for the minimum wage. She pays $40 to Social Security, and has that much less for food and other expenses listed in the chart.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ardys Bayliss and Simon John Hambidge were married yesterday at the United Church of New Marlborough in Southfield, Mass. The Rev. John Robert Hambidge of the Church of England, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.
LEAD: LEO AFRICANUS By Amin Maalouf. Translated by Peter Sluglett. 360 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: ''A chief executive has got to lead,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said, speaking about himself and also, inevitably, about the man who beat him for the Presidency four months ago. ''You have to lay it out there, come in with a plan, take the hits.''

LEAD: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has started a new telephone service at 800-247-7433, with recordings and agents giving information on getting to or between the three area airports, including names and telephone numbers of companies providing transportation. Kennedy International Airport

LEAD: THE BOOK OF RUTH. By Jane Hamilton. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) On the surface, it's classic tabloid fodder. ''Family Erupts in Violence: One Dead, One Injured, as Tot Looks On,'' the headline might read. And inside the story, one might read: ''The killer only wanted to be 'a gentle person, a good boy.

LEAD: IF the Boston Pops Orchestra is coming to the County Center here, can the Boston Symphony be far behind? How about the Mormon Tabernacle Choir or Ella Fitzgerald? The county's Cultural Affairs office can afford to dream a little these days, thanks to the initial success of its Performing Arts Trust.
LEAD: A legal commission studying the feasibility of a bill of rights for South Africa has concluded that it would have to include the right to vote for the country's disenfranchised black majority.
LEAD: WAKING EARLY, MOORED NEAR A pine-dense island, you go up on deck.

LEAD: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION was neither the best of times nor the most frivolous, but there will be plenty of frivolity throughout Republican Paris this year. It seems every museum, every arrondissement's city hall, even every esoteric reading club, is vying to mark the events of 1789, although of course no one wants to re-create the parts that make everybody uneasy.

LEAD: In the first official look at who voted and who did not in the 1988 Presidential election, a Census Bureau study shows increasing disaffection among young people, minority people and the less educated.
LEAD: As the cameras rolled, Justice Frank Vaccaro stood solemnly in his long black robe and delivered a monologue about the responsibilities of jurors.

LEAD: WINTER pies, made with staples found in every larder and designed to fight the cold with calories, are particularly dear to the Quebecois. Old-fashioned favorites, which are now served in Quebec year round, include raisin pie, suet pie, and tarte a la ferlouche (molasses and raisin pie). But the most

LEAD: AT Dragon Garden, on the Boston Post Road in Norwalk, near Ski Market, the potential for competent Hunan- and Sichuan-style Chinese dining is apparent. The professionalism clearly exists, both in kitchen skills and in service. And the gray and-pink decor has a restful, serene quality that could hardly be improved on, with smoking and nonsmoking sections kept well apart on separate levels and with generous space between the well-napped tables.

LEAD: In 1882, Oscar Wilde effused: ''A glass of absinthe is as poetical as anything in the world. What difference is there between a glass of absinthe and a sunset?'' Verlaine, Rimbaud, Toulouse-Lautrec, van Gogh, Daumier, Baudelaire - all took ''inspiration'' from absinthe, the cloudy green aperitif made from wormwood, a strong-smelling perennial herb.

LEAD: Branchburg $209,000 428 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; screened porch, landscaped yard, greenhouse; taxes $1,800. Brick $137,000 520 New Jersey Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; patio, family room with skylights, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,912.

LEAD: AGAINST THE ENORMOUS BLUE BACKDROP of an Arizona morning, early arrivals quietly gather in the grandstand of HoHoKam Park, in Mesa, about 13 miles from Phoenix. Palm trees sway in the soft breeze beyond the billboard fences, and the only sound to be heard is the crack of a bat hitting a ball.

LEAD: A GRAVESTONE MADE OF WHEAT. By Will Weaver. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Will Weaver has followed his acclaimed first novel, ''Red Earth, White Earth,'' with a collection of 12 stories unified by a compelling sense of place. These stories rise, with an equal balance of pathos and humor, from the farmland of the American Middle West.

LEAD: Most designers create wedding gowns in lace or silk. Robert Comstock has designed one in leather. In his first collection for women, the 38-year-old men's wear designer has created a wedding suit of white deerskin. The jacket is embroidered with turquoise beads in an Indian motif and tops a skirt that has a sterling silver clasp at the waist.

LEAD: So Strawberry is a bit of a baby. Every fanatic fan is a bit of a baby (even I, a 64-year-old grandmother) - that is what makes us so crazy about baseball. No way should Strawberry be traded. Darryl generates excitement every time he comes to bat. He has the capacity to elicit our wildest fantasies, sometimes less than heroic, he identifies us with our failures.

LEAD: Jessica Harper, a movie and television actress, and Thomas Edgar Rothman, an executive vice president of production at Columbia Pictures in Los Angeles, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Mel Hawthorne, a Baptist minister and the chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the interdenominational ceremony at the Century Association in New
