(Feb. 19) confirms my most depressing fears about the Byzantine world of book publishing, and about any naive hopes I may have had of becoming a published author. Break-even points, bottom lines, last dollars, seven-figure sales - all of this sounds very much like the ''only big hits'' frenzy that has resulted in the demise of
LEAD: Washington is concerned that it may not recover Stinger missiles from Afghan rebels and that terrorists may get the weapons. Page 18.

LEAD: Nnenna Lynch of Hunter College High School and Brad Sumner of McQuade Jesuit in Rochester turned in stellar performances today at the New York State boys and girls indoor track and field championships at Cornell University.

LEAD: IT was in India, during a month of intense heat, that I hired four men to work for me as beasts of burden. I didn't hire them as porters to carry luggage or hiking gear. I hired them to carry me. I was not enthusiastic about it then and the event is not a pleasant memory now, but at the time it was the surest way to get where I wanted to go.

LEAD: Since its invention, photography has been associated with mirrors: it seems to reflect the world directly back at us. When we look at a print of turn-of-the-century Paris by Eugene Atget, we seldom ask if that's the way Paris really looked at the time. But camera vision is as much a product of human invention as language.

LEAD: A sentence in last Sunday's Bridge column about the Regional Swiss Team Championship had incomplete editing and the diagramed deal was incorrect. The sentence should have read: ''An example is the diagramed deal from the Regional Swiss Team Championship played Nov. 6 in Lancaster, Pa. North and South were Jerry Clerkin of North Vernon, Ind.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ginsberg of Roslyn, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Carla Ginsberg to Joseph Alan Feshbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Feshbach of Miami Beach. A July 8 wedding is planned.

LEAD: A SWEEPING change in the Federal Fair Housing Act, which becomes effective today, is emerging as the Government's most ambitious - and potentially most disruptive - civil rights initiative of the 1980's, according to civil libertarians, tenants rights experts and business people across the country.

LEAD: In a response to the crisis of Salmana Rushdie,28 distinguishedwriters born in 21 countries speak to him from their common land - the country of literature. For expressing their ideas publicly in the past many of these writers have suffered censorship, exile - forced or self-imposed - and imprisonment.

LEAD: Every so often a question arrives in the mailbox that does not ask for advice about what camera to buy, but addresses a problem plenty of us share. Here's one example, from L.G., a reader who lives in New York City:

LEAD: THE EXPERIMENTAL CHOREOGRAPHY of Trisha Brown tends to defy standard characterization, even by the choreographer herself. ''I struggle with it,'' she admits. ''It's important to try and demystify it, yet not take away the mystery. There's no narrative structure, but that's the excitement. It has impact and it has meaning, but it's not a story.
LEAD: Why did accountants throughout the nation fail to detect the shenanigans that triggered one of the biggest financial calamities this country has ever seen?

LEAD: SULLEN WEEDY LAKES By William Logan. 76 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $9.95. TOWN LIFE Poems. By Jay Parini. 79 pp. New York: An Owl Book/Henry Holt & Company. Paper, $10.95. BLOOD PRESSURE By Sandra M. Gilbert. 114 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company.

LEAD: Youth has its musical say at several concerts this week, starting this afternoon at 2:30 when Bushnell Hall's ''Winners Circle'' series presents Gary Schocker, a flutist who has already made his Philadelphia Orchestra debut.
LEAD: TWO of the candidates in this year's top elections in New Jersey carry an added burden as they seek voter support in the weeks ahead. They must live down their previous campaigns.
LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government announced Friday that it would pardon 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard by March 19.

LEAD: Perri Klass's article ''The Perfect Baby?'' (Body and Mind, Jan. 29) touched a very personal chord, for I, like Shakespeare's Richard III, was ''deformed, unfinished, sent before my time.'' I am now 18 years old, and studying at Yale University.

LEAD: Trade Strawberry as soon as possible. Ship him to the American League, the Rangers or Mariners. He also should fit in with the Yankees, the team I love to hate the most. Throw in HoJo and Dykstra, two expendables, and maybe a front-line groundskeeper, and you might be able to get Winfield. NAT BOYNTON Delmar, N.Y.

LEAD: Jerome Robbins started the dance without a scenario. ''I didn't know what I would do,'' he said, recalling his creation of the Bathing Beauty Ballet for ''High Button Shoes'' in 1947. ''But it began to roll, you know, and on it went'' - a Mack Sennett chase complete with eight bathing beauties, seven cops, three robbers, a set each of male and female twins, 14 singers, a lifeguard and a large gorilla racing on the boardwalk and through the slamming doors of seven bathhouses on the Atlantic City shore in 1913.

LEAD: THE rising waters are already lapping at the treetops and soon a new expanse of rain forest will completely disappear in Brazil's rush for energy. In a few months' time, Samuel, a new hydroelectric dam near this town in the Amazon Basin, will be ready to operate.

LEAD: The equation was simple and crushingly effective. Take superior size, experience, depth and ability. Add Dean Smith, North Carolina's 28-year head coach, facing a Maryland assistant who was directing his first major college game.

LEAD: A year after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled in the Baby M case that commercial surrogate motherhood contracts were illegal, a state panel drafting legislation on the subject has gone further still and come down strongly against even unpaid surrogate arrangements among friends, relatives or others.
LEAD: TWO years ago last summer, 64-year-old Jean Elbaum lapsed into a ''persistent vegetative state,'' a form of eyes-open permanent unconsciousness, following a stroke.

LEAD: An item in the Sports People column last Sunday incorrectly reported the number of players who have been members of the Parade Magazine high school all-America team for three seasons. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Patrick Ewing are the only ones to have made the first team three times. Six players - Abdul-Jabbar, Ewing, Kenny Anderson, Alonzo Mourning, Sean Kemp and Jerrod Mustaf - made the team as either a first- or second-team selection in three seasons.

LEAD: Just around daybreak Thursday March 2, at a gray and chilly hour when most of his Detroit Red Wings teammates were sandwiching some sleep between the rigors of Wednesday night's game and Thursday morning's practice, Bob Probert was arrested at the Canadian border after Federal customs officials conducted a strip search and said they discovered 14 grams of cocaine in his underwear.

LEAD: Here is a typical story from the pages of the improbable career of Oprah Winfrey: It's 1984, the 30-year-old host of a Chicago morning talk show is in North Carolina, on the set of Steven Spielberg's film ''The Color Purple.'' Though she has no previous acting experience, she has been cast in an important supporting role in a lavish production of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel.

LEAD: WHEN DUSTIN HOFFMAN was preparing for his role in the film ''Tootsie,'' he bewildered Utaemon VI, Living National Treasure and the Kabuki theater's most senior onnagata, or ''man-actress.'' ''What do you do to hide your

LEAD: Cats as Cats Can WHEN show dogs win enough points they become Champions. Show cats become Grand Champions. Everything is grander in the world of cats. Take cat show living quarters, for example. Rum Tum Tugger, a red tabby Persian, had not a care in the world as he lounged in his blue velour bed, which took up only a small portion of his lavishly carpeted and curtained cage with the litter box discreetly placed in the far corner.
LEAD: IN his determination to prove that Stamford is a theater town, Steve Karp is not playing it safe.

LEAD: The Knicks did their best shooting in the first and last quarters last night to defeat the Indiana Pacers, 114-95, and run their home-court winning streak to 25 games before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: A Greek Revival house containing sections that predate the Revolutionary War is being incorporated into a new housing development in the Village of Westport, Conn. Most of the five-bedroom structure dates to 1820, when it was rebuilt in the Greek Revival style by Talcott Wakeman, a prosperous onion farmer in the area along Sherwood Farms Lane two miles east of the center of

LEAD: To the Editor: Upon returning from a recent trip to Tokyo I was delighted to read Jared Lubarsky's ''Exploring the Heart of Old Tokyo'' (Travel, Oct. 23). Travelers should know that they can stay in the Asakusa View, a Western-style hotel in Asakusa adjoining the Asakusa Kannon Temple. The hotel has an attraction no other hotel in Tokyo offers: a huge wooden bath on the top of the building overlooking the Shitamachi section of the city.

LEAD: My knee-jerk reflex was to trade him. But then I witnessed his monstrous home run to the center-field wall in an exhibition game this weekend. The beauty of his outstretched arms and bat acting as one, making contact with the ball and launching a rocket, would be lost to me if he did it for any other team but the Mets.

LEAD: If you happened to be living in Berlin in the late 1920's or early 1930's and witnessed the episode in historical insanity that was the rise to power of Adoph Hitler, it is highly probable that the name Hanussen might ring a bell. Hanussen was the stage name of one Klaus Steinshneider, a nightclub and stage clairvoyant of considerable fame during those years, widely accused of fraud in the newspapers, but, nonetheless, it seems, a magician of rather chilling abilities.

LEAD: IN rejecting John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, a bitterly divided Senate seemed to be applying a new and ill-defined standard of personal and professional conduct. The next question is how extensively and uniformly the standard will be applied to other Cabinet nominees, to lower-ranking Administration officials and to lawmakers themselves.

LEAD: Douglas Dunn united the sacred and the secular in ''Sky Eye,'' the hourlong new work Douglas Dunn and Dancers presented last Sunday night at St. Mark's Church. Over the years, Mr. Dunn's unpredictable dances have ranged from the austere to the complex. ''Sky Eye'' was rich in both choreographic invention and thematic implication.

LEAD: Mount Kisco is going through an ambiguous period of development that is attracting new office buildings that many in the Westchester County community fear will change its character. An example is a developer who is anticipating a need for office space there by putting up a high-tech building, although the project has unsettled some residents.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Business Forum article on Feb. 26 misstated the positions taken by Venezuela and Mexico on United States oil imports. Both nations oppose an oil import fee as a vehicle for reducing United States oil imports.

LEAD: They laughed when Susan M. Wachter sat down at her computer keyboard two years ago and announced that she could predict the future of Manhattan cooperative apartment prices, an accomplishment that for years had defied the best efforts of real estate experts and economists. Yet her prediction turned out to be about as correct as a computer- assisted human's could be.

LEAD: Having survived a second consecutive winter of drought and strict water rationing followed by a cold snap that brought record low temperatures in February, San Franciscans are especially thankful to see spring busting out all over the city this year.

LEAD: ROB LAMOTHE does not consider himself to be a gambler, but this year he is taking a chance. At the same time that many of his fellow maple syrup producers are cutting back, Mr. Lamothe, who operates Lamothe's Sugarhouse in Burlington, is doubling the size of his operation.

LEAD: In the five weeks of the National Football League's new free-agency system, about 10 percent of the 619 eligible players have signed or agreed to contracts with new teams. The Jets have signed 3 players and lost 3 of their 27 free agents. The Giants have lost 2 of their 27 and have signed none.

LEAD: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits. To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave. I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment.

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry should be traded immediately. I'd like to see a trade for Kirby Puckett; if necessary, Dave Magadan or some other of the Mets' extraneous players could be thrown in. GEORGE J. FERRARESE New York
LEAD: When Ron Rothstein winces in anguish in downtown Miami, Roy Rubin feels the pain clear across a causeway in Miami Beach.
LEAD: On the wall above Michael Kuhnen's sofa is a blank space where a color portrait of Hitler and two red, white and black swastika banners recently hung.
LEAD: IN Connecticut, as elsewhere across the nation and in 16 foreign countries, the bereft are gathering to sew emblems of their loss.

LEAD: FOR a person traveling alone, among the sour notes embedded in the small type of any tour brochure is the phrase ''single supplement.'' The supplement is the extra charge that the tour operator imposes upon a person occupying a room alone on a tour where double occupancy - two in a room - is the standard.
LEAD: TALES OF FAMILY TIES ''Some Sweet Day'' by Nancy Fales Garrett, featured last year in the play-reading series at the Long Wharf, will open March 23 as the theater's 200th Main Stage production.

LEAD: A BRIGHT blue Escort slowed, then stopped in front of the realtor's For Sale sign. It stayed long enough for a closer look at the house, certainly long enough for jotting down the realtor's telephone number. I could not see how many people were in the car, but I began to imagine just what sort they were.

LEAD: To the Editor: The directory of barges and freighters (Travel, Feb. 12) was greatly appreciated. Many people just don't know much about that mode of travel. But there was one slight misstatement: that freighter passengers are not accepted over 75 years of age. Most lines are now up to a 79-year limit, and some are higher, such as CAST, which is 80, and Columbus Line, Chilean Line and Mineral Shipping, which accept passengers through 82.

LEAD: WHAT IS THIS THING? A ship, you say? Well, no. Not anymore. Once she was a ship, a few centuries ago. Now she looks like something that spent a hundred years in a food processor and another hundred in a trash compactor. She must have struck the reef over there and slid off into this sand hole and stuck, all of her, and wallowed and worked and rocked back and forth under the force of tide and current and countless storm seas, vanishing into the living coral and beneath the shifting sand until, back in 1983, a sharp-eyed Bermudian spotted an anomaly on the bottom and decided to investigate.

LEAD: A STORY IS TOLD ABOUT THE AESIR, THE gods of Asgard. It seems that they had to fashion a rope of tremendous strength, and they asked Odin the One-Eyed to obtain one for them. He went away for a while and returned with what appeared to be a slender silken cord. It didn't look very strong, but when the gods examined it they saw that it was woven from the roots of a mountain, the purring of a cat, the sinews of a bear, the breath of a fish, the beard of a woman, the spittle of a bird.

LEAD: Edward R. Murrow might have sniffed at anyone's taking, muchless giving, a course on his work and life. LEAD: THE road to Hana, a secluded town at the easternmost tip of Maui, second largest of the Hawaiian islands, is known as the Hana Highway, undoubtedly dubbed that by some waggish jofficial to encourage tourism. A highway it is not. It is rather a two-lane layering of macadam over a 54-mile course that takes more than two hours and 600 turns to maneuver, a pothole-pocked trail that tunels and twists along rain-eroded cliffs, between sea and rain forests, passing over 54 narroiw birdges.

LEAD: Denmark Question: During a stay in Copenhagen we would like to visit Legoland. How would we get there? Also, are there bed and breakfast places near Tivoli in the city, and are there discounts on local transportation? - H. K., Westport, Conn. Answer: Vacationers bound for Legoland, the amusement park in Billund, from Copenhagen may use rental car or fly, but taking the train is the least expensive route.

LEAD: Besides the Mets' pitching staff, Strawberry is the only outstanding player the team has. Sure Hernandez was, Jeffries could be, and McReynolds might be. But, none brings the magic to the plate like Strawberry. His ability to hit the long ball at a pitchers' park, his blazing speed, topped with his m.v.p.-like stats the last two years makes him the top everyday player in the National League, and maybe in the Major Leagues.
LEAD: The American Museum of Natural History is to present a free series of lectures and a performance in celebration of Women's History Month, March 14, 22 and 29 at 7 P.M. Information: 769-5315.

LEAD: To the Editor: I noted with interest the item concerning getting cash from automatic teller machines in England (Travel Advisory, Jan. 22).

LEAD: The Sunbelt Savings Association sits in a nondescript four-story office building overlooking an endless stream of cars that whiz by on the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway. Dark tinted windows give it a secretive quality and it is hard to distinguish this building from at least a dozen others clustered like so many covered wagons and encircled by concrete freeways.

LEAD: The Bush Administration plans to ask Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to take steps to ease tensions in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to lay the foundation for peace talks, a senior Administration official said.

LEAD: Chile's Communist Party, holding its first congress in 20 years, is engaged in a fierce internal debate over whether to continue to support the use of violence against the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

LEAD: LAST summer, when George Bush visited the New Jersey coastal resort of Belmar, he made a campaign pledge: No Federal licensing fees would be imposed on saltwater fishermen if he became President.

LEAD: CURING the common cold has always seemed an impossible dream, but at last scientists are beginning to see ways they might achieve it. Last week researchers reported experimental results that might eventually lead to a drug that would act as a decoy, diverting cold viruses from attacking human cells.

LEAD: East Hartford, Conn. $130,000 15 Matthew Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; landscaping, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,398. Sherman, Conn. $365,000 Orange Pepper Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; fireplace, pond, 3.3 acres; taxes $2,000.

LEAD: I fail to see how Salman Rushdie can say about Islamic culture, ''I know it well'' (''Salman Rushdie: Fiction's Embattled Infidel,'' Jan. 29). After all, from the age of 13, he worked to be accepted by a society that despises the culture from which he came. However, if it is true that he understands Islamic culture well, this is proof that his current book is a conscious defamation of Islam.

LEAD: Skiing Schneider Wins Again: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland became the first skier to post 14 World Cup victories in a season, breaking Ingemar Stenmark's 11-year-old record, by winning the slalom yesterday in Shiga Kogen, Japan. Schneider won the race, the season final, with a two-run clocking of 1 minute 25.67 seconds.

LEAD: Is there life after bankruptcy for Eastern Airlines? It's too early to tell. What's already clear, though, is that if Eastern dies, competition will be reduced and travelers will pay higher fares.

LEAD: ''Married . . . With Children'' is a tasteless show about a moronic family given to suggestive experiences and vulgar language. Even so, the half-hour sitcom, shown Sundays at 8:30 P.M., is Fox Broadcasting's top-rated series. What, considering the literary level of most television series, is wrong with that?

LEAD: When Jodie Chidester, an adviser to foreign students, looked out her office window in Ballou Hall on St. Valentine's Day, she was shocked to see the newest message on the cannon on Tufts University's main quad. ''Jodie,marry me.'' it said.

LEAD: THE South African Government set a precedent last week that could hasten the demise of its laws on strict residential segregation. In response to threats by a right-wing municipal council to cut off utilities used by ethnic Indians living in the officially white town of Boksburg, it asked provincial officials to give them temporary permits allowing them to stay.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Shafer of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Anne Shafer, to Bart Robert Shachnow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Shachnow of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: It seems the older you get, the more people want you to dig up the past,'' says Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as he hands a visitor a cup of English tea during an interview in his Park Avenue apartment. ''I'd much rather talk about the future or at least the present. But not at all. People insist on hearing about the good old days.
LEAD: It's still too early to tell whether the cheering ''New York Stories'' will be a box-office hit, but one can hope.

LEAD: IN Saturnia the smell of bad eggs wears off after two hours. Initially overpowering, the sulfurous smell rises with the steam from the hot waters that for millenniums have been gushing out of an extinct volcanic crater in this village, midway between Rome and Florence, in southern Tuscany. The waters of Saturnia have been considered a panacea for a number of ills for 3,000 years.

LEAD: As early as next year there may be a limit on the number of bluefish an Atlantic Coast angler will be allowed to catch and keep. The intent is to give some protection to a species that is vitally important to the recreational-fishing industry.

LEAD: In a test of the Sandinista Government's recent commitments to greater political pluralism, a former contra leader has requested permission to open a private television channel in time for this year's election campaign.

LEAD: They traded poodle skirts in the Fifties, miniskirts in the Sixties and bell-bottom pants in the Seventies. And although the look may have changed over the years, clothes swapping is still very much in style among women in their 20's.

LEAD: Echoes of the 1960's and the 1988 Presidential campaign reverberated through a prominent black university last week. Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, resigned as a trustee of Howard University in Washington after students staged a sit-in to protest his presence on the board.

LEAD: The criminal division of the Justice Department has asked Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate the hiring of a Congressman's son by Walter Fauntroy, the delegate for the District of Columbia in the House of Representatives.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last week in The Week in Review on airplane repairs misstated the number of accidents and deaths related to metal fatigue on United States commercial airliners in the last five years. According to the National Transportation Safety Board, there have been 16 accidents and one death.
LEAD: WAY OF DEATH Merchant Capitalism and the Angolan Slave Trade, 1730-1830. By Joseph C. Miller. Illustrated. 770 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $35.
LEAD: Finnish and Danish officers have arrived to make preparations for the arrival of other United Nations peacekeepers assigned to monitor Namibia's transition to independence.

LEAD: I RECENTLY DINED IN ONE OF THE PATRI-cian clubs scattered throughout New York -those limestone oases that transport you from the tumult of city life. In the library, attending maids passed prefatory drinks to our assembly, along with hot hors d'oeuvres: flaky spinach tarts; napoleons of Roquefort; smoked salmon on dark bread; shrimp with green mayonnaise.

LEAD: By their nature, the best relief pitchers respond to pressure. They also respond to pressure questions. And now, at his locker in the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse, Dennis Eckersley, who threw the pitch that Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers hit for the home run that turned last year's World Series, was asked what he had learned from the salt that still sears his wounds.

LEAD: RICO, is a statute run amok and no one is beyond its reach. Many times a day, unsuspecting citizens and businesses are shocked to find that they are targets of RICO suits. The law's broad civil suit provisions cast a net so wide that virtually any commercial dispute becomes a candidate for civil RICO jurisdiction.

LEAD: THE MEN FROM THE BOYS: Rites of Passage in Male America. By Ray Raphael. (University of Nebraska, $19.95.) How does a young boy attain manhood - or learn what it is all about - in a society where there are no formal rituals to facilitate his passage? Ray Raphael, the author of ''The Teacher's Voice,'' explores this question in ''The Men From the Boys: Rites of Passage in Male America.

LEAD: The engagement of Diana Frances Ford to Scott Ward Seaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Seaton of Pepper Pike, Ohio, has been announced by the father of the future bride, Sir John Ford of Guildford, Surrey, England, and Hutchinson Island, Fla. The wedding is planned for June 3 in Guildford.

LEAD: Sandra Charlotte Greenspan and Douglas James Lederman were married yesterday evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by Rabbi Arnold G. Fink. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Michael Greenspan of Harrison, N.Y. Her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Lederman of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

LEAD: MAKEBA: My Story, by Miriam Makeba with James Hall. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Born in South Africa, the black singer Miriam Makeba has drawn on her Swazi culture to endure a career in political exile. Her autobiography is the story of ''life lived as communal dialectic, a matter of African creative will set against bureaucratized repression,'' Robert Farris Thompson said here last year.
LEAD: Otis Thorpe scored 21 points and Akeem Olajuwon had 19 points and 11 rebounds tonight to lead the Houston Rockets over the Nets, 124-94.

LEAD: For equal, or nearly equal value, yes. Despite being a feared hitter, he does have significant failings. His defense is suspect, if not downright poor. He catches the ball off-balance and is then in a poor position to throw. His powerful arm is more than negated by the number of extra steps he takes to release the ball.

LEAD: The camel's-hair overcoat is as dependable in cold weather as the camel is when it's hot. Here is a cover-up that will go anywhere with practically anything, be it a pin-striped business suit or blue jeans and a turtleneck, silk scarf or wool choker. It's dressy enough when it needs to be, but there's always that nice dash of informality and practicality.

LEAD: Julia Ann Petitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phil Andru Petitt of Darien, Conn., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Lance Harvey Choos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Melvin Choos of Highland Park, Ill. Ann Mandel, the First Selectman of Darien, officiated.

LEAD: SINCE May 1985, when Francis C. Hall was named commander of the Police Department's 1,300-member narcotics division, drug arrests in New York City have risen steeply, to 3 of every 10 arrests, and the number of armed attacks on police officers has risen to unheard of levels.

LEAD: Forty or 50 years ago, an urban school was the centerpiece, the anchor, of its neighborhood, a building of both architectural grandeur and civic importance. ''DeWitt Clinton High School Clinton High School was the best building I ever walked into as a kid, except maybe church,'' Robert Esnard, the deputy mayor of New York City, said not long ago of his childhood neighborhood in the Bronx, and he had it exactly right.

LEAD: UNLIKE an industrial technology, an algorithm, the step-by-step recipe for carrying out a mathematical calculation, might seem more like something that is discovered than invented. But in the last few years, corporations have been patenting these abstract procedures, leading many mathematicians to complain that the free flow of ideas is in danger of being interrupted.

LEAD: Allium flowers come in a wonderful spectrum of colors: from bright yellow to warm red, from delicate blue to soft white and from gentle pink to rich purple. The forms also vary. In some cases, these flowers suggest a pompon, in others they spread out on thin branches and look like a starburst of fireworks.

LEAD: I RECENTLY read yet another article about trends. With the change of the seasons, people who claim to have their finger on the pulse of the future use a lot of fancy words to predict how certain groups of people will eat, dress and entertain themselves for the next several months.

LEAD: To the Editor: In reference to William L. LEAD: Does it subvert public education to show a daily video news program with commercials in high schools? Whittle Communications says no. The Tennessee-based company has launched a pilot project to give six high schools $50,000 worth of video equipment in exchange for showing ''Channel One,'' its 12-minute news program for teen-agers that includes two minutes of advertising.

LEAD: Weather vanes, which have been around since antiquity, are more popular than ever and increasingly less visible - at least on American rooftops. These days wind indicators are more often seen indoors - at museums, folk-art galleries, antiques shows and auctions. Major dealers who handle these artifacts say they stock mostly rarities and choose them carefully for their special shape, an enviable patina, or both.

LEAD: Your article on Kinder-Care reflects the popular but unwise trend to mix child day care with academic learning programs. A day-care program genuinely focused on the needs of children would direct its objectives to achieve a representation of basic family, home-style care. It would provide daytime surrogates who would offer the tots unconditional acceptance (love can't be bought), much consistency and sensory experiences to stimulate well-documented early learning needs.

LEAD: There is no more delicate responsibility for political leaders than nuclear weapons. But from the beginning, in 1945, leaders made decisions about the weapons on flawed premises and with inadequate understanding of possible consequences. We are lucky to have avoided the worst.

LEAD: To put it mildly, ours is not a golden age for Italian opera. Thus, as current recorded documentation reaches us, we should approach it with modest expectations. It is with this sobering view that we greet new recordings of Rossini's ''Cenerentola'' and the three components of Puccini's ''Il Trittico'': ''Gianni Schicchi,'' ''Suor Angelica'' and ''Il Tabarro.

LEAD: Richard Martin can't suppress a smile of triumph as he shows off his prize acquisition. Slick to the touch, and not much to look at, save to Martin's expert eye, it is, in pop parlance, a ''nerd shirt.''

LEAD: Two fast-moving subway riders brought two toddlers to safety Friday morning after a 2-year-old accidentally pushed his baby brother's stroller over a platform's edge and fell after him onto the IND tracks at a Harlem station.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''A Book Lover's Los Angeles'' (Travel, Jan. 8) may have misled readers as to the first edition of Beatrix Potter's ''Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' Unable to get a trade publisher to produce her little book, the author arranged for 250 copies to be privately printed in December 1901. Its unexpected reception led to a second edition printed (privately) in February 1902, with some slight changes in both the text and the binding.

LEAD: Tamar Lewin's very comprehensive article ''Small Tots, Big Biz'' (Jan. 29) points out the tremendous need for child care in this country. The most important ingredient in quality child care is the child's daily interaction with staff members. The staff must be properly trained, must enjoy and understand children and must be stable members of a team.

LEAD: Even without strikes and slowdowns, business travelers are an unhappy lot, or so the conventional wisdom goes. A television commercial for an automobile rental company, for example, depicts business travelers as prisoners, locked in leg irons, forced to subsist on slop. But if most people think life on the road is like life behind bars, there are many young professionals who are delighted to serve a sentence.

LEAD: When Barry Switzer, the beleaguered Oklahoma football coach, decided to take his daughter, Kathy Switzer, on a skiing trip to Colorado during spring break last week, some of his friends were skeptical. LEAD: It was 50 years ago this year that baseball's Iron Man, Lou Gehrig, took himself out of the Yankee lineup for the first time since 1925 and brought an end to his remarkable record of 2,130 consecutive games. The ailment that ended his career, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is still considered incurable.

LEAD: John J. McCloy, the lawyer and diplomat who was the United States High Commissioner in postwar Germany and an adviser to Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan, died yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: IN the fairest of all possible worlds, one would be all aglow over N. Richard Nash's newest play, the last of a trilogy that began with ''The Rainmaker.''

LEAD: As the official basketball supplier for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company makes a point of providing new balls for the various N.C.A.A. tourmanents.

LEAD: Ian A. Martin, chairman of Grand Metropolitan Inc., couldn't wait to get back to the United States last October. He was returning from Tokyo, after having sold the Inter-Continental Hotel chain to Japanese interests for a rich price. Now he would have the money to pursue the big American company he had his eye on.

LEAD: ELIZABETH ROCKWELL was scared to dance as a child. ''I never wanted anyone to watch me,'' Mrs. Rockwell explained with an easy laugh that made her sound impervious to nerves. ''I was extremely shy. The word that is usually used is 'painfully.' '' But her life has been filled with dance - as a young performer, later a teacher and now the founder and director of the Rondo Dance Theater of Bedford.

LEAD: An escalating series of sectarian killings in Northern Ireland continued Friday night, when a Catholic was shot dead by terrorists as he was leaving a bar in West Belfast. Three other people, two of them Catholics and one a Protestant, were wounded in two other shootings in Ulster on Friday.
LEAD: The city agency responsible for opening the doors of housing opportunity in New York is beginning to boast these days of its ability to seal them up, as well.
LEAD: IT was the faces that told the story.

Transplant to individual pots seedlings of impatiens, geraniums, perennials and other garden flowers started indoors last month.

LEAD: AT 5:30 in the morning, the Zeus Room of the Alexis Park Hotel in Nevada was packed with animated tourists. Even in the predawn hours, a substantial assembly in one of the public rooms of a Las Vegas hotel would not have been unusual. But in this case, not a single slot machine, roulette wheel or blackjack table was in sight; the Alexis Park is a nongambling hotel.

LEAD: Since he took the oath of office on Jan. 20, Vice President Dan Quayle has been campaigning hard, both here and on the road, for the things that eluded him in the 1988 Presidential campaign: respect, affection and a political base he can call his own.

LEAD: Bike riding is good preparation for telemark skiing because it strengthens the legs and knees, requires balance and contributes to aerobic fitness. It is important to be limber for telemarking, so regular stretching exercises are helpful. Watching the ''The Telemark Movie'' (available from the North American Telemark Organization for $34.95) is good preparation and review of the movements.

LEAD: It is the prospect of increasing business with China that brings more foreign companies here each year, and it is the threat of China's eventual dominance over business that drives away their potential employees.

LEAD: Many airline industry experts say that an important next step in Frank Lorenzo's strategy to build a new Eastern Airlines will be discount fares as low as $49 between New York and Florida in a dramatic gesture to attract passengers and thrust the ailing carrier back into the competitive fray.

LEAD: FIVE weeks ago, Tiffany Sessions, a 20-year-old student at the University of Florida, put on her workout clothes and a Walkman and went for a fitness walk. Sessions told her roommate she would return in an hour. It was growing dark when she left her off-campus apartment at 6 P.M., the usual time for her fitness outings.
LEAD: Inside the beige, prefabricated headquarters of the Immigration and Naturalization Service Processing Center here, Maria Inez Secan Hernandez Dezamorra sits and cries.

LEAD: Mounting pressures that threaten to undermine the economic program of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari are likely to make Mexico the test case for the new debt plan announced Friday by Washington's Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, Mexican and foreign officials and bankers here said over the weekend.

Uncertain that his longtime publisher would be enthusiastic, he considered turning to another publishing house for just that one book. But when Mr.

LEAD: Israeli troops killed two members of a Palestinian guerrilla group Saturday night as they were trying to infiltrate into Israel from Lebanon. A radical group backed by Syria said today that the infiltrators were its guerrillas.

LEAD: Lyle McDowell Allen Jr., a former head of the legal division and assistant secretary of the American Home Products Corporation, died of lung cancer Thursday at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 66 years old and lived in Chapel Hill, N.C.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation has entered into a $2 billion joint venture to push its way into the European appliance market. The International Paper Company has made a $350 million bid for a French paper maker. And Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has recently expanded its investment banking offices in Milan, Italy, and in Madrid.

LEAD: Tony Granato hesitated, and an instant later both Dale Hunter and the game were lost. Hunter beat Granato to the puck and then beat John Vanbiesbrouck with it for the decisive goal in the 4-2 victory the Washington Capitals gained over the Rangers here Saturday night.
LEAD: President P. W. Botha, South Africa's ailing leader, indicated today that he has no intention of heeding mounting pressure in the ruling National Party for him to resign as President.
LEAD: Danny Cox, a St. Louis Cardinal right-hander, will undergo elbow surgery later this month and will miss the entire season, the club annouced today.

LEAD: After eight years of partisan stalemate over raising the minimum wage, Democrats and organized labor appear to be moving toward accepting some kind of two-tier system that Republicans have made a condition for any increase.

LEAD: Massacre in El Salvador The Salvadoran military has acknowledged that soldiers massacred 10 civilians last year, and it cleared the way for prosecution. Page A8. Breakthrough on Wage Law Congress is moving toward an agreement that would raise the minimum wage for some workers. Page A12.
LEAD: The trial of Oliver L. North enters its fourth week of testimony on Monday in a legal melodrama that has provided intense moments along with fresh insights into the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: The colossal American Thread Company complex, which rises from a winding river valley here in the Willimantic section of town, looks more like a mausoleum than a mill these days.

Catto Jr., who has been nominated as Ambassador to Britain after holding previous dipomatic posts. While Mr. Catto is a longtime Republican contributor, he was not among $100,000 contributors to the Republican party last year.
LEAD: The snow that comes to Kabul in winter turned into a chill drizzle today, adding an extra touch of mournfulness to the cemetery on Martyrs' Hill.

LEAD: From Radio Afghanistan to the Voice of Zaire, more official government radio stations than ever before are broadcasting abroad on shortwave, and many have started downplaying strident propaganda and overt ideology in favor of more candor in their official newscasts.

LEAD: * Mother Jones magazine, to Buckley/DeCerchio, New York, for its trade and consumer advertising.

LEAD: Nearly 18 years after Amtrak was created to rescue the nation's sinking passenger rail system, its trains are carrying record numbers of passengers, wooing them from the airlines with skiing packages, movies and phones on some trains and even an experimental return of linen and china to dining cars.
LEAD: One major championship was decided here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, but another remained in doubt until 12 hours after play ended.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CHARLES SMITH looks badly fed. When players on the Georgetown basketball team go back to the bench during the game for a cup of water, it seems Charles Smith should maybe get a peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwich, too.

LEAD: President Bush has announced that he will propose legislation to halt exports of hazardous waste unless there is an agreement that the receiving country will handle the material in an approved, safe manner.

LEAD: Women have always worked outside the home: harvesting fruit, digging ditches, making airplane parts, cleaning houses, selling clothes, teaching children, emptying bedpans, taking down somebody else's letters. Labor for pay, then, is nothing new to them; but good pay is, and so, finally, is a sense of entitlement.
LEAD: There were times during his slam-bang victory Saturday night over Michael Dokes that Evander Holyfield appeared to be in a spot of trouble.

LEAD: Centaur Partners said today that it would appeal a judge's order blocking a special meeting of the Pennwalt Corporation's shareholders and said it was ''unwavering'' in its resolve to take over the chemical company.
LEAD: Having fended off regulation in the past, Chicago's commodity futures exchanges are staging a desperate attempt to retain their autonomy.

LEAD: After a weeklong delay, the Sudanese Prime Minister today offered the resignations of his Cabinet to the Council of State and said he would form a new government.

LEAD: A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization yesterday dismissed suggestions from the Bush Administration for reducing tensions in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as unbalanced and outdated.

LEAD: Victoria Griswold's Saturday afternoon program at Weill Recital Hall offered a stimulating look at the American piano literature that arose during the early years of this century. The six composers whose music she played were born in the second half of the 19th century and worked hard to establish an American idiom.

LEAD: A coalition of groups concerned with publishing and entertainment is planning to file a lawsuit in Washington this week challenging the constitutionality of a recent Federal law against child pornography.
LEAD: Legislators in Albany are moving toward a significant expansion of a New York State law that allows news organizations to withhold from courts information obtained by reporters.
LEAD: The furor over ''The Satanic Verses'' has recently overshadowed the spirited debate in the British book industry on an issue with probably more lasting impact.

LEAD: Barry Levinson won the 1988 Directors Guild of America award Saturday night for ''Rain Man,'' a drama about a manipulative car salesman who tries to trick his autistic savant brother out of his inheritance.

LEAD: Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., Oliver L. North's chief lawyer at the Federal trial involving the Iran-contra affair, has made no secret of his Irish heritage. Last week Mr. Sullivan asked Judge Gerhard A. Gesell if he would consider suspending the proceedings on St. Patrick's Day. And last week the judge announced that on March 17, ''We're going to not hold court.
LEAD: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills.
LEAD: * All Nippon Airways Co. Ltd., Tokyo, and Toda Construction Co. Ltd. are considering setting up a joint company to build a $200 million hotel in Los Angeles, according to Toda.

LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated Dow Jones & Company's relationship to Texas Monthly magazine. It holds a minority interest in the magazine; the main owner is Mediatex Communications.

LEAD: As the end of the first quarter nears, credit market economists remain divided over how much higher interest rates will have to move to pare back economic growth and inflation to the levels wanted by the Federal Reserve Board.
LEAD: A muscular Democratic Senate majority, having diminished the power of George Bush's Presidency, now demands that bygones be bygones.

LEAD: The designation Prelude meant different things to the two subjects of Jean-Yves Thibaudet's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening. If the term implies anticipation, an announcement of things still to be said, than it best fit the 24 Chopin pieces that made up the second half of this evening.

LEAD: The nation's orange harvest for the 1988-89 crop season is estimated at 210.9 million boxes, down 2 percent from last month's forecast but 5 percent more than actual production last season, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

LEAD: The composer Leon Kirchner, who is celebrating his 70th birthday this year, was the subject of a Continuum retrospective program at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening. Continuum's connections with Mr. Kirchner are stronger than with some of the other composers whose music it has examined over the last 23 years.

LEAD: A Federal official said today that investigators had compiled a description of a man of Middle Eastern appearance who had been seen in the past several months walking in the San Diego neighborhood of Capt. Will C. Rogers 3d, the captain of the Navy missile cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet last July.

LEAD: The Bush Administration will seek aid to keep the Nicaraguan guerrillas in Honduras at least through February 1990, in spite of a regional peace agreement that calls for disbanding the rebels, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Speed Skating Two Victories for Jansen: Dan Jansen of the United States beat the world sprint champion, Igor Zhelezovsky of the Soviet Union, twice at a World Cup meet in Inzell, West Germany, that ended yesterday. Jansen won the 500-and 1,000-meter races yesterday, both times edging Zhelezovsky.

LEAD: The military acknowledged today that its forces killed 10 unarmed civilians in a small village last September, and it cleared the way for the prosecution of two officers and seven soldiers implicated in the massacre.
LEAD: The theme for North Carolina was, finally, redemption.
LEAD: Joseph Ferriola, the reputed boss of organized crime in Chicago, died Saturday after his second heart transplant in recent weeks. He was 61 years old and lived in Oak Brook, Ill.

LEAD: Ellen Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Frank of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Bayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Bayer of Jamesburg, N.J. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.
LEAD: The City Council's Environmental Protection Committee is to vote today on legislation that would establish a program of trash recycling. It's a crucial step for the city's future welfare.

LEAD: What Joe Szurley remembers best about the first match of what has become an annual collegiate hockey classic is not his team's 15-2 victory in the 1987 debut game, or even his own four goals. It is the opponents' pep band.
LEAD: New York's Liberal Party, with fewer than 1 percent of the city's registered voters, is poised for the first time in years to wield its grossly disproportionate influence in a mayoral campaign.
LEAD: Gilbert W. Harrison, a well-known retailing merger specialist, has resigned as a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to re-establish his former company, Financo Inc.

LEAD: Voters in Frankfurt and in municipalities across Hesse State followed the lead of West Berlin today, abandoning the Christian Democratic party of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and showing strong new support for the anti-foreigner stance of the extreme right.

LEAD: This nation is still technically at war with its northern half - but even more at odds with itself.

LEAD: Ronald H. Brown, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has started but not finished his housecleaning.

LEAD: The Treasury's plan announced Friday to reduce the debt burden of developing countries is similar to existing programs that have operated on too small a scale to satisfy the largest debtor countries, bankers said over the weekend.

LEAD: Jung Ja Kim, a pianist on the faculty of the Boston Conservatory of Music, came to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night with a program of Ravel, Schubert, Chopin and Isang Yun. LEAD: Mile after mile of colorful plastic-covered structures give this section of south Spain the appearance of a motionless glittering sea.
LEAD: Space agency officials said today that the shuttle Discovery is ready to blast off on its five-day mission at 8:07 Monday morning.

LEAD: Thomas Hine staked his claim here for God and king 350 years ago, scratching out a farm on an isolated hilltop in the middle of a wilderness. Twelve generations later, Mr. Hine's descendants once again find themselves in isolation.

LEAD: The child of a divorced couple, Dave Lebo vowed long ago to be a special kind of parent. ''Myself growing up and not having a father,'' he said, ''I felt I wanted to give my son something I didn't have myself: time and attention.''

LEAD: The systemic crisis of the Soviet world is the new and centrally important reality confronting Western policy in East-West relations. Responding to that crisis will require a comprehensive and long-term Western strategy. Such a strategy currently does not exist.

LEAD: At one time or another almost everyone in state politics here has done battle with Assemblyman Alan J. Karcher, a man known to many as New Jersey's most brilliant, charming and acerbic contrariant.

LEAD: Sixty-four teams now know where they will travel and who they will battle in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball tournament, which will begin Thursday. LEAD: President Bush and Jack Kemp want them, 36 states have them and five versions of them await Congressional attention. Enterprise zones - the answer to urban decay that even a conservative can love - are inscribed on the Bush agenda. But do they work? No one really knows.

LEAD: A new report by the National Research Council ratifies the conventional wisdom that cutting back on salt, fat and cholesterol can have tangible health benefits. It adds weight to the case for new Federal labeling rules that would help consumers know more precisely what they are eating.

LEAD: At 9:30 this morning, Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer for the United States Government, is to rise in an 11th-floor courtroom at the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan to begin what may be the decisive battle in a decades-long war between the Government and the largest labor union in the world.

LEAD: Within two days of each other last November, Zubin Mehta announced his resignation as music director of the New York Philharmonic as of May 1991 and Bruce Crawford said he would step down as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera around April 1.
LEAD: Once-beaten Auburn was seeded No. 1 in the Mideast Region as the 48-team field was announced today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

LEAD: BACK in the 1860's, a Norwegian skier named Sondre Nordheim systematized a technique for turning and stopping on skis so he could repeat the maneuvers at will. Other skiers in his home province of Telemark copied his technique and it became known as telemarking.
LEAD: A report released today by Congressional researchers said the Pentagon's implementation of financial management changes required by law has been inadequate.
LEAD: QUESTION: In the 10 years that the Big East Conference has been in business, how have its basketball teams done in games against the Big Ten Conference?

LEAD: A year-round drug testing program was approved unanimously today by the board of directors of The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field.

LEAD: More than a decade after a Federal study found serious overuse and misuse of powerful drugs in nursing homes, many patients are still being drugged into a stupor just to make them easier to care for.

LEAD: This morning James S. Brady, Ronald Reagan's press secretary, is to hold his first news conference in nearly eight years. Now he is being called a miracle worker.

LEAD: The Bush Administration today appeared to be stepping up its efforts to refine the reversal in its developing-country debt policy and to answer critics who contend the plan lacks substance.
LEAD: The Afghan Government stepped up assertions today that the guerrilla attack on the border city of Jalalabad had been directed by American and Pakistani military advisers.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought another 515,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Monday.

LEAD: Pleas and shouts and swoops, tapping feet and spangles and tuxedos inaugurated Ruth Brown's Rhythm-and-Blues Revue, a Monday-night series that continues through April 10 at the Lone Star Roadhouse, 240 West 52d Street. Ms. Brown is becoming a one-woman rhythm-and-blues revival through her syndicated public-radio show (''Harlem Hit Parade''), roles in musical theater (she is in the Broadway show ''Black and Blue'') and her down-home, regal performances as a club headliner.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher yesterday on evidence suggesting that consumers may be feeling the pinch of higher interest rates.

LEAD: Only a few weeks ago, politicians discounted the rising calls for controls on military-style assault rifles - the so-called Rambo guns. The gun lobby seemed just too powerful. But now, suddenly, moves against the guns in California and Washington D.C. add up to a reassuring victory for reason.

LEAD: The White House has brought its speech-writing corps up to strength in Marks. Only one Mark, Mark Klugman, was left after Mark McIntyre recently joined the Washington consulting firm of Cassidy & Associates.

LEAD: Back for a new season on CBS tonight at 9, ''Jake and the Fat Man'' has moved to Hawaii. Why? Because with the demise of ''Magnum, P.I.'' the network found itself with a lot of idle Honolulu production equipment on its books. Weekly television's artistic decisions are deeply rooted in practical considerations.

LEAD: When the Starship, the Beech Aircraft Corporation's new business airplane, begins flying commercially next summer, the event will represent something of a milestone in materials technology. The Starship is the first passenger plane to eliminate the metal frame and skin in favor of materials in which plastic has been combined with other substances to form composites.

LEAD: PIERRE FRANEY'S column last week about making risotto with converted rice brought to mind a recent conversation I had with Marion Cunningham, the author of the 1979 version of the ''Fannie Farmer Cookbook.''
LEAD: Declaring that Wisconsin has become ''a welfare magnet,'' Gov. Tommy Thompson has proposed a two-tiered public aid system that would reduce benefits for newcomers by 25 percent.

LEAD: Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, an osteopath whose patients included Richard M. Nixon and Nelson A. Rockefeller, died of complications from lymphoma Monday at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Space agency officials said today that a problem with the space shuttle Discovery's electrical system might force the winged spaceship to land a day early, on Friday.

LEAD: A front-page caption in Science Times yesterday about X-ray crystallography, used for growing protein crystals in space, referred incorrectly to the diffraction patterns measured by the technique. It measures the scattering of X-rays, not light.
LEAD: ''When you're turned on by something, you feel it inside!'' exuded the diamond-bedecked lady to the right. ''Like a love affair!''
LEAD: The European Community today moved closer to a common policy on television broadcasting as it agreed to limit programs from the United States and to restrict commercials.

LEAD: Corey Millen, a member of the 1988 United States Olympic team, will not play for the Rangers this season even if an agreement is reached to buy out the final year of his contract with Ambri of the Swiss League, according to an organization official.

LEAD: Thousands of Russians and other non-Estonians marched in Tallinn today, threatening a general strike if the Communist Party does not stem Estonian nationalism and ''creeping counterrevolution,'' journalists there said.

LEAD: President Bush will preside over a National Security Council meeting on Wednesday to arbitrate conflicts between the Defense and Commerce Departments over helping Japan to build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Realizing that young scientists do not just grow in a vacuum, many state governments have moved energetically to set up selective high schools specializing in science and mathematics.

LEAD: FOR years people have been told to eat a variety of foods - something from each of the four food groups every day - in order to have a well-balanced diet. Now there is more urgency to the suggestion. To spread around the hazards in our food supply, hazards most people have become aware of only recently, it is best not to eat large quantities of any single food and to be more selective in what you eat.

LEAD: In a case involving Federal racketeering charges against sports agents, a jury heard testimony today from a man who described himself as a member of the Colombo crime family and said he was a silent partner in the sports-agency business of Norby Walters.

LEAD: A picture caption in some editions yesterday, about a conference in New York on peace in the Middle East, mentioned one moderator erroneously. The moderator, Nubar Hovsepian, had been on the scene but was not visible in the picture.

LEAD: ANGER is still coursing through the commercial production industry, a month after a leading advertising agency executive contended that independent production companies were behind the rise in the cost of making television ads.

LEAD: President P. W. Botha returned to his office here today, preparing to confront a united opposition of National Party legislators who want him to yield his post to the new party leader, F. W. de Klerk.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is reconsidering the Reagan Administration's decision to tear down the new American Embassy chancery in Moscow, State Department officials said today. The chancery has been found to be riddled with sophisticated eavesdropping systems and has never been used.

LEAD: The Illinois Sports Facility Authority is offering $150 million of sport facility bonds with a maximum yield of about 7 7/8 percent for an issue due in 2010 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearnsi & Company.

LEAD: Randy Gordon, former editor of Ring magazine, was confirmed yesterday as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. LEAD: Edward Abbey, a naturalist, novelist and one-time forest ranger, died of a circulatory disorder yesterday at his home in Oracle, Ariz. He was 62 years old.

He would carry his message, if not directly to the 1.1 million poor people his agency serves, then at least to those who work in the welfare centers and homeless shelters and child protection offices.

LEAD: This is not a column I wanted to write. Rather, it is a column I would have wanted to write had things turned out differently. For the past year and a half, as I confided in a recent column, I had been going regularly, month after dutiful month, to one of California's leading-edge fertility clinics to try to become pregnant.

LEAD: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage, said it had reached a definitive agreement on it previously announced plan to acquire Rose and Company Investment Brokers Inc. from the Chase Manhattan Corporation for $36.7 million. Completion of the acquisition is expected before April 30.

LEAD: Tony Mandarich, Michigan State's 320-pound tackle, is fed up. Just 17 credits short of a bachelor's degree, Mandarich, a two-time all-American, plans to move to Los Angeles to escape allegations that he has used steroids.
LEAD: Zita, the last Empress of Austria-Hungary, died yesterday at her longtime residence, a Roman Catholic home for the elderly in Zizers, a village in eastern Switzerland. She was 96 years old.

LEAD: The criminal trial of an assistant trader of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. opened yesterday with a central Government witness testifying that a former Drexel trader and several executives from a New Jersey investment partnership had engaged in a scheme to violate securities laws.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: J. H. Tyler McConnell, a retired Delaware banker and lawyer who was a member of the board of governors of the United States Postal Service, died of a stroke Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

LEAD: Mike Norris pitched 15 minutes of batting practice today, but he did not face Reggie Jackson and Bert Campaneris, both former teammates, or Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire, who play for the Oakland Athletics today.
LEAD: Hartford's John Anderson scored twice in the opening five minutes and Paul MacDermid and Sylvain Turgeon added two goals apiece as the Whalers defeated the Islanders by 8-2 tonight.
LEAD: Bonnie Raitt, Frankly

LEAD: Domestic automobile sales declined 14.8 percent in the first 10 days of March, despite higher buyer incentives. Analysts predicted that the decline would lead to further discounting and perhaps a cut in production to clear excess inventories.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempts to rescue the failing Soviet farm system, already facing resistance in the countryside, are now encountering opposition in the Kremlin as well.
LEAD: The Players Championship will start Thursday on one of golf's most controversial courses: the Tournament Players Club adjacent to the PGA Tour's national headquarters.

LEAD: Ron Guidry's attempt to play another year with the Yankees has suffered a setback. The 38-year-old left-hander did not work out today because of a swollen elbow, and it is not known when he will be able to throw again.

LEAD: PEOPLE who move frequently often wax nostalgic over memories of their mother's kitchen. The steamy warmth of a simple boiled potato can have the transporting power of Proust's sophisticated madeleines.

LEAD: A first vice president and stockbroker with Gruntal & Company was convicted yesterday on charges of insider trading and perjury stemming from the takeover in 1986 of Waldbaum Inc. by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Eating Well column last Wednesday misidentified the author of ''Cooking From Quilt Country: Hearty Recipes From Amish and Mennonite Kitchens.'' She is Marcia Adams. The column also misidentified the chef at the Duke University Diet and Fitness Center. He is Michael Eddins.
LEAD: In some of the most widespread combat in years, 35 people were reported killed and more than 140 wounded today as Christians and Muslims fought artillery battles in Beirut and outlying areas.

LEAD: LONG known for its hoagie sandwiches and cheese steaks, Philadelphia is now staking its claim as a center for more exalted cuisine. Beginning tomorrow, the city will sponsor a culinary festival to prove its point.

LEAD: In a corporate realignment more common in the world of popular recordings than on the less volatile classical side, the Bertelsmann Music Group, which owns RCA Red Seal and other labels, has announced that it will replace Michael Emmerson, president of BMG Classics division since 1986, with Gunther Hensler, effective
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday priced six bond issues totaling $6.94 billion at par. They are being offered through various securities dealers.

LEAD: Setting the stage for a confrontation between the securities and futures industries, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved three financial products that will allow several exchanges to engage in so-called basket trading.

LEAD: The pilots' union at Eastern Airlines asked a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday to appoint a trustee to run the crippled airline, a request that opens a second front in the struggle between the airline and its striking unions.
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to show strong gains for the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: Three teams of researchers have detected strains of the AIDS virus that have become resistant to AZT, the only drug licensed by the Government to treat the disease, researchers said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: At a time of rare political stability but also of economic austerity, Bolivians are preparing to elect a successor to the 81-year-old President, Victor Paz Estenssoro.

LEAD: Moving to fill senior positions in a department that will be critical to his pledge to be the education President, President Bush has nominated John Theodore Sanders to be Under Secretary of Education. Mr. Sanders is to replace Linus D. Wright, who has accepted a position with a personnel recruitment company in
LEAD: Barbara Bush has said that, unlike some previous First Ladies, she is not interested in redecorating. But there is always a bit of rearranging here and there in the White House.
LEAD: A state administrative judge will hear a case in which two New York National Guardsmen assert they were discriminated against because they tested positive for AIDS antibodies.

LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had lowered his stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 10.5 percent from 14.98 percent. Mr. Jacobs sold 584,400 Shaklee shares on the open market on Monday for an average price of $47.17.
LEAD: IS there more symbol than substance to the continuing controversy over the minimum wage?

LEAD: FIGURE SKATING Soviet Skaters Take Early Lead: Soviet skaters took early leads in the men's and pairs events yesterday at the world championships in Paris. Aleksandr Fadeyev led an East European sweep of the first three placings in the men's compulsories ahead of a countryman, Viktor Petrenko, and Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland.

LEAD: After more than 10 months of internal debate, the State Department has quietly dropped a proposal to screen certain Foreign Service officers for psychological problems, State Department officials said yesterday.
LEAD: * Emily Cohen has been named senior vice president of DDB Needham, New York.
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: From their homes of mud and thatch nestled along country roads lined with tamarind trees, landless rural laborers have been coming out by the thousands to block roads, stop trains and join in other acts of mass disobedience. They are demanding that affirmative-action laws deliver on promises to improve the lot of one of Hinduism's poorest rural castes.

LEAD: It was 6:40 A.M. in the silent White House press office. Alixe Glen, a White House press officer, was sitting in her office writing a summary of the morning papers for a staff briefing when she heard a noise behind her. Ms. Glen did a double take. There stood President Bush, with the family dog, Millie.

LEAD: The Oklahoma State forward Richard Dumas, the Cowboys' leading scorer going into Friday night's National Invitation Tournament game against Boise State, was suspended from the team today and said he was entering a substance- abuse program. ''I feel I have let my mother, coaches, teammates and fans down because of a substance-abuse problem,'' Dumas said in a statement in which he apologized.

LEAD: The regular customers stood in the normal afternoon lines at Ro & Sons Produce in Philadelphia, carrying red shopping baskets that overflowed with fresh produce. But where there might have been grapes and peaches and raspberries the day before, there were now oranges and apples and strawberries. The day before, the customers made their usual requests for the ripest samples, but yesterday the question was, ''Are you sure this is safe?
LEAD: Jakob Gimpel, a concert pianist known for his interpretations of Chopin, died at his home in Los Angeles on Sunday. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: THE three best-known red wine regions of France are Bordeaux, Burgundy and the Rhone Valley. The best red wines of California have been fashioned after the wines of Bordeaux and to a lesser extent Burgundy.

LEAD: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has asked Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to determine what interest there may be among other airlines and investors in buying Eastern Airlines, industry executives said yesterday.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, an article about the fur industry appeared in some editions yesterday with an unrelated subheading duplicated from another article. The subheading should have read, ''Once a high-ticket item, furs are now seen as more affordable.''

LEAD: A New York City plan to begin charging a $250 annual licensing fee on out-of-town limousines has touched off an uproar among limousine owners, who plan a court fight against the fee and related regulations.

LEAD: Erwin Ephron thinks many media planners are missing the forest for the trees in today's increasingly fragmented media market. So earlier this month, Mr. Ephron, the former president of Ephron, McCabe & Tsao Advertising, opened a consulting firm to help advertisers with their media buying.
LEAD: SportsChannel America announced yesterday that it had agreed to a five-year contract to televise a weekly national package of high school sporting events starting in September.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: The Justice Department today accused the Singer Company of overcharging the Pentagon by $77 million from 1980 to 1988 by falsifying cost estimates on contracts for flight simulators.

LEAD: A 16th-century Florentine portrait of Cosimo de'Medici, described by scholars as the finest Italian Renaissance painting to be offered at auction in more than a decade, was removed from the Frick Collection 10 days ago to be sold at Christie's on May 31.

LEAD: Five weeks after receiving a huge order for its wide-bodied MD-11 commercial aircraft, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay the General Dynamics Corporation about $2 billion over the next six years to produce fuselage sections for the new plane.

LEAD: Two weeks before Health Secretary Dr. Louis W. Sullivan endorsed local programs that let drug addicts trade their dirty needles for clean ones, a memorandum by a subordinate warned Federal grant recipients that they could lose the aid if they ran such efforts.
LEAD: The Giants lost three more players yesterday to the National Football League's new system of free agency.

LEAD: A senior Soviet defense analyst, Andrei A. Kokoshin, testified before the House Armed Services Committee in Washington last week, itself a sign of how fast the manners if not yet the hard facts of Soviet-American relations are changing.

LEAD: An injury-depleted Devils team had little chance tonight against the efficient Calgary Flames at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, The Devils were beaten, 5-1, and lostmore ground in their fading playoff bid.

LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation said it would hold a special stockholders meeting on April 14 to vote on the merger agreement made last year by its board with Conagra Inc. Conagra's offer to acquire the company in a stock swap worth more than $1 billion is subject to the approval of two-thirds of the companies' common stockholders.
LEAD: A man charged with the beating death of his former wife while he was on a furlough from prison intends to plead not guilty because of insanity, his lawyer told a judge today.

LEAD: It must be hard to be a Met fan or a Yankee fan this spring with both teams operating under trade rumors that loom ominously like Herblock's famous cartoon of a swarthy hydrogen bomb endangering the human race.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The central bank today lowered Belgium's primary lending rate, the interest rate on three-month treasury bills, to 8.4 percent from 8.3 percent. The rate on one- and two-month bills was cut by five-hundredths of a point each, to 8 and 8.2 percent, respectively.
LEAD: Like many older suburban areas around New York City, Bergen County is rapidly running out of open land and faces a future that looks increasingly urban.

LEAD: J. William Moffett was pleased. He sponsors the annual convention of vintners and vineyard managers east of the Rocky Mountains - ''a pulse-taking of the regional wine industry,'' he calls it. A near-record 600 people from 139 wineries in 31 states attended the 13th such gathering here last month, an indication, he says, of a healthy future for the industry.

LEAD: The Big Sky Transportation Company, a regional airline that feeds Northwest Airlines Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today, citing unspecified contract problems and a large bank debt. Jase O. Norsworthy, its chairman, said the airline had $2 million in secured debt. Its assets, including 11 aircraft, total about $2 million, he said.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission requested additional comment today on whether a New York Stock Exchange rule proposal that would allow companies listed on the Big Board to break their stock into securities known as ''unbundled stock units'' unfairly disenfranchises shareholders.

LEAD: When Coach Gene Keady walked into a meeting yesterday with George King, Purdue's athletic director, he was unsure whether he would accept a reported offer of $300,000 a year to become the basketball coach at Arizona State. Then he looked out a window, scanned the campus and made up his mind to stay put.
