LEAD: Citizens A Chronicle of the French Revolution By Simon Schama Illustrated. 948 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95

LEAD: In September the University of Illinois football team is scheduled to play a televised game against the University of Southern California at Dynamo Stadium in Moscow. It is being billed, naturally, as the ''Glasnost Bowl'' and seems born of diplomatic genius.
LEAD: * Aldus Corp., a desktop publishing software designer, to Dahlin Smith White Inc., Salt Lake City, with a budget of $2.2 million.

LEAD: Two reigning world champions captured the Open Pair title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Monday night. Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., and Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., whose many successes include a victory in the 1986 world team championships, won here by the slender margin of three match points.
LEAD: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey announced today that he would introduce legislation to require colleges and universities to disclose the graduation rates of student athletes.

LEAD: The deficit in the broadest measure of the nation's trade declined 2.1 percent in the October-to-December quarter, to $31.9 billion, compared with a revised $32.6 billion deficit in the previous quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Federated Investors Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Aetna Life and Casualty, will be sold to a new company to be operated and primarily owned by Federated's management. Under the agreement, which will also include related investment management operations, Aetna will receive about $320 million in cash and $25 million in Aetna common stock held by

LEAD: Two pleasures greeted the hundreds of people running around the Central Park reservoir in Manhattan yesterday morning. One was remarkable: Gliding alone across the still, black waters was a brilliantly white swan. No chill wind, no icy chop. Just a single swan in the dawn sunlight, a graceful portent, perhaps, of spring.
LEAD: A man was killed when he lost control of his car as he berated another driver for cutting him off on the Sprain Brook Parkway, the state police said today.

LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, the parent of Panasonic, Technics and Quasar, yesterday announced the appointment of Richard A. Kraft as president and chief operating officer, the first American to hold the posts.
LEAD: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan lost an effort Monday to break her political opponent's control over the country's most populous province, Punjab.

LEAD: Before this year, perhaps Ball State University's most publicized claim to fame was its being the alma mater of David Letterman, the late-night television host whose 1970 graduation from the school in Muncie, Ind., is now memorialized by a plaque that reads: ''Dedicated to all C students before and after me.
LEAD: ''Roseanne,'' the hit comedy series on ABC, knocked the ''Cosby Show'' from its longstanding position at the top of the Nielsen ratings last week.

LEAD: United Parcel Service Inc. has ordered 10 more Boeing 757-200PF jet freighters at a cost of about $500 million, the aircraft maker said today. In 1985, U.P.S., based in Greenwich, Conn., ordered 20 of the 757-200PF's - for ''package freighters'' - and took options on 15 more. Today's order converts 10 of those options into firm sales.
LEAD: Should Israel talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization? The question cannot begin to be addressed as long as the P.L.O. continues to speak in two voices.

LEAD: Should there be more religion on television? Dan Wakefield, journalist, novelist and sometime television writer, thinks so. In last's week TV Guide, he offered several examples of the sort of faith that he wants projected into the American home. One episode got his special blessing. It occurred on ''Thirtysomething'' on ABC, when Michael, shocked by an automobile accident involving his wife and baby daughter, wound up at a synagogue service.

LEAD: Last spring Williwear, a clothing company known for its youthful trend-setting design, broke the tape for a pack of high-profile fashion retailers along lower Fifth Avenue. This neighborhood had been discovered nearly a decade ago by trail-blazing advertising agencies, designers, architects and small publishers in search of cheap rents and large spaces.

LEAD: Indicating they were worried more about the nation's ability to compete in world markets than about possible anti-competitive effects at home, members of a House antitrust panel expressed considerable support today for the proposed $18 billion merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.
LEAD: John Wheeler is looking for a Russian in Moscow with the given name of Mikhail.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A musical performance is a fun-house mirror into which the player peers, perhaps thinking to see the image of the composer. Actually, the reflection always resembles more nearly the performer himself, a specific human being of a certain temperament and a certain talent, locked into a certain time and place.
LEAD: ''I always had a bad spring,'' said Dwight Gooden, who fortunately for the Mets has never had a bad summer.

LEAD: WINTER-SPRING Winter, truculent and tired gives off an empty growl of bluster and cold as Spring, demure and quiet shows a shy budding smile of gentle, pale green soon to break into a full bloomed last laugh April with a broad Crayola grin winking, smirking at a waning, muted played-out Winter March.

LEAD: The conductor Andrew Litton has canceled his next three appearances at the Metropolitan Opera because of illness. He was to have conducted ''Eugene Onegin'' on Saturday, next Tuesday and March 25. James Levine is to take Mr. Litton's place on those dates. No replacement has been announced for subsequent performances.

LEAD: A prosecution witness testified today that he had heard a group of teen-agers on a Hoboken street taunt his friend, Navroze Mody, about his baldness but that he was knocked to the ground within 90 seconds and did not see anyone actually hit Mr. Mody.
LEAD: Interest rates, which fell last week for the first time this year, rose yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

LEAD: A group of executives of the American Continental Corporation, including a former Congressman from California, has offered to buy the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, one of the nation's largest savings institutions.

LEAD: In an amiable Senate hearing laced with humor and references to family and character, Representative Dick Cheney, President Bush's second nominee as Secretary of Defense, today began what Republicans and Democrats alike promised would be a quick confirmation process.

LEAD: Hardly since World War II has an exhibition of 20th-century art been as eagerly awaited as the retrospective of Kasimir Malevich that opened on March 5 at the Stedelijk Museum here and can be seen through May 23. For the first time, the Soviet authorities have agreed to lend the bulk of their hitherto virtually invisible holdings of Malevich.

LEAD: A walk by the athletic complex on the campus of Princeton University provides a visitor with no sign of unusual activity. There are no groups of students planning pep rallies, no banners proclaiming basketball glory, no sense of excitement or expectation in the air.

LEAD: East Europeans have taken to calling Rumania's President, Nicolae Ceausescu, the ''Idi Amin of Communism.'' He has squandered billions on grandiose public works that don't work, and has left many of his people hungry and freezing in half-darkened homes. Yet on his 71st birthday in January he was acclaimed as ''The Great Conductor,'' ''The Genius of the Carpathians'' and ''The Danube of Thought.

LEAD: In New York City, where replacing a subway light bulb often seems to require an enormous outlay of public funds, it is good to learn of a project that will cost at most $175 and maybe rid the parks of rats. It involves owls.

LEAD: From Maine to California, governments and housing groups are scrambling to help hundreds of thousands of lower-income tenants whose apartments are threatened by unforeseen consequences of Federal programs begun in the 1960's.

LEAD: The Fisher Camuto Group, a privately held shoe company, said yesterday that it might be willing to offer more for the Footwear division of the United States Shoe Corporation than the $422.5 million bid announced Feb. 26 by an investment group headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. But Fisher Camuto said it first wanted access to confidential sales information.

LEAD: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority offered $134 million of revenue bonds yesterday for a housing mortgage finance program. The competitive bidding was won by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: In a long and sometimes emotional afternoon of testimony, Angella Issajenko told a Canadian Government commission today that her teammate, Ben Johnson, knew exactly what he was doing over the seven years he took anabolic steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Manhattan approved the settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering lawsuit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday, saying the agreement ''affords some hope that the union will become part of the mainstream of honest unionism.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, shouted at a prosecution lawyer today when questioned about a letter he wrote to a Congressman the day before he attempted suicide in 1987.
LEAD: Last month, the nation's governors cited Americans' ignorance of foreign languages and cultures as a threat to this country's future.

LEAD: A consortium of community colleges, liberal arts colleges, foundations, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Association of American Colleges are beginning a program to encourage students in two-year schools to continue their education beyond an associate's degree.
LEAD: The distinctive cry of snow geese is usually music to the ears, and money in the cash register, for this northern Missouri town that is the ''home of the honkers,'' as a highway sign proclaims.
LEAD: A main nut on the rotor shaft of a military helicopter was replaced just two days before it crashed, killing 15 servicemen, military officials said today.

LEAD: Trone Advertising, an agency based in Greensboro, N.C., has received nearly $6 million in billings from two major accounts in the last two weeks. Carlyle & Company, a jewelry store chain, awarded its $3.3 million account to Trone this week, and the Weyerhaeuser Company assigned a $2.5 million account last week.
LEAD: Alaska Airlines has prospered by emphasizing service, with touches like an extra flight attendant on heavily booked flights, more expensive meals and fewer seats in each plane.
LEAD: Louis John Puglies, once a senior partner of the now defunct Manhattan brokerage firm of Filor, Bullard & Smythe, died yesterday at his home in Saddle River, N.J. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee told Israel's Foreign Minister today that support for Israel, while solid in Congress, was beginning to show signs of erosion among the American public.
LEAD: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said the wide-ranging program of rebates and low-rate financing it announced Thursday would not hurt first-quarter profits.

LEAD: Several members of Congress raised questions today about whether the Bush Administration's desire to sustain the Nicaraguan guerrillas for another year was consistent with a regional peace plan that would disarm and disband the rebels.
LEAD: There is no way for shoppers to know whether unlabeled fruit is domestic or imported, and if it is imported there is no way to tell whether it comes from Chile, Mexico or New Zealand.

LEAD: More than 700 Suffolk County residents, irate over rising property taxes, packed the legislative chambers here today to demand that county lawmakers roll back the increases or face defeat at the polls in November.

LEAD: Two years ago, Mike Price, the football coach at Weber State, was beaten out by Dennis Erickson for the Washington State job. Yesterday, Price was named to succeed Erickson. Price, 42, had a 46-44 record in 8 seasons at Weber State, including a 5-6 record last season. He was a leading candidate for the Washington State job when Erickson was picked in 1987 from Wyoming.

LEAD: A bill that would prohibit children under the age of 12 from riding in the back of a pickup truck passed the State Senate in a voice vote Monday and was sent to the House. The bill would make it a misdemeanor to carry a child in the back of a pickup on a public road at more than 15 miles per hour.

LEAD: Florida bank regulators have ordered the sale of part of a $28 million art collection assembled by the largest savings and loan institution in the Southeast. The centerpiece of the collection is a Rubens painting that was purchased in a private sale for $13.2 million through Sotheby's, the auction house, but that is said by some experts in New

LEAD: The Carmina Quartet, an ensemble based in Zurich, gave an impressive account of itself in a Sunday afternoon concert at the Frick Collection. Its players - Matthias Enderle and Susanne Frank, violinists; Wendy Champney, violist, and Stephan Goerner, cellist - produce a unified, well-blended and interestingly textured sound.

LEAD: Depositors at savings institutions, seeking higher-yielding investments and nervous about the Bush bailout plan, withdrew a record $10.7 billion in January plus $8 billion to $9 billion in February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Lindsay String Quartet's program at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night had largely to do with finalities. Britten finished his Third Quartet only months before he died. Beethoven's Opus 135 in F was his last quartet as well.

LEAD: The main Afrikaner church has backed away from its unequivocal condemnation of apartheid last week, apparently jeopardizing gains it had achieved in talks with its mixed-race and black counterparts.

LEAD: The House of Representatives split along party lines today as it passed a bill that would require President Bush to intervene in the Eastern Airlines strike.
LEAD: Chile's fruit export industry was paralyzed today as growers and sellers halted all shipments and began scouring their stocks in response to a worldwide cyanide contamination scare.

''There's a tendency for them to walk on the trails and the biggest trails available to them are the tracks and the roads,'' said Carl Grauvogel, a state wildlife biologist.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed at the close of a mixed session yesterday.

LEAD: IN the early 1980's, Empire of America, the Buffalo-based savings bank, was part of the solution to the crisis in the savings and loan industry, acquiring 13 sick institutions with the approval and help of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

LEAD: A comprehensive housing bill, intended to provide assistance across the spectrum from the homeless to first-time home buyers, was introduced in the Senate today with broad and bipartisan support.

LEAD: John Van Buren, the former dean of Hofstra University's School of Education, died of liver cancer Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 57 and lived in Hempstead, L.I.

LEAD: Here is a sampling of special Holy Week events in Manhattan, including performances of oratorios. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Today ALICE TULLY HALL. Music by Lassus, Weill, Ginastera; Schutz's ''German Requiem''; Luboff's ''Look to This Day,'' and other works; Musica Sacra Chorus, a capella and with cello, bass and organ; Richard Westenburg, director and with synthesizer.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission repealed a rule today that had limited contracts between television networks and their local affiliate stations to two years. The F.C.C. said the rule, adopted in 1945 when TV networks were just forming and lining up local outlets for their programs, was no longer necessary to assist in the development of new TV networks in today's television industry of alternative delivery systems such as satellites and cable.

LEAD: Herbert A. Brandon, the former publisher of Brandon's Shipper and Forwarder, a trade publication for the shipping industry, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Some of the world's greatest players were on the sidelines today at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals after suffering a big upset by a small margin in the second round of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams.

LEAD: In 1981, in a symbol of the army-linked repression that turned criticism of the right into a capital offense, the armed forces put a bounty on the heads of 138 leftists by publishing a list of their names and describing them as wanted traitors.

LEAD: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop told a Congressional hearing today that there was not enough evidence to assess the psychological effects of abortion and that an unimpeachable scientific report was not possible.

LEAD: The Chinese these days are not given to looking sentimentally at their violent and troubled 20th-century history, and Fred Tan, the young Taiwanese director whose film ''Rouge of the North'' is playing tonight and tomorrow as part of the New Directors/New Films series, is no exception. ''Rouge of the North'' depicts the empty formalities and useless customs, the cruelty and resignation that many of China's most important writers, particularly in the 1920's and 30's, saw as the fatal flaws of their society.
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had taken over 47 insolvent savings and loan associations in five states with assets of $6.8 billion.

LEAD: Stuart M. Glasser, executive vice president for merchandising at Lord & Taylor, has been named president and chief executive of the department-store division of the Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation of Dayton, Ohio.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, long engaged in rescuing and preserving historic buildings, will be honored by the National Building Museum at a dinner Wednesday for ''championing the quality in buildings and public places for over 25 years.''

LEAD: Norm Nixon, who faded from the National Basketball Association limelight after he was traded from the Los Angeles Lakers to the Clippers in 1983, announced his retirement yesterday.
LEAD: R. Gene Simmons is back on death row today after a fellow inmate persuaded the United States Supreme Court to block Mr. Simmons's execution for the slayings of 14 members of his family.

LEAD: The fall and winter fashion collections opened here Wednesday with an explosive blast of color and invention. The starting teams were a medley of Japanese, French and American players; Italians will show later. It is fashion with a global sweep.
LEAD: Three Federal agencies, responding to growing public alarm about the safety of the chemical Alar, said in a statement today, ''The Government believes it is safe for Americans to eat apples.''

LEAD: The nation's industrial operating rate declined last month for the first time since September, but economists and analysts said it was too soon to tell whether this signaled a sustained easing of inflationary pressures.

This is one of the few valuable insights to be obtained from ''Slaves of New York,'' the film based on Tama Janowitz's short stories about various denizens of the downtown art scene, stories that amount to ashtray-wearing in a literary vein.

LEAD: China rejected American scrutiny of its family-planning programs today, saying it was a nation's sovereign right to determine its own population policy.

LEAD: ''Tapeheads'' sees the world of commercial video production as a new frontier, a wild and woolly place where rules don't exist yet and the pioneering spirit still prevails. It's a funny idea, one that might have been more so if the film had worked solely in that satirical vein. As it is, ''Tapeheads'' tacks on various cliched elements of intrigue - there's a blackmail plot against a political candidate - that dilute its humor.

LEAD: Dino Anagnost is to conduct the Little Orchestra Society in a children's concert with a space theme at Avery Fisher Hall at 11j A.M. tomorrow. The program, ''A Musical Journey Through Time and Space,'' includes an excerpt from Richard Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra''; John Williams's ''Star Wars'' Suite; ''Mars'' from Gustav Holst's ''Planets'' and Otto Luening's ''Fantasy in Space.

LEAD: The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency, which said in June that it intended to issue taxable commercial paper to support interim financing for small businesses, said yesterday that it had completed the first transaction under the program.

LEAD: Parlay betting, introduced to New York racing last fall, always seemed likely to prove more popular at OTB parlors than at the track. Lunchtime offtrack bettors were expected to like the idea of betting several races in advance, whereas on-track players could reinvest their own money.

LEAD: The viola can be a deeply poetic instrument - any good performance of Berlioz's ''Harold in Italy'' is proof of that. But given its intermediary status between the brilliance of the violin and the richness of the cello, the viola can also sound genteel and bland as a solo instrument. Within those muted terms, Rosemary Glyde's viola recital Monday night at Alice Tully Hall provided considerable pleasure.

LEAD: Prosecutors rested their case yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens in the trial of three men charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer, Edward Byrne, in South Jamaica on Feb. 26, 1988. Prosecutors say Officer Byrne was killed by four men at the order of a drug dealer seeking retaliation against the police.

LEAD: Apparently seeking to dispel reports of a conflict with the Treasury, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today endorsed the reorientation of the developing-world debt policy proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With the closing today of a student art exhibit that protesters said defiled the American flag, military veterans rolled up their own flags and said they would end daily demonstrations in front of the Chicago Institute of Arts.

LEAD: Mark Ingram, a Giants wide receiver, told a Federal jury here today that he knowingly violated National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations when he agreed to be represented by Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom. He also accepted loans from the agents before his eligibility at Michigan State had expired.
LEAD: Dr. Steven Koweity, a pediatrician, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Sand Lake Hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Searingtown, L.I.

LEAD: IN advertising, as in the theater, a smashing out-of-town tryout does not mean an act will succeed on Broadway. Struggling to prove itself an exception to the rule, Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein has discovered that patience is one of several lessons it can impart.

North suggests that President Ronald Reagan approved a ''very specialized intelligence'' mission in October 1985 to equip the Nicaraguan rebels with information and weapons to attack the Sandinista government's arms shipments.

LEAD: President Bush talked with the Discovery astronauts today as their shuttle orbited 184 miles above the Earth, praising their work and pledging his support for a proposed $25 billion space station.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that a new technology to send advertising by telephone wires to in-store video monitors cannot be used for cigarette advertising. The unanimous decision overturned a 1986 staff ruling by the commission that it had no jurisdiction over the system, created by the Marketing Technologies Group Inc.

LEAD: There's an intentionally dreamlike quality to the physical and emotional violence in Jean-Claude Brisseau's ''Sound and Fury'' (''De Bruit et de Fureur''), about a couple of young, none-too-bright boys trying to find order in a world that has none.

LEAD: American Mensa, the society for people with high intelligence quotients, is taking to the airwaves with its first television advertising campaign. The Central South Carolina chapter of the organization has bought time on the network affiliates and the Cable News Network to attract new members. The spot, which will be shown through March 26, is designed to appeal to ''extraordinary'' viewers, a Mensa official said.
LEAD: A former Wall Street securities analyst was found guilty of murder today in the strangling and beating of his second wife in their summer home in Amagansett, L.I., in 1987.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 18 about political developments in Liechtenstein described the country's history incorrectly. Formed in 1719, the principality was part of the Rhine and German confederations between 1806 and 1866.

LEAD: Roy Hanson, a writer and editor at Newsday, died of lung cancer Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 54 and lived in Copiague, L.I.

LEAD: Young Irish immigrants in a steady stream climbed a flight of stairs above Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, last Tuesday to try their luck in the Federal Government's latest organized immigration gamble - a lottery that promises legal status to a happy few.

LEAD: The suddenness of their troubles has not quite shaken the Yankees, but they no longer look like the team that began spring training. Dave Winfield is hurt. Ron Guidry faces surgery. There are trades being considered, and tonight Don Mattingly said that a strained muscle behind his left thigh would keep him out of the lineup for a few days.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle charged today that critics of the Bush Administration were looking for ''razzle-dazzle'' rather than substance and said that news organizations were promoting shallow politics to suit the needs of broadcast news programs.

LEAD: Lynne V. Cheney, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the wife of Representative Dick Cheney, called The Washingtonian magazine this week with a bit of old but still good inside stuff.

LEAD: Senior United States officials here charged today that Cuba and Soviet-bloc countries had been upgrading the arsenal of the Salvadoran rebels to help them escalate their nine-year war against the American-backed Government.

LEAD: For decades, the United States managed to avoid the proliferation of cabinet positions that engulf other governments, keeping the total under a dozen. By comparison, China has 44, Japan 22, Britain 21. Indeed, Presidential study commissions have repeatedly urged simplifying the U.S. cabinet structure, creating, for instance, five supercabinet jobs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Holy Week, that solemn, inevitable progression in the Passion of Christ that proceeds from this weekend's Palm Sunday through Maundy Thursday and Good Friday to Easter Sunday, forms the culmination of the Christian year - and, by extension, the annual high point of Christian liturgical music. The sheer richness and variety of the church-music concerts and musically accompanied services to be heard in the next 10 days provides an opportunity to examine that liturgical world in the New York area, and in particular the extent and diversity of music making in

LEAD: The 22d annual Film and Video Festival of the Brooklyn Arts Council continues tomorrow in the Uris auditorium of the Metropolitan museum of Art, from 1 to 5 P.M. The festival focuses on independent film and video artists, and the program tomorrow features ''The Man Who Planted Trees,'' a 30-minute animated film by Frederick Back that won an Academy Award last year; Esther Duran's ''My Sin Is Loving You,'' a Brooklyn-made film that was selected as the festival's best narrative drama, and 11 other works.

LEAD: Michael Ritchie's ''Fletch Lives'' is the overly optimistic title of the follow-up to the far more entertaining 1985 Ritchie comedy ''Fletch,'' about a wise-cracking investigative reporter played by Chevy Chase. ''Fletch Lives'' looks less like ''Fletch 2,'' which it is, numerically speaking, than '
LEAD: Joseph Carroll, an author, editor, journalist and prominent figure in the Irish-American arts, died of congestive heart failure March 7. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: Elmer Lee Fingar, a former partner in McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan, Drazen & Smith, a law firm in White Plains, died Tuesday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: ''Toward Form'' is a nice little show. It is about process. Its selections are revealing. Although there are no major works, visitors to the Greenberg Wilson Gallery are likely to come away knowing more than before about all six artists.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn will likely seek the Democratic nomination for New York City comptroller, joining an already crowded primary that will almost certainly be as contentious as the Democratic mayoral contest.

LEAD: P. J. Carlesimo and Seton Hall have a blueprint that makes plenty of sense to them as they enter the school's second National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament since the Pirates began playing basketball in 1903. It unfolds this way: We're the third-seeded team in the West Regional with a 26-6 record and play Southwest Missouri State (21-9) Friday in McKale Center at the University of Arizona.
LEAD: Even when the Senate is at its back-slapping friendliest, there is an edge to the smiles and laughter. Witness a discussion at a meeting of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
LEAD: It has become an annual ritual among law deans: Magazines publish surveys ranking the top schools, the winners spread the good news and the losers profess disdainful indifference.

LEAD: The United States Justice Department yesterday offered a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of Constabile Farace, who is suspected of killing a Federal drug agent on Staten Island last month.

LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority has agreed to expand bus service in a Queens neighborhood after merchants there sued the authority, saying their businesses had suffered when bus routes were changed or eliminated.

LEAD: The Hispanic community is the target of ads introduced Wednesday by the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America. The spots, which are part of the pro bono anti-drug campaign, will be shown on several Spanish-language television stations, including Univision and Telemundo. They will also be on English-language radio and television stations in cities with large Hispanic populations.
LEAD: The Senate today refused to dismiss impeachment charges that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami conspired to get a $150,000 bribe and later lied about it at his trial.
LEAD: Terry A. Anderson began his fifth year as a hostage in Lebanon today, and the Bush Administration called his detention a ''criminal act which serves no cause'' and demanded his release.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 460 money market mutual funds increased by $1.26 billion, to $296.55 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $213.6 million, to $72.47 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $913 million, to $96.11 billion.

LEAD: There is something wonderfully primordial about watching Madison Avenue moguls roll up their shirtsleeves and tear into slabs of roasted lamb with their hands, then lick their fingers and snag a clump of cauliflower along with some barbecued shrimp. This peculiar scene unfolds daily at Bukhara, the Indian restaurant that specializes in what is called frontier cooking.

LEAD: The fertility of fields is declining. . . . Mismanagement is responsible for the loss of up to 20 percent of everything raised. . . . Sometimes one has to travel scores, even hundreds of kilometers to benefit from elementary services or buy primitive necessities. . . . The situation is so grave in many regions that people are deserting the land.

LEAD: There are those in legal and public interest circles here who say that Daniel Sheehan has a messianic desire to uncover criminal conspiracies by conservatives and has long been a legal accident waiting to happen. There are others who say Mr. Sheehan is a maligned prophet deserving honor, not scorn from his peers.

LEAD: * Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis, said it would introduce a de-alcoholized beer, O'Doul's, in five Southern test markets next week.

LEAD: Nearly 300 refugees detained by the Immigration and Naturalization Service at Port Isabel, Tex., tried to pull the chain link fence out of the ground this afternoon before the police stopped them, witnesses said.
LEAD: Top-ranked Arizona scored the first 12 points, took a 21-2 lead and defeated Robert Morris, 94-60, in the first round of the West Regional today.

LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV's call for a ''drastic restructuring'' of Soviet agriculture, aimed at increasing food production long term, could aggravate his country's immediate fiscal crisis. At a time of worsening agricultural shortages, Mr. Gorbachev has proposed a farm price increase next January, somewhat greater flexibility for farmers to negotiate the prices of what they sell and, ultimately, ''complete freedom'' to choose ways of marketing their products.

LEAD: Winding down its current pledge period, public television goes for a couple of classy acts this weekend, both offered under the ''Great Performances'' umbrella. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, there is the hourlong Don Mischer Production called ''Gregory Hines's Tap Dance in America,'' a current state-of-the-art survey that gets you feeling good and keeps you that way until the taking-it-home finale.
LEAD: Two Landsat Earth-sensing satellites that were to be turned off at the end of the month for lack of money have been given a reprieve by the Bush Administration.

LEAD: An 11-year-old boy was arrested today after he carried a loaded semiautomatic pistol into an elementary school, the police said. The boy, whose name was not released because of his age, was arrested at Shelter Rock Elementary School after a teacher found the 9-millimeter pistol in a gym bag on the floor of a classroom, said Lieut.

LEAD: Travel industry executives said yesterday that several tour operators who had sold tour packages based on flights on Eastern Airlines have declared for bankruptcy since Eastern machinists went on strike two weeks ago. An undetermined number of travelers have been left with little financial recourse except to file as creditors in the bankruptcy proceedings involving the tour operators.

LEAD: ''SOUND AND FURY,'' the French writer and director Jean-Claude Brisseau's film about aimless adolescents drifting into violence in a working-class high-rise complex outside of Paris, has little of the bonhomie and sensuousness we tend to associate with French cinema.

LEAD: Two poisoned Chilean grapes add another puzzling dimension to the menace of global terrorism. Warnings by public health authorities in Washington, Tokyo and Ottawa have brought Chile's huge fruit exports to a standstill, and Chilean fruit has been pulled off the market while inspectors investigate thousands upon thousands of crates.

LEAD: CORRECTION: In a recent column suggesting a ban on the sale to civilians of military-type assault rifles, the favorite tool of the drug killers, I called them automatic weapons. Wrong.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Home Section yesterday about three influences on modern American style omitted the name of the designer of F. Schumacher & Company's ''Eisenhower Toile'' fabric. She is Elizabeth Draper.

LEAD: The Transport Minister came under attack in Parliament Thursday for withholding from the public Government warnings sent to airlines and airports last November and December about terrorist bombs in radio-cassette players. Such a bomb brought down a Pan Am jumbo jet in Scotland in December.

LEAD: James Levine and members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra are to give a chamber music concert at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73d Street, on Sunday at 4 P.M. The program includes Ponchielli's Quintet for Winds and Piano, Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat,'' the Debussy Cello Sonata and Puccini's ''Chrysanthemums,'' for string quartet.
LEAD: What is the point of racing around Washington grabbing Federal dollars for New York City if bureaucratic gridlock prevents the city from using the money?

LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, which stunned the banking community in December with the announcement of large problem loans at its new partner, the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, yesterday announced a loss of $176.2 million for the fourth quarter. In the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company lost $34.6 million.

LEAD: The official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who supervised the background check on John G. Tower said in an internal briefing paper that the investigation found a ''pattern of alcohol abuse'' that Mr. Tower had taken steps to correct by 1983.

LEAD: No heads rolled in the top echelons of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters as part of this week's settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering suit against the giant union. Since it was well known that the Government had originally intended to force at least five international vice presidents with strong mob ties to walk the plank as the price of a negotiated peace, many observers have concluded that once again the forces of law have wound up on the short end of a major contest with the underworld.

LEAD: When Vladimir Feltsman arrived in the United States two years ago as a much-publicized emigre, he enjoyed a ready-made kind of success. Owing to his long and successful struggle to leave the Soviet Union, many listeners were naturally predisposed to admire him as a political hero and, by illogical extension, to believe in his greatness as a pianist.

LEAD: It's one thing to blame the Russians for behind-the-scenes chicanery in Vietnam, as George P. Cosmatos did when he directed ''Rambo: First Blood, Part II. '' It's quite another to blame them for mutant undersea monsters, which is what Mr. Cosmatos's new ''Leviathan'' does.
LEAD: Votes on 2 Nominees, And More About Tower

LEAD: One thing to celebrate on St. Patrick's Day weekend is the vitality of Irish traditional music - the jigs, reels and Kerry slides for dancing, the harp tunes, ballads and slow airs for listening. Around the world, traditional music is under siege by broadcast mass-marketed pop and rock. Although Ireland has its share of U2 wanna-bes, the Irish and their diaspora in Britain and the United States have held onto old-fashioned instruments like the fiddle, accordion, pennywhistle, bodhran (hand drum) and uileann pipes
LEAD: With Mario Lemieux out because of an injury, the Pittsburgh Penguins clinched their first playoff berth of the Lemieux era with a 2-1 victory over the Devils tonight.
LEAD: Zairean Shakers
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Chilean Government agreed today to work on an urgent basis to return Chilean fruit to grocers' shelves in the United States.

LEAD: Teh De Falla Trio - Terry Graves, Dusan Bogdanovic and Kenton Youngstrom, guitarists - is to play music by Mr. Bogdanovic, Qilliam Boyce, Leonard Bernstein, Theolonious Monk, Mozart, Stravinsky and the ensemble's namesake, Manuel de Falla, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Mexico is expanding its cooperation with American efforts to curb the flow of illegal immigrants into the U.S. The Mexican Government has allowed Federal immigration agents to step up their investigations in Mexico. Page A1
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Newspaper advertising spending rose 6.1 percent in 1988 over the previous year, according to an industry report, but the numbers will give little solace to jittery newspaper executives.

LEAD: Christina Martin, a ninth grader at the Rochester School for the Deaf, knows what it would be like to go to a local public school where everybody else could hear, because she tried it a few years ago.

LEAD: John P. Scripps, founder and chairman of the board of the John P. Scripps Newspapers division of the Scripps Howard media group, died of heart failure Wednesday night at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla. He was 76 years old.
LEAD: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the wounded giant of health maintenance organizations, filed yesterday for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

LEAD: Through thousands of television and movie westerns and more than a century of intimate involvement with the United States military, the name Colt Firearms has become emotionally and historically loaded with meaning.

LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously endorsed the nomination of Representative Dick Cheney to be Secretary of Defense today, praising his ''high standards of personal conduct and integrity.''

LEAD: The 18th New Directors/New Films series, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Department of Film of the Museum of Modern Art, begins tonight at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the museum, 11 West 53d Street. Tickets may be ordered by mail at the Film Society, 140 West 65th Street, New York, N.Y.
LEAD: For the first time, Sears, Roebuck & Company has appointed a major outside marketing and merchandising organization to develop a series of women's apparel lines.
LEAD: They arrive this time each year, all at once, in cities and towns they have never seen before, and places they have dreamt about for weeks.
LEAD: Texaco Inc. yesterday announced a new ''poison pill'' defense to block anyone who might try to take over the huge oil company.

LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty yesterday named Richard Johnson as its New York chairman and chief creative officer. Since 1987, Mr. Johnson, 47 years old, has been the agency's Detroit president and chief creative officer and was a force in retaining the AMC/Jeep and Renault account for the agency and in building it to $150 million in billings.
LEAD: ''He has to be everybody's President, not just the N.R.A.'s President.'' - Hugh Brock, a gun dealer, on Government curbs on the import of assault rifles. [ A18:2. ]

LEAD: In a move that further deregulates the telephone business, the Federal Communications Commission today changed its method of shaping long-distance rates, giving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company more freedom to set its own prices.

LEAD: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation approved a new employment plan yesterday to address repeated charges by black and Hispanic workers that its hiring and promotion practices are discriminatory.
LEAD: Taxes on cigarettes cover the costs imposed on society by smoking, but taxes on alcohol do not pay for the costs of drinking, a new study reports.

LEAD: The Senate today approved a bill to increase job protection for Federal workers who expose waste, fraud and abuse. A similar measure was killed last year by President Reagan when he let Congress adjourn without his taking action on it.
LEAD: John A. Spiech has sold some exotic cars in his career, including the Lotus and the Ferrari. Now he will try to get the utilitarian Yugo moving out of showrooms.

LEAD: The once-decorous process by which Federal judges select their law clerks has degenerated into a free-for-all in which some of the nation's most eminent judges scramble for the top law school students.
LEAD: The Knicks' 26-game winning streak at home, the third-longest in the National Basketball Association for a season, ended last night.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Cleaning a litter box is a bit like paying bills: a necessary chore, but hardly a favorite pastime.
LEAD: Sales of United States Savings Bonds declined in February for the first time in five months, falling 14.5 percent, to $691 million, the Treasury Department said Thursday.

LEAD: Beatrice Swancutt Wright Fuerst, former assistant director of women's activities for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, died of natural causes Wednesday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 83 years old and lived in Rhinebeck.

LEAD: The Colombian film ''Details of a Duel'' takes place on a single morning, during which two decent and well-liked citizens of a small Andean village prepare to die. The schoolteacher (Frank Ramirez) and the butcher (Humberto Dorado) have, for reasons that are not explained, challenged each other to a fatal contest.

LEAD: Jesus Maria de Leizaola, who headed the Basque government in exile for nearly two decades during the Franco dictatorship, died Thursday after a heart attack, doctors in this Basque provincial capital said. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would allow most Chilean fruit to return to American grocery shelves over the next five to nine days, but the agency also introduced more stringent inspections to help assure the safety of the imported produce.

LEAD: Charles Billingslea, a retired Army major general who served in World War II and Korea and later helped to enforce judicial desegregation orders in Mississippi and Alabama, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 74 years old and lived in Oxford, Md.

LEAD: Although he led the Brigham Young basketball team to five winning seasons in six years as coach, Ladell Anderson resigned yesterday. ''I felt this was the best thing I could do for myself, the university and everyone concerned,'' he said of his sudden announcement. ''There was never any pressure put on me by anyone at Brigham Young or the administration.

LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it has signed a letter of intent to acquire a majority interest in the Interbase Software Corporation of Bedford, Mass., a privately held company specializing in data base software for minicomputers. Ashton-Tate previously had acquired a minority interest in Interbase as part of a joint-technology agreement announced in April 1988.

LEAD: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has told Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. that it must dismiss Michael R. Milken before a settlement of the agency's complaint against it is submitted to the S.E.C. commissioners for approval, people involved in the situation said.

LEAD: Edwin Janss Jr., a California real estate developer who helped expand and develop the ski resorts of Sun Valley and Snowmass, fell to his death Thursday when he jumped from the 12th story of a building in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: A servicewoman with a 6-month-old daughter has sued for a hardship discharge from the Army so she will not be sent to South Korea and be separated from her child.

LEAD: Bowing to a heightened campaign by leftist rebels to disrupt presidential elections, poll workers resigned today in 11 eastern towns, provincial officials said.

LEAD: A committee of the Inter-American Development Bank has agreed to increase the bank's capital by $26.43 billion in a compromise that resolves a three-year dispute between the United States and Latin American countries over the organization's policies.

LEAD: Angel Myers, the swimmer from Furman who was disqualified from the United States Olympic team for testing positive for steroids, made a smooth return to competition Thursday at the N.C.A.A. women's swimming and division championships in Indianapolis. Myers, who placed first at the Olympic trials in the 50- and 100-meter freestyle events and the 100 butterfly, won the 200 individual medley in a career best time of 1 minute 59.49 seconds.
LEAD: Helen Engelhardt asked Alan, her 6-year-old son, to sit next to her on the couch. This wasn't going to be easy.
LEAD: Eddie Chiles, the principal owner of the Texas Rangers, said yesterday he had agreed to sell his 58 percent share of the team to a group led by George W. Bush, the President's son.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said tonight that a judicial report on the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, which had been suppressed on the grounds of national security since 1986, would be released to Parliament in 10 days.

LEAD: Under a little-noticed provision of the anti-drug law Congress adopted last fall, companies and institutions will risk losing future Federal contracts and grants if they do not make a ''good-faith effort'' to institute programs that assure a drug-free workplace.

LEAD: With a breeze at his back, a Ben at either side and his rivals walking well behind him, Edward Irving Koch strode up Fifth Avenue yesterday in his 12th St. Patrick's Day Parade as Mayor of New York City, exultant amid no more than a smattering of boos and determined to march in a 13th next year.

LEAD: The Halliburton Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell a subsidiary, the Life Insurance Company of the Southwest, to a West German-led investment group for $71 million in cash. Halliburton announced last September that it was seeking a buyer for the company, which it has owned for 25 years.

LEAD: In making its first move into Manhattan, Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based retail chain, believes it can succeed in a market in which many other mid-price retailers have found it impossible to survive. It is a risky move, but one the chain sees as necessary.

LEAD: In a setback for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a bankruptcy judge yesterday ended the utility's exclusive right to propose a plan to end its bankruptcy and gave himself a major role in future negotiations.

LEAD: A Michigan judge yesterday upheld the legality of the November referendum in which Michigan voters cut off public funds for abortions except those in which a woman's life is endangered.

LEAD: The House Armed Services Committee has overwhelmingly rejected an effort to block the shutdown of surplus military bases, but the battle isn't over yet. Representatives from California, Illinois and New Jersey are leading the fight to keep pouring money into obsolete installations. They plan to bring the issue to a floor vote next month; it warrants the same resounding disapproval.

LEAD: Milton J. Petrie, the octogenarian chairman and chief executive of the Petrie Stores Corporation, disclosed today that he might seek to acquire all the shares of Deb Shops Inc. that he does not already control.

LEAD: In a brief ceremony under a blazing sun, the Government today officially pardoned 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard imprisoned when the Sandinistas came to power 10 years ago.
LEAD: The highest-rated female chess player in the world will join about 40 grandmasters at the Penta Hotel for the New York International tournament tomorrow through March 28.

LEAD: The youth whose errors are recounted in ''The Errors of Youth'' is Dmitri Guryanov, whom we meet as he is about to complete his army service. His main error is restlessness, an inability to settle down with one or another of the pretty women who find him appealing. The main error of this Soviet movie, which will be shown tonight at 6:30 and tomorrow at 3:30 P.M.

LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf's concert Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall took a prize for imaginative programming. Bringing together three seldom-heard pieces by Debussy, Brahms and Berlioz, it had great intrinsic interest. Fortunately, the night also proved to have extrinsic interest as well, in the form of carefully prepared, gracefully realized performances.

LEAD: In an arena filled with the squeals of teen-age girls, as the Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands was on Wednesday night, Bon Jovi's popularity starts to make sense. Seasoned rock listeners are dismayed by the multimillion-record sales of a band that blatantly borrows from other rock while dispensing cliche upon cliche; hearing Bon Jovi is like being locked in a greeting-card warehouse with a radio that plays only 1970's ''classic rock.
LEAD: A new vision of the American urban future emerged today as regional officials in Southern California voted to impose drastic restrictions on everyday activities to reduce air pollution.

LEAD: I was told to measure up, so I did. But rather than shuffling off to shrink, shrine or spa, I went to meet my makers. And in this material world, that meant suiter, shirter and shoer. I admit that I'm too old to be a yuppie, and too young to be an old boy, but I do like nice things. So when asked to venture on an odyssey into the world of custom-made clothing, I was more than ready to dress up my dressed-down appearance.

LEAD: AS the mascot of Newtown High School, the image of an Indian warrior graces everything from the school welcome mat to the jackets on the back of the school's athletes. But students are now debating whether the mascot is a form of racial stereotyping best left behind.

LEAD: MY WIFE and I purchased our home from the estate of a woman who had recently died. All we knew about her was that she had been an elderly widow. Yet you could tell that her last years had not been happy ones. One clue was the heavy steel doors she had had installed front and back. The front door was equipped with an apartment-style peephole, which was needed because she had had the windows in and around the door covered over with contact paper.

LEAD: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art is putting into place the last element of its master plan of 1970 - a second garden court. But what was originally conceived as a vast, skylit garden court has now shrunk to a quarter of its original size and, inside, the museum's 1888 facade has been beautifully restored but been robbed of its perspective.

LEAD: The scholar Percival Spear, who devoted more than 50 years to the study of India, had a special fascination for New Delhi, which he called ''the stop-go capital.'' He meant that the city had an unusually uneven and protean history, changing its face, its ethnic composition, its religious character and its role as a subcontinental metropolis from century to century or decade to decade.
LEAD: The 10th anniversary of the most joyous event in Israel's recent history - the signing of peace with Egypt - will, by deliberate choice, pass virtually unnoticed here.
LEAD: LAST summer when George Bush visited the New Jersey shore, he made a campaign pledge: No Federal licensing fees would be imposed on saltwater fishermen if he became President.
LEAD: The Soviet Union sent troops to Afghanistan in 1979 over the objections of the military's General Staff, a Deputy Defense Minister said in a magazine interview published today.

LEAD: The New York New Music Ensemble's Wednesday-evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall began with two older scores that have not lost their shine. Peter Maxwell Davies's ''Antechrist'' (1967), a set of inventive and colorful variations on a 13th-century motet, and Henry Cowell's amusing ''Set of Five'' (1951), with its lyrical violin line, propulsive piano part and exotically varied percussion component, served as light-spirited appetizers.

LEAD: Dr. Bruce Dobkin states that Dalmane is a short-acting drug. In fact, Dalmane has the longest half life (the time it takes for half of the drug to be metabolized by the body) of any of the benzodiazepines, or 40 to 200 hours. This means that the drug accumulates in the body when taken regularly, especially in the elderly.
LEAD: Eating Italian used to mean a bottle of red wine, a loaf of garlic bread and a thousand tomatoes over spaghetti and veal alike. Then came the revolution.

LEAD: WHEN it is absolutely fresh - straight out of the water - there is nothing better than fish cooked plain, brought sizzling to the table and served with a piece of lemon. But the fish we buy is not always that fresh. There are many ways to enhance its flavor, however, with fresh herbs like thyme or tarragon, or a marinade of soy sauce, spices and ginger.

LEAD: For practically 50 years, George Perle has been known for his ability to unravel in words the intricacies of 12-tone music. Such a classic is his 1962 book ''Serial Composition and Atonality,'' one of the first attempts to explain how Schoenberg, Berg and Webern could make musical sense out of the chaos of atonality, that it will be published in Beijing, in Chinese, this year.

LEAD: JANET TABERER, 66 years old, has been going to the Neighborhood Facility at Nelson Avenue in Peekskill every day for the last several years to get a hot lunch. The hot-lunch program is one of several nutrition programs for the elderly sponsored by the County Office for the Aging.

LEAD: Richard Taylor's claim that his case is ''fairly typical'' is a gross libel on his colleagues. His letter does not mention that 20 years before retirement, he moved to a house 90 miles from his university, abandoned all but the bare minimum of his academic activities, and, for a number of years, devoted himself mainly to the keeping of bees.

LEAD: IN Greenwich, there is talk of a takeover of a water company that has been privately run for nearly a century. ''If they keep raising the rates, it's something we're going to have to consider,'' said First Selectman John B. Margenot Jr. The utility that serves Greenwich, the Connecticut-American Water Company, is seeking a 33 percent rate increase, which would make it the third in as many years.

LEAD: PROPELLED by the common cause of social consciousness - and a creative cost-cutting method of play production - two of the state's newest small professional theater companies have joined forces in the world-premiere staging of a work about the conflicts surrounding independence for Puerto Rico.

LEAD: SHEEP FROM THE GOATS: Selected Literary Essays. By John Simon. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $24.95.) Gore Vidal once called John Simon a ''literary gangster,'' adding that there was nothing Mr. Simon - best known for his trenchant theater reviews in New York magazine - could not ''find to hate.'' Yet as ''The Sheep From the Goats,'' a discerning, highly idiosyncratic collection of literary essays, attests, within the gangster lies an equally ferocious, uncompromising champion of literature.
LEAD: Anglers who find nothing appealing about the great outdoors when their catch comes up short may be able to better their luck if they have access to a facsimile machine.

LEAD: Mandy Patinkin is blessed and cursed with the kind of acute sensitivity that makes many of his waking moments feel like matters of life and death. In the current Public Theater production of Shakespeare's ''Winter's Tale,'' which opens on Tuesday, he plays a character who is even more bedeviled than he by overwhelming anxieties.

LEAD: There can be no easier way of feeling culturally disenfranchised than to insist on seeing the most popular film in the nation each week, whatever it may be. Reading everything on the fiction best-seller list might offer a comparable shock, but it could never match the immediacy of a really bad (as is so often the case) hit film.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Let's hear it for women. That worthy sentiment comes through heartily in ''The Women of Brewster Place,'' the four-hour television movie being broadcast on ABC tonight and tomorrow, beginning at 9 each night. The problem: Just about nothing is heard for men who, almost without exception, are dismissed as irresponsible, even vicious louts.

LEAD: After decades of shunning classroom discussion of religion, fearing that it was too divisive a subject or that church-state separation might be breached, many American public schools are now moving to incorporate it into their curriculums.
LEAD: BEN JONSON A Life. By David Riggs. Illustrated. 399 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.
LEAD: Where have all the rallies gone?

LEAD: What is 12 feet tall, 120 feet long and red, or at least rust, all over? It is ''Tilted Arc,'' a curving steel wall by the sculptor Richard Serra that was at the center of a prolonged artistic battle. The work, commissioned by the Federal Government in 1981, bisected a portion of Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan.

LEAD: EQUESTRIANS with horse sense can spot a pair of authentic English riding boots in any show ring or stable yard around the world. Crafted in the country that developed the formal hunt, dressage and polo, English boots are acknowledged to be the finest in terms of both craftsmanship and materials.

LEAD: Christopher White hoisted a bundle of Norfolk reeds and climbed to his rooftop workplace, repeating a timeless ritual in the ancient craft of thatching, which after decades of decline has dramatically revived in recent years.

LEAD: Lay Down, overtaken on the lead by three rivals as they turned for home, came roaring back in the final yards to run down Its Acedemic and win the $85,300 Grey Lag Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

LEAD: Twenty years ago, E. William Judson opened a real estate office on the East Side of Manhattan and began leasing space for the many midtown galleries that sprang up as New York became the art capital of the world. As he leased more and more space for galleries, he noted that the typical gallery used half its space for storage, making such storage increasingly expensive as rents shot up.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The About Long Island article featuring the Nassau County Police Mounted Unit (''The Nassau Mounties'' Feb. 26) reflects a recent trend, rediscovering horses as a unique resource in modern law enforcement.

LEAD: Cynthia Levy of New York and Dr. Roger Levy of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Andrea Levy, to Jonathan Ian Greenfeld, a son of Drs. Albert and Sandra Greenfeld of Westlake Village, Calif. A June 3 wedding is planned.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: WHEN Hillary M. Lee moved to Weston from Alexandria, Va., recently, she was disappointed to learn there was no local farmers market. So, with the help of the State Department of Agriculture and growers from Connecticut Farm Fresh, Mrs. Lee has organized a farm market that be open on Saturday mornings beginning in late spring in the parking lot of the Weston

LEAD: Most of the characters in the new film ''Slaves of New York'' probably never went to Bloomingdale's, but that is where their real-life counterparts were last Tuesday night for cocktails, to benefit the New York Preservation League. The downtown art-world crowd portrayed in Tama Janowitz's book met 300 other guests in the ''Slaves of New York'' boutique.
LEAD: Hillary Anna Michael, the copy director of Mademoiselle magazine in New York, and David Quinn, an actor, were married last evening at Temple Beth Am in Seattle by Rabbi Norman D. Hirsh.

LEAD: Women of style have always known what a potent tool an accessory can be. With one stroke, the right handbag, careful conglomeration of jewelry or even a hat can give an older, familiar costume a new configuration.

LEAD: After three years of local protests and several lawsuits had tried and failed to halt it, a 10-story condominium tower is rising in Maplewood, N.J., adjacent to the 2,000-acre South Mountain Reservation, one of the few large open spaces left in Essex County. Called ''The Top,'' the residential tower will be the highest structure in the immediate area along the boundary between Maplewood and South
LEAD: He waits until he's comfortable collecting his pension, but Richard Taylor does tell the truth - or at least part of it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WE out here on the East End have been hearing much talk of late about the notion of us just up and telling the whole rest of Suffolk County that we don't want to play with you folks anymore. Some people out here are saying we should make our own county and call it ''Peconic County.''

LEAD: At the Reformed Church in Brookville, L.I., Kimberly Gail Waldorf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Helmuth Waldorf of Brookville, was married yesterday to Brian Krick Mercer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Mercer of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Allan Ramirez performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev.
LEAD: THIS spring, while some people let their fancy turn to thoughts of love, others will be worrying about the New York area housing market.

LEAD: President Bush said in Texas last week that changes in the Soviet Union, and China, are ''profound. It will never go back to the way it was.'' This is true, and it is of great importance that it is recognized by America's leader because it highlights a whole new era confronting the U.S.
LEAD: We would like to clarify the purpose of our lawsuit, as it was inaccurately described in the article [ ''Lab Use of Animals Puts Issue Into Court,'' Feb. 26 ] .

LEAD: Sara Elizabeth Johns, a daughter of Dr. Margaret A. Johns of Mountainville, N.Y., and D. Craig Johns of New York and Pawling, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Gaines Griffen, a son of Dorothy Griffen of Hudson, N.Y., and the late Charles R. Griffen. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alan Macy, a Congregational minister, at the United Church of Christ in Lenox,

LEAD: IN the jury of journalistic opinion, from New York's Newsweek to London's Economist to Moscow's Znamya, the verdict on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's perestroika these days is that it has failed. Looking at the shambles of Soviet industry and the paucity in stores, few Soviet watchers would consider this an eccentric judgment.

LEAD: For many busy men, exercise has become a little too much like work: getting up early, putting on the required clothes, traveling at least some distance, toiling alongside hordes of others and then returning home - exhausted.

LEAD: RESIDENTS of Kabul had little trouble waking last week. Shortly before dawn on most mornings, a noise like a giant thud echoed across the Afghan capital, followed by a roar that rapidly faded away. The sound would be repeated before quiet returned, and then on sporadic occasions later in the day.

LEAD: A FEW years ago, Chamber Music Plus, which is in its ninth season at the Old State House in Hartford, decided to expand its operations. It is now presenting some fascinating recitals at three other locations.
LEAD: We have just moved to the juncture fo Westchester County and Putnam County.
LEAD: The mummy of an aristocratic young woman, her smile frozen in a plaster death mask, has been unearthed in a shallow pit at the foot of the Great Pyramid of Cheops.
LEAD: DAUGHTER OF DESTINY An Autobiography. By Benazir Bhutto. Illustrated. 412 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.
LEAD: SOUNDINGS
LEAD: The Government and the country's most feared guerrilla group have signed an accord to begin talks toward ending nearly two decades of insurgency.
LEAD: When Merce Cunningham touched his forehead during a curtain call at the end of his dance company's City Center season last Sunday, this vague salute was interpreted by some as a farewell.

LEAD: WHILE driving home from work the other night on the Merritt Parkway, I was passed by a sleek red sports car. I caught a glimpse of the driver's bumper sticker as she went by: ''Women run for office, not coffee.'' My sentiments exactly.
