LEAD: Skiing Plans

LEAD: It should have been easy to predict a few decades ago, when American symphony orchestras and opera companies first began to rattle their tin cups and plead for government aid, that majority taste would eventually affect and probably erode their artistic independence. Why not? The prime business of a democratic government is to discover what most people want and try to please them.

LEAD: Every man and woman who has ever dated knows that the process is not simple. If it's a blind date, a first date or one of the first dates, it boils down to a game of chance. The other person may be pleasant and presentable, but that's no guarantee of anything. Thousands of pleasant, presentable people are boring, pedestrian and erased from the mind as quickly as they disappear from view.

LEAD: Mookie Blaylock scored 34 points and Stacey King had 21 with 15 rebounds today as fourth-ranked Oklahoma beat Louisiana Tech, 124-81, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. Southeast Regional. The top-seeded Sooners (30-5) showed a spark that had been missing for several games as they advanced to the regional semifinals for the third straight year.

LEAD: Until the LP arrived, most Wagnerites knew his work only in discontinuous form, either from the chunks served up at orchestral concerts or in drastically condensed versions available on bulky 78-r.p.m. disks. These fragmented performances were often pieced together from a bewildering variety of sources.

LEAD: THE black flies were swarming, looking for a landing spot. One went humming into my ear, another burrowed under an eyelid. Several flew up my nose, and when I opened my mouth, five or six dived down my throat, causing me to choke and sputter.

LEAD: Beginning about a decade ago, a younger generation of Jews decided that there was no reason why they had to be masochistic to be observant when it came to the High Holy Days. Many of them ba'alei teschuva (returnees to the faith), they were also sophisticated in matters of food and drink. They refused to accept the viscous, sweet sacramental wine of their elders and demanded something better, or at least something more in tune with their modern tastes.

LEAD: An official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters threatened today to stage a sympathy strike at the Pan Am Corporation to support Eastern Airlines workers as they began their third week on strike.

LEAD: THE construction of 75 new town houses as the first phase of a development called Salters Square in the East Crotona Park section of the South Bronx is driving home some lessons about residential building in New York City.

LEAD: A DRAWBACK to suburban condominium living, in contrast to owning a one-family house with a backyard, is the limited opportunity for gardening. Those who seem to feel the loss most, managers report, are older people who have spent a lifetime tending a favorite plot at a former home.

LEAD: SAUL BELLOW'S Herzog, on the verge of a nervous breakdown, decides there's only one thing to do: head for the men's shops on Madison Avenue. ''Therefore, he went shopping for clothes.'' When I first encountered this passage, it scarcely registered. It was the 1960's, and I was in college. No one cared about clothes.

LEAD: Chappaqua, N.Y. $615,000 280 Hamilton Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, greenhouse, pool, 1.27 acres; taxes $8,886. New Rochelle, N.Y. $1.8 million Central Drive 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; maid's suite, fireplace, sauna, atrium, playroom, pool, water access and mooring; taxes $16,967.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: HOOKED By Pauline Kael. 510 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $14.95.
LEAD: Lois Margaret Brenner, a lawyer, and Robert Stein, a retired magazine executive, collaborators on a book about divorce, plan to be married in May.

LEAD: FOR Americans who have not recently seen Versailles, this is the ideal year for a return visit, both because of celebrations marking the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution and the recent conclusion of a five-year, $70-million restoration.
LEAD: I SERVED THE KING OF ENGLAND By Bohumil Hrabal. Translated by Paul Wilson. 243 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.
LEAD: Alan Chow
LEAD: Three weeks ago the Emerald City filled a hangar at Van Nuys Airport in southern California, and there were Munchkins everywhere.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-19
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: His program is under the cloud of a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation, and although he has not been personally accused of wrongdoing, Eddie Sutton appears to be on his way out as the Kentucky basketball coach.

LEAD: For This Week: Daffodils, tulips and other spring-flowering bulbs are pushing up; apply fertilizer now so it is available to bulbs in summer when they will form flowers for spring, 1990. Transplant seedlings to a one-one-one soil mixture. Use rakes to clean up lawns and remove winter debris; add to compost pile.

LEAD: HOPES for peace and democracy in Central America are built on a series of agreements named for the obscure towns where they were signed. The effectiveness of these accords has been questioned, particularly by United States conservatives who contend that the more recent ones omit some guarantees found in the earlier pacts.

LEAD: The immigration law calls for sanctions against those who employ illegal aliens, but Federal officials have checked only 0.2 percent of the nation's employers for compliance, says a study made available today.

LEAD: The sob sisters are at it again, this time bewailing the alleged bias or fatuousness of Scholastic Aptitude Test exams (''S.A.T. Exams: One Size Doesn't Fit All,'' March 5.) For the crybaby, naive, nonastute individuals, let it be known that there are no college admission officers who solely look at S.A.T.

LEAD: I am sorry that Richard Taylor cared so little about teaching. He should not, however, use his own laziness in the classroom to impugn the hard work, dedication and commitment of other university professors. Perhaps Professor Taylor (and his students) would have been better off if he had stayed in that ''other warm place.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Reid of Flossmoor, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christina Marie Reid to Michael Wyatt Dickerson, a son of C. Wyatt Dickerson and Nancy Dickerson, both of Washington. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: An article on page 10 of the Travel section today, about New Delhi, gives an incorrect telephone number for the Diplomat Hotel in some copies; the number should be 301-0204. The article also misstates the price of a book, ''Old Delhi: 10 Easy Walks''; it costs $5.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 2 2 3 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie.

LEAD: Stream of consciousness is always a tricky business in the theater. Shakespeare was a master, and the Greeks employed choruses to similar effect. Sam Shepard and Lanford Wilson are among the modern playwrights who can seamlessly weave asides to the audience into their dramas.
LEAD: This letter is in response to the well-written Feb. 5 article ''Woman's Fight Against Navy Radar Raises Health Issue.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In the last two years, a secondary market has emerged for public limited partnerships in everything from real estate to oil drilling to computer equipment.
LEAD: If you think the British Parliament has been preoccupied recently with the state of the economy, or by the investigation into the Lockerbie air disaster, you have been misinformed.

LEAD: WHAT is the public supposed to think? Last month, the Environmental Protection Agency identified Alar, a chemical used to make apples redder and crisper, as a carcinogen and said that it should be banned - though not until 1990. The E.P.A.'s Acting Deputy Administrator, John Moore, told a Senate subcommittee that if the substance had just been invented, the agency would not allow it to be sold.

LEAD: So much of a stamp's design seems predictable - the name of the country, the denomination, ''postage,'' ''par avion.'' A casual glance fails to note the extraordinary skills required to produce what are often miniature masterpieces.

LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding first-class air fares: I bought a round-trip ticket to San Francisco, coach fare, for $284. I had asked for a business-class fare and was told there was none from San Antonio to San Francisco. First class would have been about $1,300 at that time, but now I understand that if space is available you can get a ''coach upgrade'' to first class for $860.
LEAD: GEORGE KLEIN was supposed to be a Manhattan pioneer, opening Midtown West to bankers, lawyers and other white-collar professionals by erecting four huge office towers near Times Square.

LEAD: WHAT are the ingredients that assure a restaurant's success? If there were a textbook answer to that question, every entrepreneur opening an eating establishment would be guaranteed a quick return on the investment.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is considering a formal break in relations with the Soviet-backed Afghan Government, but is not ready to recognize the rebel government in exile, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The Jewish Museum is presenting, through April 2, an exhibition called ''Golem! Danger, Deliverance and Art,'' in which artistic and popular-culture responses to the ancient golem legend are brought together. A golem is a clay man brought to life through mystical incantation. Created as a protector, it grows independent of its maker and is destroyed.

LEAD: For Anne Iobst and Lucy Sexton, it was just an ordinary evening at home. They blew the fuses while doing housework, threw an ironing board at each other and dueled with scrub brushes. Offstage antagonists pelted them with vegetables. Ms. Iobst drank from a fishbowl. An amorous lion dropped by. So did mechanical toy bears.

LEAD: In the hotly competitive world of big-time college football, Notre Dame has always remained aloof from the controversial practice known as redshirting, extending selected players' careers by sidelining them during one of their first four seasons so they can play a fifth season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Christopher Whittle says he prefers to do things quietly, the way so many of his 42 projects have come into the world. His GO! Girls Only! magazine, his Dental Health Advisor, his Pet Care Report, his Funnies wall poster have all sneaked up on people so quietly that years later many individuals still don't know they exist.

LEAD: Running from jammed airport terminals to leg-numbing flights, from cramped cabs to crowded conferences, can put a wrinkle in any man's schedule - not to mention his clothes. In addition to the heat, haze and humidity of summer, basic business wear is to blame: A man in a dress shirt and tie has at least a dozen layers of cloth bound snugly around his neck.

LEAD: Imagine the freedom of suddenly being able to write what you think - after years of censorship, of suddenly being able to say the things you want to say instead of only the things the authorities will let you say - and you will have some idea of both the excitement and the difficulty of being a writer in the Soviet Union today.
LEAD: Humankind has suddenly entered into a brand new relationship with our planet.
LEAD: Sometimes called ''the poor man's salmon,'' American shad will begin arriving in the rivers of the Northeast by mid-April.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Ebbitt of Bronxville, N.Y., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Martha Elizabeth Mitchell of Washington to Paul James Savidge of Silver Spring, Md. Mr. Savidge is a son of Robert J. Savidge of Wayne, Pa., and the late Dolores T. Savidge. The Ebbitts are the future bride's godparents.

LEAD: IN an immersion tank at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center on Brigantine Boulevard here, a weary harbor seal bobbed and turned as concerned volunteers monitored its progress. Whether it would live or die would depend on the animal's inherent strength, said Robert Schoelkopf, the center's director and founder.

LEAD: The magic left months ago, the confidence evaporated shortly thereafter and a steady stream of players vanished for varying periods due to injuries in the ensuing weeks. With all that disappearing for the Rangers, it is hardly surprising that a chance at first place in the Patrick Division is fading fast as well.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: One of the things that student volunteers at ''Ye Olde Safer Sex Shoppe'' at Stanford University want to prove is that ''not all condoms are created equal.''

LEAD: She may never be a household name, but Julie Croteau made a bit of baseball history last week. In a Division III game against the Spring Garden College Bobcats, Croteau, who plays for St. Mary's College of Maryland, became the first woman to play in a National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball game.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: J. R. Reid, North Carolina's leading scorer, was suspended today for his team's second-round Southeast Regional game Sunday against U.C.L.A. for violating curfew Friday night.

LEAD: ONCE again, the familiar strains of Faure's ''Palms,'' Handel's ''Messiah,'' and the medieval lilt of plainsong will enrich church services throughout the state, as people gather to mourn the death of Jesus and celebrate the Resurrection.

LEAD: A former mental patient shot and killed a 10-year-old girl and critically wounded two other children here this afternoon, before being killed in a gun battle with a police officer, authorities said. The officer was also wounded, but not critically.

LEAD: To the athletes dressed in Princeton black and orange who find themselves somewhere between adolescence and middle age, the coach with the cigar in his mouth must seem as if he has been passing on the same principles since basketballs were directed into peach baskets.

LEAD: Louis A. Landa, professor emeritus of English at Princeton University, died of kidney and heart failure Friday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 87 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the Fare of the Country (Travel, Feb. 5), Austria's favorite Wurstel is likely these days to be loaded with MSG, which the Viennese seldom label as glutamate but rather as Geschmackverstarker or taste strengthener. Those allergic to this chemical should avoid the street stalls; when buying at groceries, check the product's ingredients.

LEAD: Assuming fair weather and enough spring fever, scores of people will gather tomorrow morning in the plaza at the World Trade Center in Manhattan. At 10:29, the moment of the vernal equinox, they will attempt to stand eggs on end. Many will succeed, in a small triumph of folklore over common sense, if not science.
LEAD: A LITTLE-NOTICED clause in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget message threatens to dismantle most youth programs in the county, officials of Westchester youth agencies warned last week.
LEAD: The Mets were involved in three scuffles this afternoon and not even one of them was among themselves.

LEAD: IT is 10 o'clock and Andrea has the first appointment of the day. We're on time but it's a miracle we got here at all. When I first suggested that she have her hair cut, Andrea said ''No'' very definitely, the same way she says ''No dresses'' whenever we go out for a special occasion. ''Jogging pants and a polo, just like Evan,'' is the usual response.

LEAD: With a deadline less than a month away, a New York State utility official said Friday that the Public Service Commission is likely to approve rate increases that will lead to adoption of a plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: People with mental and physical disabilities have come a long way since the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which requires the Government and institutions receiving Federal funds to make reasonable efforts to employ the handicapped.

LEAD: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that the Jordanian Government was ultimately responsible for an ambush Friday night by guerrillas who slipped across the border and killed an Israeli soldier before escaping back to Jordan.
LEAD: Margo Tress Garcia and Jay Vigoreaux were married yesterday in Rio Piedras, P.R. The Rev. Donald Vega performed the ceremony at San Ignacio Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Steven Meisel defines his style of photography as ''a little bit outrageous, a little bit crazy or sick - when I'm allowed to do what I want.'' But his work hasn't been too outrageous for Clairol, the Gap, Barneys New York, Vogue or Vanity Fair. And Marc Jacobs, the new designer for Perry Ellis, says Mr.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Four Democratic Senators have asserted that a group representing sellers of imported cars is a foreign agent, and they have asked the Justice Department to investigate it.

LEAD: In New York in the last few months, a developer who paid a $2 million fine for illegally tearing down some single-room occupancy hotels in the middle of the night is now erecting a skyscraper hotel on the same site, and naming it after himself. Another developer put up an apartment building with 12 more floors than the zoning allowed, and has been trying to work out a deal to avoid tearing down the illegal stories, which contain 24 apartments that could sell for more than $500,000 each.

LEAD: Two weeks after 13-year-old Kelly Tinyes was found stabbed and strangled in a neighbor's basement here, investigators said they would present evidence to a Nassau County grand jury on Wednesday and seek a murder indictment.

LEAD: Chris Tancill snapped a 2-2 tie at 6 minutes 12 seconds of the third period tonight, leading Wisconsin to a 4-2 victory over St. Lawrence and eliminating the Saints from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I playoffs.

LEAD: Plans for an April 29 wedding for Diane Tekakwitha von Gal and Brian Joseph Woods have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Vreeland von Gal of Stamford, Conn. Mr. Woods is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Woods of Sussex, N.J. Ms. von Gal graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn., and Ithaca College.

LEAD: The broad acres surrounding E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's textile fiber plant in Kinston, N.C., used to be mowed religiously, leaving a lawn that was beautifully manicured but a biological desert for animals and plants.

LEAD: TIME WAS, a man's watch was just a timepiece: classical, understated and functional. Now watches tell a lot more than the time of day. They seem to offer a number of clues about the men who wear them, and serve, at the same time, as conspicuous status symbols. These days, more and more men concerned with quality as well as image are returning to the classic mechanical-movement watch of the past.

LEAD: A near-complete collection of brilliant proof trade dollars is at auction in Sotheby's sale of the Harry Warshaw Collection of United States coins on Tuesday. The trade dollar is an exotic coin evoking the long-lost days of the China trade. The Warshaw pieces are in beautiful condition.

LEAD: Janet Malcolm, a writer who has skillfully explored many worlds, has a talent for the socko start. Hear the way she begins a recent two-part article in The New Yorker about a lawsuit brought by Jeffrey MacDonald, a convicted murderer, against Joe McGinniss, who wrote a best seller, ''Fatal Vision,'' about him:

Years ago, several professors of English at Harvard taught me to pronounce the title of Emily Bronte's novel as Mr.

LEAD: Just in time for this transitional, between-seasons period, several of the more free-spirited designers have come up with new suits that have almost literally taken flight. Ungaro, for instance, has reinterpreted a romantic, 18th-century look, with dipping peplums, puffy sleeves and lavish lapels (near right).

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Schmults of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Creighton Schmults, to Cameron Horatio Burns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horatio Winspear Burns of Big Timber, Mont. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick populist whose election battle has become a referendum on the Soviet establishment, charged today that the Communist Party had used dirty tricks to obstruct his campaign and might try to falsify the election results.

LEAD: REFLECTING ON THINGS PAST: The Memoirs of Peter Lord Carrington. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $22.95.) Oh, to be an Englishman! Or rather, to write like one. Peter Lord Carrington is a man of his class and times - an aristocrat whose line began in the mid-17th century with one Thomas Smith of Nottingham, a draper who kept accounts for farmers.

LEAD: A man. A woman. A deserted rest area by the side of a highway, where the man and woman meet by chance. She (Catherine Deneuve) has been abandoned there by an abusive husband who has left her stranded, in her fur coat and fur hat and dark glasses, in the middle of the night. He (Gerard Depardieu) has already been there for a couple of days, trying to fix the engine of his car, an engine that -symbolically, no doubt - will not go.
LEAD: Two forest fires in southern New Jersey burned more than 4,000 acres of environmentally important Pinelands before being brought under control yesterday.

LEAD: You do not have to travel as far north as Vermont to watch maple syrup in the making. At Warrups Farm in Redding, Conn., about an hour-and-a-half drive from Manhattan, Bill Hill and his brother Bob welcome visitors to their sugarhouse on weekends.

LEAD: WE'RE going to burn the 30-year mortgage if the bank remembers to send it to us. We've been living in the briar patch for 30 years, and it seems more like 50.

LEAD: Fourth-seeded Louisville, which narrowly survived a lethargic performance Thursday, rebounded nicely this afternoon and shook off pesky Arkansas, 93-84, to advance to the Midwest Regional semifinals.

LEAD: ONE WANTS TO CALL IT A TEMpest in a very large teapot. Or maybe a controlled weather experiment. What it is, basically, is a 17-foot-high artificial tornado - a sculpture, of sorts, that will be publicly on display beginning next Saturday at the New York Hall of Science, one of the remaining buildings from the 1964 World's Fair in Flushing, Queens.

LEAD: In his new book, ''His Eminence and Hizzoner,'' written with John Cardinal O'Connor, Mayor Edward I. Koch wrote that though his opponents over the years had spread reports that he was a homosexual he had adopted a policy of not responding to inquiries on the matter. Last week, on a radio call-in program, Mr.

LEAD: Oliver North was sitting at a defense table in the Federal District courthouse, writing notes on a yellow legal pad and fixing unsympathetic witnesses with a blue laser gaze. He seemed smaller and slighter than he did when he first burst on the national scene during the Iran-contra Congressional hearings, his dashing aura dimmed by nondescript suits and the drone of the trial.
LEAD: MOSCOW STATION How the KGB Penetrated the American Embassy. By Ronald Kessler. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

LEAD: The imagery of copticart - owl-eyed women, plump birds, exotic beasts, pagan mythological figures and Christian symbols - comes alive in highly expressive tapestries, artifacts and stone sculpture produced in Egypt under the Romans and Byzantines. Long overlooked by scholars and museum curators, this early Christian material is now the subject of an ambitious exhibition here at the Rhode Island School of Design's Museum of Art through
LEAD: Party at the Plaza

LEAD: A special point of interest in the performance of Bach's ''Johannespassion'' at St. Thomas Church Tuesday night was the inclusion of five numbers added to the work in 1725, two years after its first performance. They have been made easily available to performers within the past decade by their appearance as an appendix to the Barenreiter edition of the score, but have not been generally adopted; this listener had never heard them in a performance of the complete ''Passion.

LEAD: Last Thursday, Izhar Patkin left for Europe to make arrangements for showing the ambitious sculpture he has just completed - a life-size anodized aluminum piece entitled ''Don Quijote Segunda Parte'' that stands in his living room on the Lower East Side.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Cohen of New York and Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Lynn Cohen, to Robert Alan Cohen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Cohen of Roslyn, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Cohen, president of Irene Cohen Personnel Inc. in New York, graduated from the Rochester Institute of Technology.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The symbolism did not escape Forrest Gregg. The 55-year-old craggy-faced Texan, who still has a twang after all those years playing and coaching pro football in the Midwest, leaned back in his chair in the temporary coach's office in a trailer outside Ownby Stadium and listened to the sounds outside.

LEAD: Laura Chamberlain, an Assistant New York City Corporation Counsel, and Mark Stein, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, were married last evening in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El. Elissa Stein Cushman, the bride's sister-in-law, was her matron of honor, and Kathleen Durkin was maid of honor.
LEAD: IF avoiding conflict of interest has become a Washington rite of passage, then Lawrence S. Eagleburger is the latest official to come of age.

LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

LEAD: ''Niedecker,'' Kristine Thatcher's earnest low-key drama celebrating the life and work of the late poet Lorine Niedecker, contemplates the artist with such intense reverence that its subject emerges an almost saintly symbol of integrity, simplicity and devotion.

LEAD: The Dartmouth fraternity system was once so zany that it became the model for the 1978 movie ''Animal House.'' But that system is about to change. Indeed, the Greek Rush now taking place at Dartmouth will be the last of its kind here.

LEAD: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space.

LEAD: The National Football League's newest coach, Jimmy Johnson, who is taking over the Dallas Cowboys, is not one to rush into a decision. So with more than a month to go before the N.F.L. draft April 23, Johnson, who has the first pick, still hasn't announced his choice.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The 1950'S and abstract expressionism, the heroic painting style that put American art on the map, are ever with us. Anyone with a passing interest in contemporary art can recite the great names of that bygone yet omnipresent era when Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman and others arrived.
LEAD: THE ad read ''Grand Opening of Homer's East.'' Was Homer Lee opening a third Chinese restaurant in the Woodbury Common? No. It's the original Homer's with a face lift.

LEAD: Missing a golf ball completely is the most ineffective stroke in golf. Mark McCumber, whose ball was one inch from the 17th hole today, may have come up with the second most ineffective shot when he stroked the ball and it did not reach the cup.

LEAD: It would hardly be an exaggeration to describe American culture in the late 1980's as art in the era of AIDS. Art has confronted AIDS the way people confront AIDS - with fear, anger, sorrow, defiance and confusion. In a country that idolizes youth and health, AIDS has struck at the very heart of the American self-image.
LEAD: The problem of affordable housing is much studied, but there are now some groups and individuals who are actually doing something about it.
LEAD: The oldest clinic in New York City will close in May, and its Greenwich Village site will become a nursing home for AIDS patients.

LEAD: Another sign that Manhattan's diamond district is breaking out of its traditional location and growing eastward across Fifth Avenue is the new character being given an office building at the southeast corner of Fifth and 48th Street. Renovations to make it suitable for jewelry companies and purchase of the building are costing the new owners $50 million.
LEAD: ''That's one to be proud of. It's a great way to start the '89 schedule.'' - Frank Culbertson, mission controller, as Discovery touched down. [ 29:1. ]

LEAD: CURRENTLY, the art at Art at 100 Pearl Street is by African-Americans. It is an awkward way of introducing an exhibition, but then Art at 100 Pearl is both the name and the address of the branch recently opened in Hartford by the Connecticut Gallery of Marlborough. Besides, the show itself is awkward, for it spans the last 100 or so years, yet numbers only 26 painters and sculptors and, hence, is less a survey of the black contribution to
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It might have been called ''dry week,'' but life at Amherst College was as wet as usual last weekend.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The Northern Ireland that James LeMoyne imagines as an analogue to El Salvador sounds like a dreadful place indeed: ''a permanent running sore, congenitally incapable of fully healing or being cured, short of the most radical measures.'' Fortunately, the real Northern Ireland bears no resemblance to Mr.
LEAD: In 1984, my 11-year-old son was hired as an extra for a wedding scene in ''Prizzi's Honor.'' I remember thinking how strikingly beautiful Anjelica Huston was (''Anjelica Rising,'' Feb. 12).

LEAD: Closings in the week ending March 4 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $410,000 30 Fifth Avenue (10th St.) 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, high ceilings, parquet floors; maintenance $742, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti)

LEAD: Perhaps Edith L. Ellenbogen [ Letters, March 5 ] did not read the article by Geraldine M. Fox (''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29), for which I wrote a comment. The idea seems to be that networks are using abuse victims as drawing cards. Talk shows use the tragedy of abuse as a form of entertainment. Anyone who is unaware of this terrible suffering would have to be living in a cave.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: President Bush is developing a highly engaged management style that is being praised in Washington as a healthy departure from the detached style of the Reagan years.
LEAD: ONE who has grown accustomed to the Boston Post Road Stage Company's adventuresomeness might well be startled by the ordinariness of its current production, ''Educating Rita.''

LEAD: Re: ''A Theory of Scientific Atheism'' (New Jersey Q & A, Feb. 5): John Koster's book, ''The Atheist Syndrome,'' is but another illustration of what has come to be called the ''psychologizing'' of social phenomena.

LEAD: THE five-year-old agreements that limit steel imports from 29 countries into the United States were once hailed by many in the industry as necessary for the revival of the American steel industry. Now segments of the industry are deeply divided over whether the import quotas, which expire this year, are still needed.

LEAD: Six years ago, when they first met as teammates for New York's Riverside Hawks in the church league, John Morton and Gerald Greene were high school juniors with a penchant for playing fancy and footloose basketball.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ray Dietz Madoff and David Andrew Nicholas, who received law degrees from New York University in 1984, were married last evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. Carl Perkins, a rabbinical student, officiated.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A CLOUD of uncertainty is hanging over the horse business on Long Island as changing conditions prompt many owners of horse farms to reassess their investments.
LEAD: Ken Dayley was a popular person this winter.

LEAD: This was not ''Sunday in the Park With George.'' Rather, it was Wednesday in the park with Giorgio and the rest of the dogs. It was a great, sweaty revel of dogs running free after dark in Central Park, of dog owners cheering them on, whistling, tossing out balls and generally behaving like country people.

LEAD: Technology enables physically impaired people to hold jobs they otherwise could not. A computer equipped with an electronic voice will read back letters typed in by a visually impaired person for accuracy. Similarly, some computers will articulate words identified on the screen, enabling people with speech difficiencies to communicate.

LEAD: Christ the King, the nation's third-ranked team and the state's top-ranked team, won the New York State Federation Class A championship tonight with an 80-57 victory over Adlai Stevenson of the Bronx, the New York City Public Schools Athletic League champion.
LEAD: The hallmark of a great combination is its embodiment of fantasy, of what appears at first sight unreal, uncanny or some kind of magician's trick.

LEAD: A June 24 wedding is planned by Grace Natalie Kooper, the daughter of Justice Sybil Hart Kooper of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and David Dean Johnson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton L. Johnson of Tacoma, Wash.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, a United Methodist sanctuary and an official New York City landmark, is falling apart. On that, there is no argument.

LEAD: It happens every year as a few overlooked or lightly regarded teams from college basketball's boondocks are thrust into the spotlight during the national tournament. The coaches are usually self-deprecating, the players just happy to be here, while opponents build them up as giant killers capable of making the Final Four.

LEAD: As an experienced journalist, James LeMoyne knows his craft and the country he covered. That's why it is puzzling that his assessment of El Salvador (''The Guns of Salvador,'' Feb. 5) was so pessimistic. He must know that important gains have been made in that troubled Central American country.

LEAD: Terre Blair, an independent television producer in New York, and Marvin Hamlisch, the composer and musician, plan to be married in May. The future bride is a daughter of Marie M. Blair of Columbus, Ohio, and Dr. William D. Blair of Circleville, Ohio. Mr. Hamlisch is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs.
LEAD: Israel and Egypt are not celebrating their 10 years without war.

LEAD: ONCE again the familiar strains of Faure's ''Palms,'' Handel's ''Messiah'' and the medieval lilt of plainsong enrich church services countywide, as people gather to mourn the death of Christ and celebrate his Resurrection.
LEAD: BECAUSE I am black, throughout my life I have expected acceptance in any black neighborhood I chose to roam.

LEAD: TODAY, Christians observe Palm Sunday, and many will carry palm branches to commemorate the day that crowds greeted Jesus with palm branches as He rode into Jerusalem. In the coming week, florists' shops will fill with spring flowers - hyacinths and daffodils - considered especially appropriate for Easter time.
LEAD: China's legislature will begin its annual session on Monday for a dose of what passes here for democracy. Officials already are bracing themselves.

LEAD: The Apocalypse of St. John, or Book of Revelation, is a most dramatic book, filled with fiery beings, battles in Heaven, Lucifer plunging into hell, the four ravaging horsemen, the destruction of the world at Armageddon and the creation of a new universe. Among other books of the Bible the nearest competitor is probably the Book of Daniel.
LEAD: NOT since the Prague Spring of 1968 has a movement to end total Communist control of an East bloc nation gained such momentum.
LEAD: A journalist who calls attention to an environmental hazard educates the public. One who educates without evidence about such a hazard merely spreads rumors.

LEAD: Joan L. Ponvert of Locust Valley, L.I., and Warren N. Ponvert of Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Jennings Ponvert, to Peter Griswold Judge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy G. Judge of New York and Roxbury, Conn. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: TOMORROW'S CATHOLICS, YESTERDAY'S CHURCH The Two Cultures of American Catholicism. By Eugene Kennedy. 208 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95. TENSIONS IN MORAL THEOLOGY By Charles E. Curran. 214 pp. Indiana: University of Notre Dame Press. $19.95. THE RESHAPING OF CATHOLICISM Current Challenges in the Theology of Church.
LEAD: THE Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, 22 years in the building, now appears to face at least five years in the unmaking, and maybe much more.

LEAD: Almost like a puppy pulling at one's trouser leg, ''Cradle Song,'' a new musical that opened for a limited run Wednesday night at the Theater at Saint Peter's Church, is doing its best to be liked. It is an unabashedly sentimental story about a modern young upwardly mobile couple and how they discovered, the hard way, what the best things in life really are.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Searchers who followed directions given by Ted Bundy before his execution found bones and the tattered remnants of a blouse Friday near a site where the multiple murderer said he buried a 17-year-old girl in 1974.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Eduardo Almeyda of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Ann Almeyda, a plastic surgeon, to Dr. George Vincent DiGiacinto, a neurosurgeon. The couple plan to wed May 7. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert DiGiacinto of Yonkers.

LEAD: A 23-year-old research project on the genetic structure of anthrax has suddenly come under fire by a newly formed coalition of Quakers, local critics and doctors who assert that the research is intended for use in germ warfare.

LEAD: THE WOODWITCH. By Stephen Gregory. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The fungus among us in the British writer Stephen Gregory's second novel is a slimy, smelly, grotesquely phallic bottom-grower called a stinkhorn. It becomes an object of obsession for Andrew Pinkney, an English solicitor's clerk who has clobbered his girlfriend because she laughed at his impotence.

LEAD: The marriage of Kathryn Mary Cruze to Charles Antoine Dietzgen took place yesterday at The Creek country club in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about the Fifth Annual New York Flower Show misidentified the display shown. It was produced by Larchmont (N.Y.) Nurseries Inc., not by China.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Alain Chevrier's return to Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the first time since being traded by the Devils last summer was, in his words, ''very satisfying.''

LEAD: It is professors like Richard Taylor (Letters, Feb. 19, in response to ''Higher Education - The Real Crisis,'' by Michael I. Sovern, Jan. 22), who teach no more than five hours a week, never prepare their classes and have all papers read by graduate students, who have caused the enormous workload under which the rest of us labor.

LEAD: A chart on March 5 headed ''What the Dollar Will Buy in 16 Cities Around the World'' converted two Lisbon costs into United States dollars incorrectly. A two-mile taxi ride is $1.67, a cup of coffee 46 cents.

LEAD: SEVEN enticements fill this afternoon's schedule, including the return of Music for a Sunday Afternoon to Tarrytown's Christ Episcopal Church. This follows a brief hiatus during which, according to the artistic director, Dorothy Beach, ''We lost one piano, but finally found another.''

LEAD: With its white tile floors, dark wood paneling and neon beer signs, Dalt's on Roswell Road in affluent North Atlanta has the look of dozens of the hip theme bars and eateries that began appearing back in the era when people could use the term ''swinging single'' with a straight face.

LEAD: T. Coraghessan Boyle is exactly who he appears to be, but at age 40, he's a pretty complex package. He'll tell you everything about himself, but first just look at him - 6 feet 3 inches tall and built like a pencil. Relaxing at home, he wears a black leather jacket over a black T-shirt with a school of fish painted on it, and baggy, pleated gray pants.

LEAD: New York State has threatened to suspend $4.5 million in payments to Suffolk County if county lawmakers do not reverse their decision this week to reject the appointment of a new Suffolk commissioner of social services.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Childress Beck of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Harpswell, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanne Boulton Beck, to George Willing Pepper, the son of Mrs. Don Hamlin McLucas Jr. of Washington and Charles Willing Pepper of Palm Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: CITIZENS A Chronicle of the French Revolution. By Simon Schama. Illustrated. 948 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.
LEAD: Alan V. Davies, president of the J. Clarence Davies real-estate concern in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Many owners of Keogh plans are facing a double tax deadline this year. Like everyone else, they must file their regular income tax returns by April 17. But if their Keoghs are considered ''frozen,'' they may also be facing a May 31 deadline to determine the future status of their plans. A failure to act could set off stiff tax liabilities.

LEAD: The gun museum on the ground floor of the National Rifle Association's headquarters here is very calm, or as calm as any place can be that features displays of double-barrel shotguns, bolt-action rifles, toggle-breach semiautomatics, Smith & Wesson .44 magnums, pocket Derringers, British muskets, Japanese ceremonial guns, Bowie knives, powder horns, boar and lion heads and a prize photograph of a woman with a large snake around her neck.

LEAD: In a recent speech, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady outlined a new plan for third world debt relief. It calls for additional lending as well as increased use of debt-for-equity swaps. It also advocates converting some of the $280 billion that debtor countries owe to private banks into low-interest bonds.

LEAD: Susan Kent Jansen and Franklin Janen Chu were married yesterday by the Rev. Frank A. Goodwin at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. William Allan Jansen of Bronxville and the late Mr. Jansen. Mr. Chu is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robin Hsin-Liu Chu of New York.

LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of people demonstrated in the streets of the Basque city of Bilbao today in a peace march that organizers and local politicians hailed as a turning point in the region's troubled recent history.

LEAD: NED EUSTACE found it difficult to tell his story. Three weeks before, he had come home from school to find his housekeeper of 10 years unconscious on the floor. No one else was home and although Ned summoned help, the housekeeper died of a heart attack.

LEAD: Pennsylvania State University's Board of Trustees yesterday approved plans to add nearly 10,000 seats to Beaver Stadium and $2 to the price of football tickets for the Nittany Lions' games. ''The unparalleled success of the Penn State football program has taxed the capacity of Beaver Stadium beyond its current limits,'' said Jim

LEAD: Despite a glut of commercial space in the New York metropolitan area, another office building is being built in White Plains, which has one of the lowest vacancy rates in this area. Louis Cappelli, a partner in the Cappelli Development Corporation of Valhalla, N.Y., which is undertaking the $23 million project, said ''construction of office projects in White Plains has been synchronized with demand, which has reduced the haphazard overbuilding that has led to the series of booms and busts in office space in other areas.

LEAD: Jennifer Drew, a third-year law student at Fordham University, and George Mayer Stone, a partner in the real-estate investment firm of Solico in New York and Williamstown, Mass., were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion and Cantor David Benedict officiated. Mrs.

LEAD: The diplomatic air in London is full of hopeful talk about South Africa: talk of change and negotiation and peace. Prime Minister Thatcher gave voice to the sense of possibility in the House of Commons last week. She was ''optimistic,'' she said, that ''before very long'' the South African Government would release Nelson

LEAD: Bonnie Raitt starts her new album, ''Nick of Time'' (Capitol 91268; LP, cassette and CD), with quiet, plain-spoken, telling words. In the title song, to a subdued drumbeat that ticks like a biological clock, she sings about a friend who: Sees babies everywhere she goes And she wants one of her own She's waited long enough, she says And still he can't decide Pretty soon she'll have to choose And it tears her up inside She's scared Scared to run out of time.

LEAD: Young people in black leather and women in furs had their noses pressed against the window of the new Emporia Armani boutique on lower Fifth Avenue in Manhattan last Tuesday. It was past 10 A.M., the shop's scheduled opening time, but members of the sales staff, wearing navy blue Armani suits, were hanging the last jackets and getting their last-minute orders.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has moved quickly to establish himself in the Pentagon, choosing the first of his aides, meeting today with President Bush and calling top military officials to a hurried budget conference.
LEAD: The cause was books, so the Young Friends of the Library chose Ray Bradbury's futuristic story about book burning, ''Fahrenheit 451,'' as the theme for their first benefit.
LEAD: The subtle point of Richard Taylor's response to Michael Sovern's article, namely that university faculties do not merely teach but also engage in research, may have eluded some readers.

LEAD: THE CARIOCAS, AS THE NATIVES OF Rio de Janeiro are known, have marvellous qualities - an infectious joie de vivre, a refined sense of the ridiculous, the most sophisticated and beautiful popular music in the world - but the ability to handle money isn't one of them. So it came as no surprise to learn last fall that the city had declared bankruptcy.

LEAD: At the Yankees' spring training clubhouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Rickey Henderson tells reporters Yankee pitchers drink too much. Dave Righetti tells reporters Henderson should mind his own business. Don Mattingly tells reporters he thinks maybe Henderson has a point. Dave Winfield, seated at his locker, watches with a big mischevious grin as schools of reporters swim back and forth from Henderson's locker to
LEAD: Purim Potpourri

LEAD: Were it not for the general ebullience of the writing, the Lovejoy adventures by Jonathan Gash might be reading a little thin by now. There is a great deal of formula writing in this popular series. Usually the books start with Lovejoy broke and in trouble. They end with him still broke and in even more trouble.
LEAD: When personal style is the point, there's room in any man's wardrobe for new fashions - and old favorites. Brooke Alexander

LEAD: Companies are taking more aggressive steps to prevent workers from becoming disabled and to speed the recovery of those who do. And for a good reason. Claims for workers' compensation have skyrocketed, jumping 60 percent since 1983 to more than $26 billion last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Evans of Lake Como, Italy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Terence J. Horan at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Burlingame,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Wine aficionados in the United States are faced with a staggering embarrassment of riches. So many wines from around the world are available here one could spend a lifetime studying them. Two young New Yorkers who do that, and in the process set wine trends in New York City and far beyond, are Kevin Zraly, 38, wine director for Inhilco, which runs Windows on the World and 21 other restaurants in the World Trade Center, and Raymond Wellington, 35, wine director for the New York Restaurant Group, in Manhattan, which includes Smith & Wollensky, the Post House and the Manhattan Ocean

LEAD: LIKE runoff from the mountain snow pack, the cars begin to seep into the freeways as the morning sun rises over Southern California. Soon tiny creeks converge into rivers of moving steel, carrying workers from the remote inland reaches of the state to jobs in Los Angeles and Orange County.

LEAD: Eddie Chiles announced today that he had sold his majority share of the Texas Rangers to a group of Texas businessmen headed by George W. Bush, the President's son, for an estimated $46 million. The sale must gain the approval of American League owners, which is expected.

LEAD: GENE HACKMAN IS BEING PURSUED. A man has been haranguing him, calling on the phone, leaving letters in his apartment-house lobby. He wants Hackman as his ally, a comrade to help thwart a plot, something inscrutable about ''Hollywood borrowers.'' Hackman has been stalked before. There was the quick-draw artist with the loaded revolvers in Alamagordo, N.M.; the Las Vegas drunk brandishing a .357 magnum; the rifleman in Seattle who left his gun case at the cast's hotel, but this time, the interloper is unusually persistent.

LEAD: SHORT and long grain, polished white, natural brown, saffron yellow - Americans have become casual, even blase, about the variety of rice available at home and abroad. In Italy, however, Europe's major rice-producing country, it is still possible to find an unexpected choice: black rice.
LEAD: Winds gusting to coat-tugging force lifted topsoil from Darwin McCall's dried-up wheat field and hurled it against a truck window where it slipped off in thin, dark sheets.

LEAD: Bolstered by the West German record industry and record-buying public, we are steadily serviced with new recordings of German operas -familiar, quasi-familiar and downright unfamiliar. Far and away the most notable of the recent crop of such recordings is EMI's account of ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' (7 49074, three CD's), which counts as Richard
LEAD: BEFORE you build an income-producing structure, you must first buy or lease the property on which you intend to build. It sounds logical, but it's not always true.
LEAD: IN ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, the well-known Baker Street detective is examined from a new perspective.

LEAD: Doris Ruth Mack and Thomas Carhart Amory, both of Santa Barbara, Calif., were married there yesterday by Judge Thomas R. Adams of Santa Barbara County Superior Court at the home of William Cornfield. Lorraine D. Bieser, the bride's sister, and Edward A. Hansen were the witnesses.

LEAD: THE WORLD LOOKED on with amazed admiration in February 1986 when Corazon C. Aquino ousted Ferdinand E. Marcos as President of the Philippines. It was an episode almost too melodramatic to be true. A paragon of piety, Mrs. Aquino attributed her triumph to divine intervention. But American intervention helped as well.

LEAD: AT 7 A.M. on a recent day, a 70-year-old woman from Tarrytown walked into the ambulatory-surgery unit at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown. At 3 P.M. she walked out. LEAD: A jump in wholesale prices gave economists and the markets a shock. The wholesale report on Friday followed other statistics that seemed to offer hints that the economy might be cooling a bit and inflation pressures might ease.

LEAD: Jay Belsky gives the impression that the safest course of action in an accident is to remain in the car (About Men: ''Ordeal on 1-80,'' Feb. 19). There is something about a car on the shoulder that acts like a magnet to attract other cars.

LEAD: Kathryn Selby, an Australian-born pianist whose technical facility is well above average, gave a satisfying recital Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y. The distinguishing characteristic of her work in Mendelssohn, Schubert, Corigliano, Debussy, Chopin and Liszt was a security of finger control that allowed her to use the pedal very sparingly and to keep firm control over musical shape in fast movements at tempos that could easily have spilled over into skittering haste.

LEAD: Tony Brooks, a Notre Dame tailback who faces two misdemeanor charges in a hit-and-run accident last month, has left the university and returned to his home in Tulsa, Okla., college officials said. Brooks, 19 years old, withdrew voluntarily for personal reasons, said John Heisler, a spokesman for the athletic department.

LEAD: A Canadian insurance executive's volunteer work at an AIDS hospice last year gave him an idea for easing some of the worries of dying and destitute patients: give them access right away to some of the money that their life insurance policies would pay upon death.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's oft-reported sluggishness in assembling a team of senior officials has been noted by any number of Washington kibitzers, but one outsider with a real stake in the matter is taking it in stride. ''The White House - no problem; the Cabinet - more of a problem,'' says Roger Kranz, editor in chief of The Capital Source, a popular telephone directory of Capitol insiders published twice a year by the weekly magazine National Journal.
LEAD: * Kent DeFelice has been named executive vice president of DDB Needham, New York.
LEAD: When the Three Mile Island meltdown began on March 28, 1979, it was more than the breakdown of a nuclear reactor - it represented the failure of the entire system of nuclear regulation.
LEAD: A trader's assistant for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was convicted yesterday of lying to a Federal grand jury about her knowledge of potentially illegal trading activities at the firm.

LEAD: The Federal agency that enforces national gun laws will soon begin a survey to determine whether military-like semiautomatic rifles are used for target shooting and hunting.
LEAD: Westin Hotels and Resorts, a chain of 65 luxury hotels, yesterday named Chieko N. Aoki chief executive and deputy chairwoman.

LEAD: In a major step toward round-the-clock electronic trading of securities, Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and its Instinet subsidiary have joined with the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange to plan a network for trading options and stocks, they announced today.

LEAD: FINDING the perfect little restaurant can be tough; finding one with the perfect little wine list is even tougher. Face it: a small restaurant, almost by definition, has to have a relatively short wine list. A place with 30 tables simply can't afford to tie up capital by buying and holding large stocks of wine: it costs too much, there may not be any place to store it and there probably won't be enough guests to drink it.
LEAD: Houston to date has seemed more like a top-secret weapon than a race horse: rarely glimpsed, highly controversial, and developed under a virtual cloak of darkness.

LEAD: As the Solidarity union negotiates Poland's future with the Communist leadership, Solidarity's leaders find their ranks swelled by radical young workers and students who support the union but reject the talks with the Government.

LEAD: With the Blackhawks leading the Philadelphia Flyers by two goals after two periods in Chicago on Wednesday night, most of the Devils went to bed thinking that their game tonight against the Boston Bruins would be as significant as the seventh and deciding game in the Stanley Cup semifinals last season.

LEAD: Two hundred anti-abortion protesters, many waving pictures of aborted fetuses, were arrested today as they blockaded a suburban health clinic. The demonstration was the first in an Easter season offensive undertaken with the blessing of the head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles.
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday gave two states a day in court over a New York tax law that raises the levy on some New Jersey commuters.

LEAD: Nai Yuan Hu, the Taiwanese violinist who won the Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels in 1985, is to play Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 12, No. 3), Faure's Sonata in A (Op. 13) and Ysaye's ''Ballade'' Sonata tomorrow evening at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. The program also includes shorter works by Kreisler, Dohnanyi and Sarasate.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 461 money market mutual funds increased by $2.8 billion, to $299.4 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 139 institutional funds increased by $449.1 million, to $72.97 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $1.3 billion, to $97.42 billion.

LEAD: House Democratic leaders sent the Bush Administration some warning signals today, saying that bipartisan cooperation between Congress and the White House could be jeopardized if other Republicans are fanning partisan warfare.

LEAD: As Mark Jackson raced up and down the floor today during a 90-minute workout in the Miami Arena, the only sign that the Knick playmaker had undergone surgery to repair torn cartilage in his right knee was the blue knee pad he wore.

LEAD: The Con Brio Ensemble called its Tuesday evening program at Weill Recital Hall ''Vienna Retrospective 1888-1910.'' Those 22 years edged toward a time of ferment in the Viennese compositional world, and the changes wrought eventually affected the course of the Western musical tradition.

LEAD: Christopher Keene, who formally assumed the general directorship of the New York City Opera on March 15, has resigned as music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, the orchestra announced Wednesday. LEAD: Administration officials and Congressional leaders reached tentative agreement today on a bipartisan policy toward Central America, including additional aid for the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

LEAD: Drug manufacturers are warning doctors that commonly prescribed arthritis and pain-relieving drugs pose a serious risk of peptic ulcers, intestinal perforations and other gastrointestinal problems, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

LEAD: Ida Davidoff Martus, who coordinated a theater program for the New York City public schools, died of heart failure yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Philbert is notable for his tremendous appetite, his unflappably even keel, and his determination to find some kind of spiritual core in contemporary American Indian life.

LEAD: Kenny Anderson of Molloy High School in Queens and Lisa Harrison of Louisville Southern High in Kentucky have been selected as the Naismith basketball players of the year by the Atlanta Tipoff Club. They will receive their awards in Atlanta on April 21.

LEAD: Private exporters have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The sale increased to 8.2 million tons the wheat sold to China for delivery in 1988 or 1989.

LEAD: John Frankenheimer, the director of one of the wittiest conspiracy movies ever made, ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' is now responsible for one of the more trivial, ''Dead-Bang.'' The movie opened yesterday at the Loew's 84th Street and other theaters.

LEAD: Made on a shoestring - and a very small shoestring at that, the $15,000 budget recommended by Rick Schmidt in his book ''Feature Filmmaking at Used Car Prices'' - Mr. Schmidt's ''Morgan's Cake'' is a deadpan, unpretentious delight. The title character, played by the film maker's son, Morgan Schmidt-Feng, is no less comically out of sync with the world around him than the gorilla-suited David Warner character in the 1966 movie for which Morgan was named.

LEAD: Mid-America Productions is the creation of a former Louisiana music professor named Peter Tiboris. Since 1984, with gathering momentum, Mr. Tiboris has presented concerts in Carnegie Hall and Avery Fisher Hall featuring combined college, adult and high-school choruses. Originally they were accompanied by the American Symphony.

LEAD: Billy Griggs, an unrestricted free agent and for four seasons a backup tight end with the Jets, signed a two-year contract Thursday with the Kansas City Chiefs. He had been set to sign with Cleveland before receiving a call from the Chiefs. Griggs has caught 16 passes in his N.F.L. career.(AP)

LEAD: Joel B. Steinberg was sentenced to 8Y to 25 years in state prison yesterday in the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, the girl he helped raise. The penalty was the maximum he could have received, and the judge said he would recommend strongly against parole.

LEAD: An article yesterday about reaction on Staten Island to the United States Supreme Court decision invalidating the New York City Board of Estimate gave an incorrect location for the Fresh Kills landfill. It is on the island's west shore, not the south shore.

LEAD: When President Roh Tae Woo surprised South Korea and his own party this week by canceling a referendum on his first year in office, the country braced for more of the chaos and protests that have marked its uneasy transition to democracy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cityspire, a new 72-story residential building in midtown Manhattan, rises high because it uses air rights from the City Center building next door. But hold on; Cityspire rises even higher, 11 extra, illegal feet. No city official waived or seemed to waive the rules, leaving responsibility for non-conformance entirely on the developer.

LEAD: Harry Schnell, a retired surveyor whose projects included Lincoln Center and Madison Square Garden, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 85 years old and lived in Forest Hills.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government denounced the new American plan for aid to the contras yesterday, saying it violates the regional accord calling for the dismantling of the rebels' bases in Honduras. Article, page 6.
LEAD: A Delta rocket carried a $140 million satellite into space yesterday as part of the first ''Star Wars'' experiment in the Bush Administration and the first one to last more than a few hours.

LEAD: Ed Krayer had a goal and an assist to lead Harvard to a 4-2 victory over Lake Superior State tonight in the first game of their two-of-three-game National Collegiate Athletic Association series.
LEAD: Dick Cheney, the new Secretary of Defense, has learned what anyone who has spent any time at the Pentagon can tell you: Don't go into the basement without a guide.
LEAD: One gunman was killed and four others were arrested last evening in a gun battle outside a Washington Heights beer warehouse the men had tried to rob, the police said.
LEAD: When Guillermo Ungo returned from exile to El Salvador in November 1987, his goal was to re-establish a place for the left in the spectrum of his country's electoral politics.

LEAD: The Yeats Drama Foundation is to present a reading on April 8 at 5:30 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Eugene J. LEAD: On Easter Sunday 13 years ago, at the height of the New York City fiscal crisis, Bishop Paul Moore Jr., the head of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, delivered a dramatic sermon in which he pleaded with the corporate leaders of the city to show their faith by investing in New York.

LEAD: Coast Guard and Navy ships battled poor visibility and rough seas off the Virginia coast today to search for a 52-foot sport fishing boat that reported it was sinking with 10 people aboard. But after searching in vain for almost 24 hours, officials suspended the rescue operation.

LEAD: Domingo K. L. Tan, a physicist-turned-entrepreneur in Alexandria, Va., won patent approval this week for an aerosol spray that instantly cools off a parked car that has been left baking in the sun. LEAD: Houston, the highly touted 3-year-old who is listed as the even-money favorite in the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct today, may be scratched from the race because of the heavy rain yesterday.
LEAD: Americans' personal income shot up 1 percent last month while consumer spending advanced at a more restrained pace, raising the savings rate to its highest level in nearly three years.
LEAD: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day in some editions yesterday, about television networks that dropped an MGM/UA advertisement, carried an incorrect headline.

LEAD: In an attempt to forge a bipartisan foreign policy, President Bush joined Democratic and Republican leaders today to announce an agreement committing the Administration and Congress to aid for Nicaraguan rebels and to support for Central American peace efforts.
LEAD: Four brothers convicted of leading a crack ring that supplied up to half the city's users from 1982 to 1988 were sentenced today to long prison terms and large fines.

LEAD: United States wool production increased 5 percent last year, to 89.2 million pounds, the Agriculture Department said today. The number of sheep shorn totaled 11.5 million, also up 5 percent, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its annual report.
LEAD: Wet as it was yesterday in New York City and the metropolitan region, the rain had little effect on the reservoirs from which the city draws its water.

Deputizing for the German conductor, whose hip operation is the latest in a series of medical problems, will be Leonard Bernstein in Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony and Robert Shaw in Haydn's ''Creation.

LEAD: Questions appear on page 17.

LEAD: There was a late-night telephone call from Bo Schembechler, Michigan's athletic director and newest basketball fan, who just wanted to tell Steve Fisher and the players to keep up the good work.

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed on Thursday a $247 million deficit-bailout bill that calls for higher taxes on alcohol, cigarettes and businesses starting April 1 to close this year's deficit. The Senate passed the measure Thursday, 22 to 13.
LEAD: Clay T. Whitehead, a former president of the Hughes Aircraft Company's satellite subsidiary, has developed a satellite for small businesses.

LEAD: In ''976-EVIL,''a ridiculous horror movie, a young high school student, picked on by bullies, gains malevolent powers through a series of telephone calls. He dials 976-EVIL for his ''horror-scope'' and thereby turns into the wolfman of the lugubrious California town where he lives. He wreaks anatomically gruesome vengeance on his tattooed tormenters.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday moved further toward allowing Northeastern states to cut air pollution by imposing stricter standards than the Federal Government does on the formulation of gasoline.
LEAD: Homicides in New York City last year totaled a record 1,896, according to official Police Department statistics released yesterday. Almost 37 percent of the slayings were drug-related.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Bowing to pressure from farm-state lawmakers, the Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would allow small wholesalers and some retailers to sell diesel fuel without paying tax.
LEAD: By taking a fresh look at some old technology, Frank E. Wicks, a mechanical engineer, has designed a gas-powered air-conditioner that he said could cut cooling bills in half.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Wilbur E. Kelley, a retired engineer who worked in the procurement and processing of uranium and other elements for construction of the first atomic bomb, died of colon cancer March 16 at Deepdale Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in New Hyde Park.

LEAD: For some, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 meant the curtailment of tax deductions on contributions for Individual Retirement Accounts. People who hold I.R.A.'s but do not have qualified pension plans at work are not affected. Some experts believe that I.R.A. certificates of deposit still offer the best returns among types of C.D.

LEAD: On center stage, Dwight Gooden pitched seven innings against Fernando Valenzuela today, a pair of superstars sharpening their stuff in the next-to-last week of spring training. Gooden is nearly ready for opening day for the Mets. Valenzuela is apparently making a comeback for the Los Angeles Dodgers after a weary 1988.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dave Winfield, the Yankees' injured right fielder, underwent surgery this morning to remove a herniated disk in his lower back and is expected to remain hospitalized for several days. Jeff Klein, the player's attorney, said it was not known when Winfield would begin a rehabilitation program or how soon he might expect to return to the team.

LEAD: Linda Bouchard is a Canadian composer now living in New York. Lately she has been operating with and through a small instrumental group called Abandon. LEAD: By acting like a hard-charging Wall Street trader, David L. Paul has turned the Centrust Savings Bank of Miami into the largest and fastest-growing savings and loan association in the Southeast.

LEAD: If Dick Tracy could leave the two-dimensional world of the funnies to solve just one real-life crime, he would rush here to the Museum of Cartoon Art. A villain, still at large, has swiped some of the comic strips that documented the square-jawed shamus's work and captivated Americans for decades.

LEAD: A Government commission has concluded that thousands of people buried in a mass grave outside Kiev were killed during Stalin's repressions, not by Nazi soldiers, the official press agency Tass reported today.
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today cleared the way for Chilean apples, peaches and plums to be sold in the United States after they are inspected for evidence of cyanide poisoning.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The old Greeks had a saying that until a man is dead, do not yet call him happy, call him lucky. I thought about this in relation to Pete Rose, and how happy he had seemed.

LEAD: Not that the Duke Blue Devils needed any added inspiration at this point of the season, but as they sat before televisions on Thursday night and watched highly-ranked teams reach the end of their seasons, the reminder was clear. All it takes is one bad night. Maybe their intentness would have driven the Devils without the knowledge that other highly-seeded teams had been pushed out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

LEAD: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy filing of Eastern Airlines issued a temporary restraining order yesterday prohibiting the machinists' union from disrupting the airline's operations at Logan International Airport in Boston.

LEAD: The circus came to Madison Square Garden on Thursday with the farewell tour of its star animal trainer, Gunther Gebel-Williams, as its focus. The celebration outshone any conceivable office retirement party.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro outside linebacker, was arrested early yesterday morning in a parked car and given a summons for driving while intoxicated, the police said. Taylor has a history of drug problems, and it was not clear how or whether this incident would affect his pro football career.
LEAD: Rick Guimond came to special notice as a superb dancer in Senta Driver's company, but in the last four seasons he has directed his own troupe, Guimond Dance Associates.
LEAD: Everett Callender, a former securities analyst, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Greenwich.

LEAD: HORSE RACING Avie's Gal Wins Distaff: Avie's Gal, the lone front-runner in a field reduced from nine to five by heavy rain, led from start to finish to win the $86,100 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Haiati rallied well to finish second, 1 1/2 lengths behind the winner and 1 1/2 lengths in front of Topicount.

LEAD: Jim Jensen, an anchor of several Channel 2 news broadcasts, including its 6 P.M. program, has been moved ''to an in-patient care facility outside the New York metropolitan area for treatment of severe depression,'' the CBS-owned station said yesterday. The station said the treatment was likely to be ''extended.

LEAD: A Washington real estate developer, Mohamed A. Hadid, has agreed to pay up to $150 million in cash and assumed debt for control of the Ritz-Carlton hotels in New York and Washington, plus more than $14 million for renovations.

LEAD: There is plenty back in New York to remind Daryll Walker of Seton Hall that his every step will be followed against Nevada-Las Vegas in the West Regional final Saturday afternoon in McNichols Arena.
LEAD: Coach Bill Berry was dismissed as San Jose State's basketball coach yesterday.

LEAD: Many of the members of the commission charged with recommending a new form of government for New York City strongly favor continuing borough influence in city government despite the United States Supreme Court decision invalidating the Board of Estimate, the principal arena for the boroughs' exercise of power.

LEAD: Wally Heider, a recording engineer whose studios were used by big bands and rock musicians in the 1960's and 70's and who recently produced a series of jazz videotapes, died of lung cancer Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Leslie Lee. He was 66 years old.
LEAD: Every Thursday a small white plane bearing United Nations insignia ferries a Yugoslav general from Baghdad to Teheran, or in the reverse direction.
LEAD: A debate over a minor amendment to an obscure 11-year-old law has lawmakers here talking about art: specifically, how it affects the beholder and who is entitled to its benefits.

LEAD: President Bush's decision to focus anti-drug efforts on the streets of Washington is part of a plan to heighten the Government's distinctive role in the capital, a senior White House official said today.
LEAD: The longer the Nets' losing streak gets, the more frustrating it becomes for the organization.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Connecticut General Assembly's approval of tax increases misstated the proposed rise in the cigarette tax. The tax on each pack will rise 14 cents, to 40 cents.

LEAD: After more than a decade of political setbacks, Italy's Communist Party has unveiled its latest modern look, hoping that its new emphasis on ecology, feminism and family issues can attract an electorate that no longer seems interested in Marx and the masses.

LEAD: In a case watched closely for an indication of the safety of top-secret workplaces, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration cited the Lockheed Corporation's airplane-building division today for widespread violations of safety and health standards and said it would seek a fine of nearly $1.5 million.
LEAD: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 57th Streets will be closed between 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. tomorrow for the Easter Promenade.

LEAD: ''I used to say, when God wants me, He'll choose me,'' Nereida Cruz recalled recently. Ms. Cruz, a 42-year-old New Yorker who is the mother of three children 9 to 24 years old, says she believes God has chosen her now.

LEAD: Like his American counterparts in the computer business, the man in charge of computer networks in the Soviet Union likes to talk about selling ''solutions'' -hardware and software combinations shaped for a specific function.
LEAD: Jacob R. Van Mater Lefferts, a retired New Jersey real-estate developer, died Tuesday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Vero Beach.
LEAD: Many top executives work so hard running their companies that they neglect their personal finances. That situation has created a demand for financial planning as an executive perquisite.

LEAD: A 14-year-old girl was killed and four teen-age girls were seriously injured Thursday when their car plowed into trees shortly after they had left school to begin their Easter break, the police said.
LEAD: There was another game between the Knicks and the Celtics at the Boston Garden tonight, and another New York loss.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government denounced a new American plan for aid to anti-Sandinista rebels today, declaring that the plan violates a recent peace accord calling for the dismantling of the rebels' bases in Honduras.

LEAD: The Field, a nonprofit service organization for emerging dance artists, will have its first Pagnano Memorial Fund Benefit on April 4 and 5 at the Dia Art Foundation, 155 Mercer Street, at 8 P.M. The performances will be followed by a dance party. The program is to include dance and performance art by Robert Kovich, Beth Leonard, Jeff McMahon and Sarah Skaggs.

LEAD: Fighting a bad cold and a mild case of nerves, Representative Harry A. Johnston, newly elected Democrat from Florida's 14th Congressional District, took a seat at the dais and prepared to hear from the most vocal and politically potent segment of his consitutency - retirees.
LEAD: A Board of Education clerk was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 15-year-old girl who was a student at the high school where he worked, the police said.
