LEAD: The Afghan Government relieved pressure on the besieged city of Jalalabad today when a convoy of 85 supply trucks that had been delayed by guerrilla ambushes and by the destruction of a strategic bridge broke through to the city, according to Government officials here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The man selected by Baseball Magazine as the Relief Pitcher of the 1970's needs financial relief. Rollie Fingers has filed a petition in Bankruptcy Court in San Diego seeking liquidation of his debts. The 42-year-old former relief ace with Oakland, San Diego and Milwaukee has assets estimated at less than $50,000 and liabilities of more than $1 million.

LEAD: The homage to Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn presented by the Center Dance Collective on Wednesday at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace offered a good deal of instruction about the work of those two innovative American modern-dance choreographers and performers. The introduction offered by Michelle Mathesius, founder of the company in 1979, and comments and projected photographs that served as preface to each number were fascinating and invaluable.

LEAD: As Karyn Whitney stood with scores of other Manhattan-bound commuters in the Staten Island Ferry Terminal at St. George, her gaze fell on groups of homeless people across the crowded waiting room, women sitting on wood benches and staring into space and groups of young men with matted hair and dirty clothes.
LEAD: A tanker filled to capacity with crude oil ran aground and ruptured yesterday 25 miles from the southern end of the Trans Alaska Pipeline, spewing her cargo into water rich in marine life.

LEAD: Saying he wanted to take firepower away from drug dealers, Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, has introduced a bill to ban the manufacture, transfer and importation of .25-caliber and .32-caliber bullets. The bill is aimed at the cheap, easily concealed pistols that Mr. Weiss said on Thursday were used in 75 percent of all gun-related homicides.

LEAD: John G. Mapes, former vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton Inc., a Manhattan-based public relations concern, died of complications from pneumonia Thursday at a Phoenix nursing home. He was 82 years old and lived in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

LEAD: Near the main thoroughfare of this dusty port city, down a narrow alley and off a courtyard for cooking fires, a local entrepreneur sought to impress a visitor with prized samples from the business he runs with his three sons.
LEAD: Defense attorneys in the trial of Oliver L. North asked the court today to compel former President Ronald Reagan to appear as a witness.
LEAD: Irving Seligman, a retired men's clothing manufacturer, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: More than $100 million in Federal aid for the New York City Board of Education was withheld last year because the board failed to meet deadlines for developing plans to spend the money, the New York State Department of Education said today.

Page 1 News analysis: The policy accord represents a new approach: Rather than trying to overthrow the Sandinistas, the Bush Administration hopes to prod them toward democracy with diplomatic pressure.
LEAD: United States stock, bond and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday.

John, a retired postal worker of failing health, acquiesces because Gerald is likely to jam his face in a plate of food or throw furniture at him if he refuses.

LEAD: Derrick Coleman shook off persistent back problems and Sherman Douglas took charge down the stretch as Syracuse ignited its running game and streaked past Missouri, 83-80, and into the championship game of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

LEAD: The Buffalo Bills aren't saying whether they will keep Bruce Smith, their two-time All-Pro defensive end, who has signed an offer sheet with the Denver Broncos for a reported $7.5 million over five years.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would shut its assembly plant in Linden next week to reduce inventories of Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta cars. The shutdown will affect about 140 workers. Ward's Automotive Reports, a weekly trade journal, said that as of Feb. 28 G.M. had a 103-day supply of the Corsica-Beretta cars on hand.

LEAD: From 1984 to 1987, the number of low-birthweight babies born in New York City rose notably, in three years erasing a decade of progress. That's another alarming symptom of the crack epidemic in cities across the country.

LEAD: As the Georgetown Hoyas approach the day that will provide the final definition of their basketball season, they are constructing a description of their own. The Hoyas entered the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament after three convincing victories in the Big East tournament that reinforced the image of an overpowering team.

LEAD: The Prospect Group Inc., which owns 26 percent of Brinkmann Instruments Inc., has held talks with the laboratory equipment manufacturer about selling back some of its shares. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Prospect said it had told Brinkmann that it would be willing to sell some of its stock for $19 a share.

LEAD: When the United States Supreme Court struck down the New York City Board of Estimate on constitutional grounds, the questions of discrimination against minority-group members and the Federal Voting Rights Act were barely mentioned.

LEAD: Pressing onward in its three-month battle to acquire control of the Universal Foods Corporation of Milwaukee, the High Voltage Engineering Corporation has sweetened its tender offer for the food concern to $38 a share in cash, or a total price of $657 million.
LEAD: Casinos here are challenging an ordinance that requires them to reserve 1 percent of construction budgets for statues, murals and other artworks, a casino representative said today.

LEAD: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency today ordered a review of a dam project southwest of Denver that could cost as much as $1 billion, saying the dam could result in ''the very heavy, final and irremediable loss of an environmental treasure of national significance.''

LEAD: U.E.I. P.L.C., a British broadcasting equipment maker, has acquired 47 percent of Unitel Video Inc. and will consider buying the remaining shares of the New York video recording services company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, U.E.I. said it had acquired its stake in private placements on March 14 for an average price of $14 a share.
LEAD: A judge set a $100,000 bond today for Timothy Jacobs, an American Indian who is charged with kidnapping in connection with the takeover of a newspaper office here.
LEAD: ''I understand the meaning of remorse. I have remorse - for losing Lisa - I have remorse for losing my life.'' - Joel B. Steinberg. [ 32:4. ]

The memory of Mickey Hargitay is still vivid in Hungary. To his old friends in Budapest, as well as to people who never knew him at all, Mr. Hargitay is a living testament to the infinite possibilities of the American Dream. Having emigrated to the United States at the age of 14, he went on to win the Mr. Universe title, appear as a professional strong man and supporting actor to Mae West in her nightclub act, marry Jayne Mansfield and become a great movie star. That's the way he's recalled (with tongue firmly in cheek) by Gyorgy Szomjas's cheerful, cockeyed, Hungarian-American road movie, ''Mr. Universe.'' The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6:30 P.M. and on Monday at 8:30 P.M. in the New Directors/ New Films Festival.

LEAD: The leaders of this sheikdom on the Persian Gulf have expressed concern at the continued stalemate in Iran-Iraq peace talks, reflecting their fears that hostilities might resume and their worries about the effect on Kuwait's own politics.
LEAD: In upholding two Federal programs that test employees for drug use in the workplace, the Supreme Court properly balanced privacy rights against public safety.

LEAD: The Rev. Robert C. Dodds, a former official of the National Council of Churches who was also a psychologist and marriage counselor, died last Saturday at Central Vermont Hospital in Barre, Vt., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Montpelier, Vt.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Thursday, with an article about the nuclear power industry, omitted the years corresponding to the number of automatic emergency shutdowns annually at the nation's nuclear plants.
LEAD: * Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., a subsidiary of Amax Inc., is expected to announce plans to build a $1 billion aluminium smelter in Canada, the Quebec Government said.

LEAD: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, in his first major written statement on pollution at the nation's production complex for nuclear weapons, outlined a five-year program yesterday to figure out what needs to be cleaned up most urgently and how and when to do it.

LEAD: Theodore C. Agins, a retired dentist and former mayor of Kensington, L.I., died of a heart attack Thursday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

LEAD: The Waseda Symphony Orchestra, which played its first New York concert Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, is a 75-year-old ensemble staffed by students at Waseda University in Tokyo. The university has no conservatory or school of music - all the players are majors in the liberal arts or sciences - but the orchestra maintains an extensive schedule of concerts, tours regularly, and is occasionally visited by celebrated conductors.

LEAD: Responding to Bush Administration demands, Japan has assured the United States that at least 35 percent of a jet fighter the two Governments want to build together would be made in the United States, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The bipartisan agreement on Central America, fashioned by James A. Baker 3d in one of his first major acts as Secretary of State, represents a sharp break from President Reagan's policy of unmitigated opposition to the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua.

LEAD: In an interview with Barbara Walters that was broadcast last night on the ABC program ''20-20,'' Wade Boggs, the Boston Red Sox third baseman, said Margo Adams threatened to make his life difficult if he broke off their four-year affair. Boggs said he worried Adams would blackmail him with pictures she had taken of them.
LEAD: Beth Slingerland, a widely known educator in the field of dyslexia, died Wednesday at the Judson Park Retirement Home in Seattle. She was 89 years old.

LEAD: The chairman of the commission that must create a new government for New York City said yesterday that he envisioned changes that could shake up the traditional power structure by giving a greater voice to minority groups and small political parties.

LEAD: Friends of South Korean democracy shouldn't be alarmed by President Roh Tae Woo's surprise postponement this week of the plebiscite he promised in his 1987 election campaign. The vote would not have added much to Korea's yearlong march toward democracy, and indeed might have distracted from the real issues.

LEAD: Attempting to lay the groundwork for a new generation of nuclear reactors, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is likely to approve in the next few days a sweeping revision of the way new plants are licensed.

LEAD: With summer on the horizon, more travelers planning international vacations are turning to a growing number of small advertisements in newspapers and magazines offering the world at a bargain price.

LEAD: TW Services Inc. said it had agreed to provide financial information to Coniston Partners and other parties who have expressed interest in acquiring the New York-based restaurant operator. LEAD: Randy Gordon, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that Bill Cayton had a valid manager's license during 1988 and has one for 1989, refuting assertions by the promoter Don King.

LEAD: As they prepare for their annual planting, farmers in the Sacramento Valley in northern California, the American Rice Bowl, are trying again to see if there is a way to open Japan's tightly sealed rice market.

LEAD: Charles Barkley was perfect tonight, hitting all 19 shots from the floor and the foul line in scoring 31 points and leading the Philadelphia 76ers to a 135-122 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.
LEAD: Now that she's well into her 60's, Millie Addolorato figures it is her turn. On May 1, she says, she is going to walk out of her house in the Bronx and pick up her ticket to freedom.

LEAD: The medieval cathedrals of England are crumbling, and their custodians are looking with increasing desperation to wealthy private donors in Britain, the United States and elsewhere to save them.

LEAD: Our frozen-apple-pie contest has been a disappointment. Hoping to discover a new cliche for the outmoded expression ''as American as apple pie,'' we offered a frozen apple pie as a prize for the best entry and sat back waiting to be deluged with fresh, pungent and colorful phrases.

LEAD: In an extraordinary public rebuke apparently aimed at establishing his control over the military, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney took the Air Force Chief of Staff sharply to task today for discussing with members of Congress a possible compromise on a major strategic issue.
LEAD: Easter plants are colorful while they last: tulips, daffodils, hyacinths, lilies, azaleas and hydrangeas, to name a few. After the holiday, most of them can be planted outdoors to bloom again.
LEAD: On a bleak hilltop at the edge of the town where Germany's first democratic constitution was framed stands a dismal reminder of how low that civilization fell not long ago.

LEAD: Randall Dale Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a Dallas police officer in 1976, was the subject last year of a critically acclaimed film, ''The Thin Blue Line,'' in which the prosecution's four principal witnesses contradicted their original testimony. LEAD: ''The paths of glory lead but to the grave,'' that memorable phrase from a poet of yesterday, Thomas Gray, whose words have never died, came close to leading me to a premature breakdown at the age of 10. As I sat in the crowded third-grade classroom, listening to the poetry being read aloud, I raised my hand it interrupt the gentle teacher who was determined to bring literature into our young lives and asked for an explanation of the short phrase.

LEAD: New York City has come to an extraordinary moment in its history, one filled with opportunity and hope, a chance to right wrongs and address old failings. Its hand forced by a Supreme Court decision, America's most tumultuous city must now reinvent itself.

LEAD: WHEN MY 4-YEAR-OLD THRUSTS her latest drawing in front of me, I seem to grow older on the spot. I take my daughter's hand, push it and her picture back away from my nose, stretch my neck backward a couple of inches, and peer. At the age of 35, I am encountering one sign of age that no amount of exercise or high-fiber foods or Retin-A can forestall.

LEAD: Throughout this century, prominent artists have collaborated with choreographers. Many of their stage designs for dances have been attractive to look at. But the best of these designs have been more than pretty pictures. By calling attention to some aspect of a work's choreography, a design can enhance that work's meaning.

LEAD: GOODNESS knows, I'm old enough to be a grandmother. It's true, although I rarely think of it, that I have got to be ''of a certain age.'' Some of my best friends are grandmothers, with clusters of small relatives to brag about and wallets full of their pictures to pass around at luncheons when old friends get together.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Corney of Nashville, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Tyler Corney, to Peter Cornelius Van Allen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Van Allen of Iowa City and Southampton, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN 1985, President Jose Sarney of Brazil argued for a new land-redistribution plan, saying that ''no modern country has developed without first dealing with its agrarian problem.'' But this month, in a stark illustration of what happened to that idea, the police fired at random as they evicted some 500 landless families who had taken over a private farm to protest the Government's broken promises.

LEAD: Under mounting public criticism over the crime wave in the nation's capital, Police Chief Maurice T. Turner Jr. says the police are doing all they can and predicts that the murder rate will fall once drug dealers finish dividing their markets.

LEAD: A project to house the elderly in Warwick, N.Y., is to be formally opened Friday as the third phase of an ambitious plan to provide tax-subsidized apartments to the growing number of elderly in the Orange County village. Named the Creekside Apartments, the $4.5 million development is providing 65 one-bedroom apartments to eligible people who are either 62 years of age or older, or 55 and handicapped.

LEAD: Rowing Oxford Defeats Cambridge: Oxford claimed its 13th victory in the last 14 years by overcoming an early clash of oars to defeat a heavier Cambridge crew by two lengths in yesterday's 135th edition of the annual University Boat Race, the first race in which both coxswains were women. Oxford finished the four and a half miles along the Thames River in 18 minutes 28 seconds, almost 2 minutes slower than the record of 16:45 it set in 1984.

Runge of Roslyn, L.I., have announced. Miss Runge graduated from Long Island Lutheran High School in Brookville and magna cum laude from the University of Delaware.

LEAD: Few best-selling bands seem so schizophrenic as the Bangles. Last year our reviewer, Edmund White, said this novel is ''highly cinematic [ with its ] psychological observation that is suggested through close-ups; lots of punchy dialogue; a convincing sense of place; a building of suspense; and a pervasive atmosphere of sexuality and violence.

LEAD: To the Editor: In her report of Washington's revitalized Union Station, which is now a shopping, dining and cinema center as well as a depot, Barbara Gamarekian told readers almost everything they might want to know.

LEAD: For anyone who believed in signs and portents, the season's first ''Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera had to be a cheerful event. The performance on Friday evening, first of three in the final weeks leading up to the company's long-awaited presentations of Wagner's complete ''Ring'' in proper sequence, went smoothly enough to suggest that the cycle may be rounding into shape at just the right time.
LEAD: A hospital here is seeking new breeds of blood donors - dogs and cats - to help set up a blood bank for pets.

LEAD: OF THE NEW GUATEMALA IS WORKING for anyone, it is working for Enrique de Leon. His unpretentious steakhouse in the capital has proved very successful, and he is investing the profits in a new and far more elegant eatery called Vivaldi, where a classical pianist in a tuxedo sets the ambiance.

LEAD: BENNY'S location on Post Avenue in downtown Westbury is next to an appliance store, across the street from a bank and a few blocks from the neighborhood movie. But this is not a haven for weary shoppers seeking a quick bite. Rather, it is that rarest of Long Island phenomena: a centrally situated, in-town restaurant offering dining on the grand scale.

LEAD: His classmates at Riley High School in South Bend, Ind., voted Daniel Waters ''most unforgettable'' eight years ago. Some of them may come to rue the irony of that vote when ''Heathers,'' a dark new satire written by Mr. Waters that transforms teen-age suicide into blackest farce, opens Friday.

LEAD: IT could arguably be described as the grandest single-family residence in New York, with a full 100-foot frontage on Park Avenue at the northeast corner of 64th Street. Such a claim may account for the asking price of $20 million for the old Thomas A. Howell residence built in 1920.

LEAD: THE RISING. By Edgar White. (Marion Boyars/Kampmann, $18.95.) ''West Indians,'' we are told in this first novel of a projected trilogy, ''never say no.'' Instead they slide around the negative with suggestion and innuendo, but God help those who misread the signals. Mother Frances rules the society of a small Caribbean island, manipulating her way unscathed through the prevailing hurricanes of sex and (usually) psychic violence.

In the graphs, the dollar value of the deficit is expressed as a positive number; therefore, the quotient of the deficit divided by the G.N.P. must also be a positive number, because, by definition, the value of the G.N.P.

LEAD: The Hudson County Board of Freeholders is investigating the Hudson County Jail, one of the most overcrowded county jails in New Jersey and long a place where troubles range from the pathetic to the tragic.

LEAD: The Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended a week ago in Reno, Nev. were the biggest ever, with a table count of 13,807 eclipsing a record set 21 years earlier in New York City. They were also slightly longer than usual, since the entry of 107 teams in the Vanderbilt Knockout made it necessary to play the final on Monday, when the other contestants had departed.

LEAD: I JUST had my first real job interview, and it was with a brokerage. I was not very serious about getting the position, but there was an open slot in the all-campus interviews schedule, so I took it. It would be a good interviewing experience, I thought. I quickly ate my lunch and hurried upstairs to change into my suit, while words like ''dress for success'' and ''corporate image'' went through my mind.

LEAD: IN 1980, in a United States-orchestrated effort to deprive a leftist revolution of its central issue, the Salvadoran Army marched onto almost 500 of this country's largest farms, expropriated the land and gave it to rural families. ''The most revolutionary land reform in Latin American history'' was the way the effort was described by the United States Ambassador, Robert E.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE revolutionary new abortion pill, RU 486, is increasingly popular in France, and is considered by the medical profession to be a far better means of abortion than surgical procedures. But given pressures from anti-abortion groups, among other obstacles, it could take years before the pill becomes available in other countries.

LEAD: DEAF IN AMERICA: Voices From a Culture. By Carol Padden and Tom Humphries. (Harvard University, $17.95.) Deafness means a great deal more than simply being unable to hear. In ''Deaf in America,'' Carol Padden and Tom Humphries - themselves deaf - argue that the deaf have developed a distinct culture that includes sign language, shared experiences and ideas that often set them apart from the hearing world.

LEAD: Though its production company is the Arts Bureau of the Organization for the Propagation of Islamic Thought, the Iranian film ''The Peddler'' is in no way a work of propaganda. In fact, it takes for granted a devastating, almost unbearably high level of misery. Though it aims at times for an incongruously rueful, almost whimsical tone, its overall impression is one of unadulterated suffering.

LEAD: Garden elements have been a recurring theme in the decorative arts for centuries, but it is only recently that materials and objects meant for use outdoors are finding their way inside. Terra-cotta vases and wire tables, stone benches and twig furniture - pieces that traditionally adorned patios or porches or gardens - are becoming as integral a part of interior schemes as the living-room sofa.

LEAD: Capt. Will C. Rogers 3d of the Navy will give up command of the guided-missile cruiser Vincennes in May, a change the Navy called routine and unrelated to the possible terrorist bombing of a van driven by Captain Rogers's wife.

LEAD: LIKE a picture window in a small room, the view of the New Jersey Palisades from the three bosky hills of Hastings-on-Hudson creates an illusion of expansiveness in this village of only two square miles.

LEAD: AS viewed from city halls across the nation, the government of New York City is like something from another planet. Who ever heard of a single municipality that is also five counties? What is a borough president? And what strange thing is a Board of Estimate that sounds like an arcane adjunct but has real power?

LEAD: John Hurley's letter [ ''Shoreham: The Hydro Option,'' March 5 ] illustrates the anti-nuke delusion as no Lilco advocate could. He suggests hydro power or natural gas as Shoreham alternatives. Natural gas is not new. Hydro power is not new. It is the prime mover that launched the Industrial Revolution.

LEAD: Joseph Romer, a former account executive in the advertising department of The New York Times, died Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan from complications after suffering a stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

LEAD: With many music lovers, among others, chronically short of cash, space or both, there has been a steady demand for cheap, small loudspeakers. In the past, most such speakers sounded thin and tinny; some still do.

Terrorist threats against airlines keep coming in ''over the transom,'' says a TV commentator. LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. P. Moyler of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Joanne Moyler, to Jeffrey Hawley McKinnon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William James McKinnon of Wadesboro, N.C. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: When Arvo Part's music was first performed in New York, less than a decade ago, the temptation was to think of the Estonian emigre composer as a Minimalist. Works like ''Tabula Rasa'' and ''Fratres,'' the first of his scores to gain any currency in this country, were solidly, unequivocally tonal, and they used repetition as a central structural element.

LEAD: Dorothy Richards loved beavers. She loved them so much that they lived in her house, Beaversprite, for 42 years, eating with her at the dining room table when they weren't filing their incisors on the table's legs. She loved them so much that she left Beaversprite and 735 acres in this Adirondack foothill town for their preservation.

LEAD: To the Editor: Ron Nowicki's piece brings to mind similar Florida land deals run amok during the 60's and 70's. My husband and I loved them. We had the perfect ploy. After playing along and enjoying the dinner, we listened ''excitedly'' to the banter and, in fact, even reached out as if to sign the contract.

LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' and ''Long Ago & Far Away'' have something in common: Both are wonderful and yet each leaves you feeling a bit sad, the stage production because it's a reminder of the sort of great musicals that aren't being made anymore, the television series because its unmistakable quality makes you keenly aware once again of the generally woeful state of programming for children in this country.

LEAD: Seven months after the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, Iran and Iraq are still holding thousands of each other's prisoners in apparent violation of an international convention, Iraqi and Red Cross officials say.

LEAD: Leah Ruth Robinson and John Pierce Rousmaniere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rousmaniere of Southbury, Conn., plan to marry in May, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Robinson of La Anna, Pa., and St. James City, Fla., have announced.

LEAD: Dog Training 101 ''THIS is going to be a comic piece, right?'' said Stephanie Reyer of Great Neck, holding her dog Sasha in a vice grip as dogs in various stages of terror and excitement entered the auditorium of Great Neck's Cumberland Elementary School. Sasha, a large German shepherd-husky-mix, was going into a barking frenzy every time a new dog came in.
LEAD: FOR millions of government workers facing drug testing, as well as those who work in industry, the Supreme Court's decision last week raised more questions than it answered.
LEAD: Shame on Michael Brim of the Cat Fanciers Association [ ''Long Island Journal,'' March 12 ] for his quotation comparing mixed-breed cats ''Volkswagens'' to pedigreed ''Cadillacs.''

LEAD: LORD NELSON: The Immortal Memory. By David Howarth and Stephen Howarth. (Viking, $24.95.) A danger in retelling the life of a national hero is that the subject's virtues often are inflated and his shortcomings diminished. Thus, in ''Lord Nelson,'' an unguardedly affectionate biography of Britain's most notable mythologized naval hero, conspicuous character deficits - cynicism, vanity, decadence, infantilism and cruelty - are largely dismissed, defended or recast as attributes.

LEAD: The Philanthropic Society, a new group founded to pursue the Jewish tenet of tzedaka, or charity, has been converting empty soda cans into cash to buy food for poor students and the housebound elderly.

LEAD: Lee Ann Duffy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Duffy of Hackensack, N.J., and Jonathon M. Gerson, a son of Dr. Arnold Gerson of White Plains and the late Elizabeth Gerson, were married yesterday in a private hall in Manhattan. Judge Zachary Carter of City Criminal Court officiated.

LEAD: PRESIDENT BUSH, in introducing his child care proposal this month, declared that child care ''is one of the key issues facing the nation.'' But Congress is far from agreement on how best to provide relief for families with children, particularly those led by working parents, and the Bush proposal is only one of several.

LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q.I want to file my tax return, but the company I used to work for still hasn't sent me my W-2 form showing my 1988 wages. What should I do? A.You should contact your former employer and request that the document be sent to you, said Frank Keith, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service in Washington.

LEAD: Buying a swimsuit is a lesson in self-knowledge, especially for the woman whose body is imperfect. ''The truth is, no swimsuit can hide flaws,'' said Norma Kamali, the fashion designer. ''You're exposed.''
LEAD: When students go to college, most expect three things: classes will be tough, study hours will be long and dining hall food will not taste like Mom's.

LEAD: CABBIES HONK APPROVINGLY. Pedestrians applaud. Diners gather at restaurant windows. Around New York, Eric Staller's ''Lightmobile'' (right) is a little bit famous. Ever since its maiden voyage in 1985, the Volkswagen beetle with its ebullient adornments - 1,659 light bulbs, computer-controlled and capable of flashing in 25 different patterns - has effervesced regularly all over town, wreaking a pleasant sort of havoc wherever it goes.

LEAD: The Personal Finance column last week misidentified the type of ''frozen'' Keogh retirement plans that must be amended by May 31. A Keogh plan is frozen when it no longer accepts contributions. Individuals who hold frozen ''defined-contribution'' Keogh plans - those to which they had contributed a fixed percentage of annual income - do not have to amend their plans.

In all those years, the forms of democratic government were travestied by uncontested elections and make-believe parliaments. The reality has been one-party rule. As cynics put it, the very name U.S.S.R.

KOENIG says that she established Grandtravel in 1987 when she learned she was going to become a grandmother, because she was so excited at the prospect of traveling with children again. Lots of the fun of travel is in the show-and-tell, and here is an occasion for grandparents to enjoy the exchange with their grandchildren to the fullest.

LEAD: There are moments in the best Louis Malle films when it is possible to believe in innocence, in an Edenic world of childhood goodness that is soon shattered in some understated, irrevocable way. AU REVOIR LES ENFANTS, now available on video (Orion Home Video, $79.98), is Mr. Malle's magnificently subtle and profoundly moving account of a Jewish boy hidden in a Catholic school in France during World War II.

LEAD: The statistics shifted enough last week to offset anxieties of inflation thatwere stoked the previous week by a report that wholesale prices had surged by 1 percent in February. This week's report on February's Consumer Price Index showed a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent - less than most analysts had predicted and lower than January's increase of six-tenths of 1 percent.
LEAD: Next fall, male and female students at Villanova University will be living in the same dormitory for the first time in the school's 147-year history.

LEAD: To the Editor: Santiago, Chile, and Prague, Czechoslovakia, also have excellent subways, clean and noiseless. RENEE REIMAN New York, N.Y.

LEAD: Attorneys for Bruce Kimball say they will ask a judge to reduce the Olympic diving medalist's 17-year sentence for drunken-driving manslaughter and transfer him to a center where he can be treated for chemical dependency.

LEAD: The earliest audiences for Wagner's ''Ring,'' like audiences everywhere and always, fussed over trivia as readily they waxed eloquent over the spectacular experience of the monumental opera cycle. Nineteenth and early 20th-century reactions to Wagner, the ''Ring,'' and Wagnerian theater, from musicians and laymen, cover a number of genres: the historical, the comical, the gastronomical, the tragical, the metaphysical, the gastronomical-metaphysical and the comical-historical.

LEAD: The White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, expressed reservations today about the Bush Administration's agreement with Congress on Central America that was negotiated by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. He said it permits Congress to encroach too far on the constitutional powers of the President.
LEAD: From the canyons of midtown to the wilds of Wall Street, urban vagabonds are abandoning the executive briefcase for the more pastoral - and arguably more practical - knapsack.

LEAD: The new Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, has hardly settled in his seat and already the civilian and uniformed sachems of the military tribe are leaping about him with their hair on fire, urging immediate decisions. He should refuse - until he has made his most important choice.

LEAD: Marti Stevens is one of a handful of veteran nightclub performers who evoke the kinder, gentler Manhattan of another era. Indeed, that world seems so far in the past that one might question whether it ever really existed outside of show business.
LEAD: Pete Peeters, the Washington Capital goalie, had seen only one performance like this before.

LEAD: In criticizing Charles Schnabolk's ''Cheers for the Lower Half'' (Opinion page, Jan. 8) Robert Wechsler's letter to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 12 confuses the point of the article. He should have read it one more time; it was, indeed, a parody of our obsession with grades and did not, as Mr. Wechsler suggests, downgrade intellectual achievement.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Klein of Syosset, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Sue Klein, to David Barnet Sokol, the son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Marvin Sokol of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Klein, a third-year student at the New York University School of Medicine, graduated from Syosset High School and Brown University.

LEAD: To the Editor: I applaud the action of all members of the United Nations Security Council but the United States (news story, Feb. 18) in voting for a resolution deploring Israel's mistreatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories, which deserves criticism.
LEAD: Motorists driving past the College of Wooster at 4 P.M. last Monday may have been startled to see more than 400 students and faculty members marching.

LEAD: ''WHEN'S the llamas' bedtime?'' was the first question our son, Jacob, asked as we started our trek into the Eagle Cap Wilderness Area of eastern Oregon. From that moment on, he never stopped asking questions, some of which he even directed at Murphy, the llama who, with exquisite docility, allowed his young inquisitor to lead him up the trail.

LEAD: Perhaps Barbara Klaus wrote her article on bridge [ ''About Long Island: High Cards, Bigger Egos,'' March 5 ] with tongue in cheek (and perhaps not), but I was very angry to read my own words taken out of context.

LEAD: THE route has been changed, the proposal has been enhanced and the public has been heard from and will be heard from some more. But after three years, the popularity of the Iroquois gas pipeline project remains as it was: it has some friends and quite a few enemies.

LEAD: There was much to admire in Jean Jordan's debut recital on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. The soprano offered a rich program of works by Handel, Wolf, Barber, Rodrigo and Roger Quilter, all delivered with the kind of expressivity that comes from attention to the texts.

LEAD: Can overexposure to music video cause hallucinations and delusions? Consider, as a case study, the cover story in the Feb. 24, 1989, issue of National Review, ''Rock of Ageds'' by Stuart Goldman.

LEAD: George Markham, president and general manager of the Carlyle Hotel, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor: Reading Ron Nowicki's article ''Yes, There Is No Free Lunch'' (Travel, Jan. 29) brought back memories of a similar experience my late wife and I had in October 1969, except that it took place in Rome. We were among the thousands in the crowd in St. Peter's Square after the Pope's Sunday noon balcony appearance and blessing.

LEAD: LESLIE SULLIVAN, a computer program designer, became so frustrated in her attempts to replace her young children's baby sitters with someone who would live in her Larchmont home that she decided to do something about it.

LEAD: WE snickered a lot in high school poetry class. Even at an all-girl school where there were no boys to make us feel self-conscious, we snickered and rolled our eyes, but never more than when we studied Emily Dickinson. Her alienation from the world was foreign to us.

LEAD: Concern about falling behind in the race for the America's Cup has prompted two defense syndicates to move ahead with preparations without waiting for a court decision on whom the cup belongs to.

LEAD: MY favorite spot in Bristol is the damp, cobbled floor of the Great Western Drydock. From down there, hemmed in by stone walls fitted almost a century and a half ago, amid mossy puddles, a voluptuous sweep of red-orange hull looms above. The hull belongs to the Great Britain; launched in 1843, she was the fist iron-hulled, propeller-driven trans-Atlantic liner - in fact, the first such vessel to cross any ocean.

LEAD: The world would be poorer if a shop owner could not don a flounced purple dress once in a while to portray a tuba player in a marimba band, or if a genial teacher could not become - for a few performances, anyway - the horrible Mr. Hyde.

LEAD: For This Week: Use a stiff metal rake over the lawn to finish spring cleanup; add leaves and small debris to compost. Shake cayenne pepper or dried chili peppers around spring bulbs, especially crocus, chionodoxa and early tulips to discourage feeding by squirrels and other rodents. Finish pruning fruit trees.

LEAD: HAVE you heard the story about the $5,499,999,999 lost in a prime real estate investment? Built on the Long Island Sound in Shoreham, at a total cost of $5.5 billion, the famous nonfunctioning Lilco Nuclear Power Station will probably be sold to the State of New York for one lousy buck.
LEAD: When students at the University of Miami leave a message on a telephone answering machine, they make sure you get the message.

Koontz's latest novel, ''Midnight,'' takes the theme of demonic possession a giant step beyond mere aliens from outer space. LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Stockman of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Celia Stockman to John Anthony LoScalzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John LoScalzo of Huntington, L.I. A May 20 wedding is planned.

LEAD: EVEN in the best of times, anxiety and confusion are the hallmarks of shopping for mortgage money. And today, not only are interest rates at distressing heights, but they also are topsy-turvy - with unadorned adjustable-rate mortgages more costly than the safer option of fixed-rate financing.

LEAD: WOBBLY chairs are annoying and, if allowed to worsen, can lead to accidents. Most wobbles are caused by broken glue joints, due either to deterioration of old glue or to excess strain placed on chair parts.
LEAD: He's been depicted as an arrogant, preening showboat, but as an undeniable tennis sensation who won six tournaments last year, 18-year-old Andre Agassi has had plenty to be arrogant about.

LEAD: AS the prices of homes have soared - particularly in areas like the Northeast and West Coast - so have the needs for buyers to seek jumbo, or ''nonconforming,'' mortgage loans. These are loans that exceed $187,600, the limit for individual dwelling set by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, the Government-chartered corporations that regularly buy home loans from lenders.

LEAD: Earlier this month a national cable network announced a five-year contract with the National Federation of State High School Associations - composed of the 51 state high school athletic/activity associations in the United States - to televise a weekly package of high school sporting events, mostly basketball and football games.

LEAD: One of the treats of my recent trip to Florida - besides a needed respite from winter - was visiting a wildlife sanctuary full of tropical birds. But as much as I enjoyed looking at the birds, I couldn't help spending much of my time staring at the photographers who converged there every evening to capture their prey.

LEAD: The Feb. 19 article entitled ''The Wiew From: The Croton Reservoir Gatehouse'' is well done, except that one vital component of the project is totally missing: Mergentime Corporation is doing all the construction work reported on with such interest.

LEAD: Pete Rose was always considered a sure bet for baseball's Hall of Fame. Last week, the odds may have changed because of accusations that the Cincinnati Reds manager was linked to gambling activities. The baseball commissioner's office said an investigation was under way into ''serious allegations'' against Rose, and Sports Illustrated reported that he may have bet on baseball games.
LEAD: The cover article of The Times Magazine today discusses the new manager for the New York Yankees, Dallas Green, and some problems he faces.
LEAD: It seems as though it used to be so simple.

There's three of us, one of you. Got it? That's how it is here. Welcome to Dartmouth.

LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST POWERFUL men in the American Roman Catholic Church is hosting his own weekly talk show from his residence behind St. Patrick's Cathedral. His study, with its striking stained-glass windows, has been converted into a television studio, the bookcases and sofa moved out and replaced by three cameras and batteries of tall and hot lights.

LEAD: A CONSENSUS is forming among politicians and economists, liberals and conservatives, that the only practical way to make a fundamental assault on the Federal budget deficit is for Republicans and Democrats to relinquish their strongest political weapons.

LEAD: IF the United States Supreme Court decides to reverse or limit its 1973 decision guaranteeing the right to abortion, partisans on both sides of the issue in New Jersey predict that the state will erupt in a frenzy of legislative initiatives to limit the procedure.

LEAD: In the great race for overseas sales, many American companies are rushing to manufacture abroad, finding this strategy more efficient and profitable than exporting their products from the United States.

LEAD: AS one of the faithful who sit in the dark, cold parking lot adjacent to the Wantagh Long Island Rail Road Station weekday evenings, waiting for a much-loved commuter to return home, I've become a kind of para-professional of successful station sitting. It is a given that there will be a wait. I've been told that any train arriving under four minutes late is ''on time,'' so let's take it from there.

LEAD: AFTER Mayor Edward I. Koch's drought emergency declaration last week, residents of New York City and their northern neighbors are being forced for the third time this decade to cut water use. Without any conclusive evidence that the area is experiencing long-term shifts in weather, the question becomes: why?

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that the overhaul of New York City's government ordered by the United States Supreme Court last week should preserve all eight existing citywide and boroughwide posts, grant the five borough presidents a role in planning and development and enlarge the 35-member City Council.

LEAD: Will it be a finely checkered rosewood grip, cool and perfectly balanced against the palm, with a long sighting plane and a blue-steel barrel machined to a hairbreatdth tolerance for marksman-grade performance? Or will any gun do, just for the sense of it, there in the bureau at night, powerful enough to stop the worst nightmare?

LEAD: In an unusual challenge to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, career lawyers at the Justice Department are protesting the department's efforts to overturn the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that guaranteed a woman's right to an abortion.

LEAD: I SOMETIMES passed him on my daily four-mile walk on Pelham Parkway. Although I am not young, I am probably 50 years younger than he. He walks with the aid of a stick, stands erect and moves along at a respectable gait.

LEAD: STAR. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The butler admits you to a mansion in San Francisco's Pacific Heights and leads you into a wood-paneled dining room. You circle an antique table laden with Limoges until you find your name on a place card in a silver holder. By the light of a crystal chandelier, you sup on smoked salmon and oysters.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David L. Call of Ithaca, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Laura Ellen Call to Robert Charles Andolina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. Andolina of Clifton Park, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A clerk at a Queens high school has been charged with the statutory rape of a 15-year-old student who is the daughter of a diplomat, the police said yesterday. The clerk, John Gordon, 40 years old, of 100 Woodruff Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was arrested Friday afternoon at the Plaza North Hotel in Ridgewood, where he was found with the student, a police spokesman, Sgt.
LEAD: With the arrival of California asparagus in the markets, the perennial question arises: should the long green spears be eaten with a knife and fork or with the fingers?

LEAD: IN scenes reminiscent of science-fiction movies in which the world's peoples band together to face a common threat from outer space, delegates from around the globe have come together in the last month to confront the dangers posed by planetary warming and the depletion of the earth's protective ozone shield.
LEAD: HAVE you ever caught the moment when a child discovers the joy of imagery?
LEAD: A step-by-step guide to the balloting and an analysis of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's strategy are in The Week in Review. Section 4, page 3.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hax of Trumbull, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Katherine Heileman Hax and Bradford Jameson Holmes, a son of Elizabeth Parsons Holmes of Winchester, Mass., and Canaan Valley, W.Va., and the late David Bullard Holmes.

LEAD: DELAWARE'S principal ocean resort is about to become an attraction for outlet-store shoppers, too. This will come about when Land Design Inc., a Rehoboth Beach real estate development concern, opens a 90,000-square-foot shopping center with 30 manufacturers' outlet stores in mid-April.
LEAD: To the Editor: As printed in your letters column on March 12, my list of freshly minted Greek travel terms contained the following:

LEAD: IT was late in the afternoon of our hardest day of trekking in Nepal, a day in which we dropped from the frosty ridge of Tharepati at 11,800 feet to a suspension bridge over the Malemchi Khola nearly 4,000 feet lower. The views were spectacular, the people we met on the trail were friendly, and the thick evergreen and bamboo forest around us was rich with new discoveries.

LEAD: A NEW book, ''The Case of the Nazi Professor,'' by David M. Oshinsky, Richard P. McCormick and Daniel Horn (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick, $35; paper, $15), joins the category of books about controversies that refuse to go away.
LEAD: In reaching the final of the East Regional, Georgetown reaffirmed its status as college basketball's quintessential defensive team.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Gina Rogers Reid, to Eric Bell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Bell of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Hollywood's Academy Awards are hardly averse to commercialism. Preparations for Oscar night this Wednesday include special racks mounted inside limousine doors, to display a row of Coca-Cola products when the stars climb out.

LEAD: An article yesterday on the Rite of Christian Initiation for Adults, a program of baptism for Catholics, incorrectly quoted the Rev. Daniel E. Danielson, a pastor in Alameda County, Calif. Saying that the program's emphasis on welcoming people into the church has led to similar programs for alienated Catholics returning to the church, Father Danielson said, ''You can't have an R.C.I.A.

LEAD: THE BUSINESS WORLD'S equivalent of a pit-bull match is scheduled for a state court in Fairfax, Va., in less than two weeks. The trial involves one of the nation's richest men, H. Ross Perot, and one of the world's biggest industrial concerns, the General Motors Corporation.
LEAD: Just when we think there will be no relief from the winter doldrums, the first proof of spring pokes its way through the snow and thaw.

LEAD: THE COMPLETE 'PEER GYNT' The Hartford Stage Company will perform the uncut ''Peer Gynt,'' Henrik Ibsen's fantasy based on the Norse legend of a young man's wanderings through universal perils and pleasures. Because of its length, the piece is usually performed in truncated versions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Employers commonly help pick up the tab when employees are relocated - paying for moving expenses, brokers' fees and hotel accommodations. But with real estate prices rising wildly in most cities and interest rates unpredictable, at best, companies are now doing more.

LEAD: During the real estate boom on the Upper East Side at the time of the Civil War, John C. Rennert, a local carpenter famed for making artificial limbs for wounded veterans, built three Italianate-style rowhouses at 134-138 East 93d Street in the emerging Carnegie Hill area of Yorkville. They were bought by merchants who valued their brick facades, stoops and small lawns.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: You can add Caracas, Venezuela, to your list of cities with subways (Q & A, Feb. 12). While it only had a few stations in the fall of 1987 when I was there, it surely is longer than that now. A. ELIZABETH EICHMAN Rosemont, Pa.

LEAD: The Producer Price Index jumped a full percentage point for February, heightening concerns about a return of double-digit inflation and sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 48.57 points. But last week, the Consumer Price Index for February - another indicator of inflation - showed a moderate gain of only four-tenths of a percent.

LEAD: Dr. Marjorie Carol Ravitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Ravitz of Smithtown, L.I., and Dr. Elliot Robert Rossein, a son of Marcella Rossein of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Dr. Withal Rossein, were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Elliott T. Spar.
LEAD: To recruit and retain nurses, hospitals throughout the nation last year gave them their largest real pay increase in history.

Although Mr. Feiner accurately pointed out that our job fair attracted more than a dozen inquiries, we are very pleased that one person currently is enrolled in our

LEAD: There is no getting around it - this is a frustrating time for Nolan D. Archibald. For nearly a year he has been shopping for a suitable acquisition to round out the product line at the Black & Decker Corporation, the Towson, Md.-based power-tool and household-appliance company he's headed for three years.

LEAD: All but one of 25 decorative art objects brazenly stolen during visiting hours from six museums this year have been recovered, and two Brooklyn men have been arrested, Federal authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: Julius Eichel, a conscientious objector in World Wars I and II who was twice charged with refusing to register for the draft, died Friday after surgery at Coney Island Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.
LEAD: A car crashed through a window of a crowded supermarket in West Orange, N.J., yesterday afternoon, injuring 10 people before coming to rest at a checkout counter, the police said.

LEAD: The marriage of Wendy Dawn Hattler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Hattler of Ardmore, Pa., to Alan Dessy, the son of Ronnie Dessy of New York and the late Andrew Dessy, took place last evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Marshall Maltzman performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Boston University, is a buyer at Burberry's Ltd.

LEAD: To the Editor: Washington's renovated Union Station is an improvement cosmetically, but the modification travelers needed was not accomplished.

LEAD: The engagement of Judith Elizabeth Gessner to Michael Campion Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Miller Jr. of Washington, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Gessner Jr. of New Orleans. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: SINCE the 1930's, the Federal Government has from time to time adopted programs and policies aimed at encouraging home ownership. Overlaying the basic subsidy of the American Dream - the deductibility of mortgage interest payments - have been other advantages like mortgage guarantees.

LEAD: The engagement of Catherine Seaton Meyer to Jeffrey C. Warlich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Warlich of St. Paul, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Beverly Barry Meyer of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and John DeBard Meyer of Brooklyn and North Egremont, Mass. A May 13 wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''The consumer is still getting a lot of dollars placed in his wallet. But when it came to spending, consumers suddenly have decided this income is not going to be disbursed as lavishly as it has been.'' Robert Dederick, chief economist, Northern Trust Company.

LEAD: New York City, which has one of the nation's most peculiar forms of government, might be headed for a system with new elements that are common elsewhere. These could include a larger legislature or one with two houses, a voting method that gives small groups a bigger voice and management procedures aimed at avoiding last-minute decisions.

LEAD: The early-music movement, once the domain of antiquarian scholars and minimally skilled dilettantes, has been gathering professional momentum for decades. It is now a small steamroller, if not a juggernaut. The movement has spawned a new generation of well-trained musicians who play their instruments well and proselytize for correct performance practices with evangelical zeal.

Gleysteen Jr. of New York, took place yesterday at the Bronxville Field Club. The Rev. Dr. Donald L. Berry, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE ultimate drop-dead line of this Soviet election season is attributed to Yuri Nikulin, a celebrated clown and director of the Moscow Circus. Mr. Nikulin was a candidate in a Moscow district until last month, when he quit in disgust. ''This,'' the clown is said to have muttered shortly before stalking out of an unruly voter caucus, ''is a circus.

LEAD: FOR blacks, according to the premise of the playwright Jeff Stetson, the day of reckoning came on Sept. 15, 1963, when the First Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., was bombed, and four girls, in their Sunday school class, were killed.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Federal deficit figures for 1960 and 1969 were improperly charted. In both years, the Federal Government operated with a budget surplus, and thus the figures for those years, $3 billion and $8.4 billion respectively, should have been charted as negative numbers in the first chart.

LEAD: Freda Stern Ackerman, an executive vice president and the director of the public finance department of Moody's Investors Service in New York, and J. Chester Johnson, president of Government Finance Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., plan to be married in May.

LEAD: In the last few years, as America's jobless rate plummeted to the lowest levels since the mid-1970's, ''Hiring'' signs have proliferated at fast-food restaurants, department stores, supermarkets and countless other businesses. Increasingly, those jobs are going to people like Margie Lobaton in Warwick, R.I., and Patrick Gannaway in Huntington Beach, Calif.

LEAD: The Princeton heavyweight varsity crew presented its new head coach, Gary Kilpatrick, with his first victory today, defeating Navy's varsity to retain the Navy-Princeton Rowing Cup.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, had no drugs in his system when he was arrested on an alcohol-related charge, Capt. Thomas B. Gallagher of the New Jersey State Police said today.

LEAD: Elisabeth Anne Bittner, an associate at the First Boston Corporation, and Chansoo Joung, an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York, are planning to be married June 3. Miss Bittner, a daughter of Dr. N. Douglas Bittner of Peapack, N.J., and Dorothy P. Bittner of Basking Ridge, N.J., graduated from Yale University.

LEAD: The Matthew Broderick who stood silently before 200 black soldiers and one Panavision camera was certainly no teen-age Eugene Morris Jerome. This was a mustachioed, portly, somber-looking Matthew Broderick, dressed in the midnight blue coat and crimson sash of a Union Army colonel. And as he began to speak his lines, he seemed very much older than his 26 years.

LEAD: In a majestic Senate committee room, flanked with ornate mirrors and decorated with impressive Victorian chandeliers, a Government official faces a panel of powerful lawmakers, who bombard her with complicated questions. The official is Wendy Gramm, chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and not only is she in the hot seat, so is her agency.

LEAD: After the Friday noon service, hundreds of worshipers streamed out of the Sultan Selim Camii mosque, and to a man they dropped worn paper money onto a bright red rug that served as a collection plate.

LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Moonlight on Judea'' (Travel, Jan. 15), Stephen R. Conn writes that he was informed by a guide from the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel ''that since archeologists could never find any remains of a wall [ around Jericho ] dating back to 1200 B.C., the time of Joshua, it probably never existed.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Aborn Hut of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bonnie Aileen Hut to Frederick Andrew Brimberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Brimberg of New York and Chebeague Island, Me. A June 25 wedding is planned.

LEAD: OUR trip to Paris last August began at the modern Chaumartin Station in Madrid, all shining marble and concealed lights. We were about to board an overnight train - the Paris-Madrid Talgo. Down an escalator from the crowded waiting room we found it, long and low, the words Talgo Pendular on its sides.

LEAD: According to his friends, Lawrence Taylor had been walking cautiously and thoughtfully across the tightrope of his career, if not of his life, for the last seven months. As a two-time offender of the National Football League's drug policy, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker has been within one misstep of toppling off that tightrope into permanent suspension, subject to appeal after one year.

LEAD: FOR months and months, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his aides have been meeting with all manner of West Bank and Gaza Strip Palestinians, struggling to find even one who speaks with authority but is not affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LEAD: In a clear departure from Ronald Reagan's approach and those of most other Presidents, President Bush has built a sizable economic policy apparatus within the White House to supplement and second-guess the policy-making work of the Treasury and other departments, and sometimes to take the initiative.
LEAD: That we are a nation of immigrants, fugitives from poverty, ghettos and pogroms, has been told over and over. Many immigrants settled in New York City. But not everyone.

LEAD: In Charles R. Morris's article (''Deficit Figuring Doesn't Add Up,'' Feb. 12), there are three graphs along with the statement that the Federal deficit, expressed as a percentage of the gross national product, is not a great deal higher than it was in the mid-1970's.

LEAD: The real Dartmouth story is an old one: how the powers that be do what they can to quiet an adversary press. My organization has received complaints of administration harassment from the University of Chicago, the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Vassar, the College of William and Mary and others.
LEAD: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 57th Streets will be closed be tween 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. today for the Easter Promenade.
LEAD: INFLATION'S coming back: bad news for New Jersey's budget, since the prices of everything the state buys, including salaries, are rising; worse news for the state pension system.

LEAD: In many ways, the story of the Neville Brothers of New Orleans, who have just released ''Yellow Moon'' (A&M 5240; all three formats), is also the story of the tension in American society between the outsider and mainstream culture. The Neville Brothers - Art, 51, Charles, 50, Aaron, 48, and Cyril, 41 - are part of New Orleans's most important postwar pop musical dynasty, a family steeped in both the Mardi Gras culture of the city, as well as its pop music-making side, which at best has had an off-and-on-again flirtation with the American music business.
LEAD: The Knicks not only reactivated Mark Jackson for last night's game against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden but also inserted him into the starting lineup.

LEAD: SKELETAL remains displayed for many years at the Historical Society of the Tarrytowns are those of two American Indians, but forensic scientists have concluded that neither was Chief Mamaronock, as had long been thought.

Mostly I consider myself to be leading a happy and active life, so why do I delay opening this correspondence from my alma mater? North. She said she had ''never met a man who worked harder for his country.'' LEAD: EVERY quarter century or so, a combination of an unpopular Democratic Mayor and an attractive Republican challenger has managed to break the Democratic stranglehold on New York's City Hall. In 1965, it was John V. Lindsay for two terms and in 1933, Fiorello H. LaGuardia for three terms.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Cluett of San Francisco and Blue Hill, Me., of the engagement of their daughter Amanda Bird Cluett to William Brook Stanton, a son of Emily Hart Stanton of Darien, Conn., and the late John Pulsifer Stanton. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: Marco Polo is credited with the naming of Madagascar. Everything else about this island, off the east coast of Africa in the Indian Ocean, seems remote and mysterious - including its art and artifacts.

LEAD: In the western territories of the United States around 1850 gold abounded but gold coins were rare. To stem the growing shortage for coins, private mints began making their own coins and these are the ones called territorial gold coins. Of these private mintings one of the strangest might be those of the Mormons' Deseret Mint of Salt Lake City, Utah.
LEAD: Among the country artists whose music has been labeled ''new traditionalist,'' Lyle Lovett is surely the least bound to country-music traditions.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The issue of the short skirt has come down (up?) to a simple matter of choice: Take it or leave it. But either way, don't worry. You can still keep your department store charge cards and no one will revoke your subscriptions to fashion magazines. For the most part, the takers appear to be younger women whose figures allow them to wear the shorter lengths without a trace of self-consciousness.

LEAD: THE coupon in the paper importuned with silent grace. Presentation of that slip of paper at the box office would entitle me, if I were to purchase one full-price admission ticket, to a second one at no cost whatsoever at the brand new Glitter-on-the-Highway.

LEAD: ''The tallest building in Bridgeport'' sounds like a punch line. And at just 16 stories, Bridgeport Center, the new headquarters complex of People's Bank here, is so small that it would barely muster notice in most other cities. There is a reason, however, that this toy-sized skyscraper merits attention: it marks the high-rise debut of Richard Meier, the New York- and Los Angeles-based architect whose career so far has been limited to museums, houses, institutional buildings and low-rise corporate structures.

LEAD: In the ''party'' exercise, Geri, a high-school student is at a victory celebration for her school's basketball team. She drives to the party in her mother's car with three friends. At the party Tom, a classmate, is trying to get her to ''loosen up'' with a drink.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials acknowledge that United States export controls have many of the same deficiencies that have permitted Western European companies to help third world countries build poison gas factories without fear of legal sanctions.

LEAD: As the producer of the television program ''Sunday Night,'' which finishes its first season tonight, John Head has mixed and matched some of the most creative and influential musicians in the country in extraordinary one-hour jam sessions.

LEAD: WPP Group P.L.C. continued on the acquisition path yesterday, signing an agreement to buy Millward Brown, a British-based marketing research company. The marketing communications conglomerate will pay Millward's stockholders $3.56 a share in a deal that values the company at $25.1 million. The deal could be worth as much as $50.6 million if shareholders opt for a alternate payment plan based on the firm's profitability in the next five years.

LEAD: TEN years ago Steve Gianakos, a New York artist, created black-humored drawings titled ''How to Murder Your Pet.'' Now he has decided to make pets comfortable.

LEAD: Arthur A. Charpentier, a retired law librarian, died of respiratory failure on March 19 at the Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor. He was 69 years old and lived in Mount Desert, Me.
LEAD: Yacht races are often lost in a sudden change of wind direction at sea. A wind shift in a New York City courtroom has now deprived the United States of the America's Cup.

LEAD: A DESK or floor lamp that does not work can be dangerous as well as annoying. If a lamp flickers, will not light, requires delicate positioning to operate, has a frayed cord or frequently burns out bulbs, it should be repaired immediately or not used.

LEAD: A criminal trial is not a procedure for disclosing the whole truth about a sequence of events. It is designed, instead, to determine the guilt or innocence of a person or persons charged with specified criminal conduct.

LEAD: Under clouds of uncertainty as gray as the mist that shrouded City Hall, the New the mist that shrouded City Hall, the New York City Board of Estimate met yesterday for the first time since the United States Supreme Court declared it unconstitutional, and despite doubts about its future it did business in its usual unusual way.

LEAD: To consumers still mourning the dismemberment of friendly old Ma Bell, the very idea of another change in the phone system is as welcome as yet another set of Yellow Pages. But this time there's nothing to worry about.

LEAD: Old habits die hard, particularly comfortable habits. Take the legislative veto, a handy device for turning conflict into accommodation that was concocted in 1932, when Herbert Hoover wanted to reorganize the Government and Congress wasn't sure it wanted him to.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 450,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the 1988-89 marketing year that began on Sept. 1, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.

LEAD: The 61st Academy Awards ceremony began by creating the impression that there would never be a 62d. The evening's opening number, which deserves a permanent place in the annals of Oscar embarrassments, was indeed as bad as that. Barely five minutes into the show, Merv Griffin was on hand to sing ''I've Got a Lovely Bunch of Coconuts,'' and that was only the beginning.
LEAD: A. Whitney Brown, whose cynical news commentaries are a regular feature on ''Saturday Night Live,'' has carved out a comic identity as the quintessential disillusioned baby boomer.

LEAD: Ken Griffey and Kent Tekulve signed one-year contracts with the Cincinnati Reds yesterday, and the signing of Griffey had historical significance. Griffey's son Ken Jr., an outfielder, has signed with the Seattle Mariners, and for the first time a father and son will play in the major leagues at the same time.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A PHOTOGRAPH, whether intended to or not, speaks of the time in which it was made. This is obvious in the case of images taken years ago -pictures from the first days of Israel's independence, for example, or from the tumultuous decade of the 1960's. But it is also true of contemporary art photographs of the sort one finds displayed in SoHo galleries.

LEAD: Harvard made it look easy tonight. The Crimson routed Michigan State, 6-3, to move into the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, In the final N.C.A.A. Division I poll of the regular season, Harvard and Michigan State were tied for first. But tonight, there was no question about which team was superior as a capacity crowd of 15,842 at the St.

LEAD: The Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum, at 32-37 Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, will reopen tomorrow. The four-year-old museum includes more than 250 of Noguchi's sculptures and many of his other works. The museum is open 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday and Wednesday through November. Buss service from Manhattan is offered every hour on the half-hour from 11:30 A.M.

LEAD: Alan Feinberg is building a major career as a champion of new music but his identification with the avant-garde does not rule out sympathy for and expertise in the traditional literature. His stimulating recital at Town Hall on Wednesday evening allowed him stretching room in both areas.

LEAD: Investigators examining the explosion of a Trident 2 missile in its first undersea launching believe the accident was probably caused by a mechanical failure, not a breakdown in the missile's computer or electrical system, a Pentagon spokesman said today.
LEAD: The poisonous effects of the Alaskan oil spill could be unusually persistent, scientists said today.
LEAD: Bastro and Alice Donut, two rock bands, are to perform tonight at 11 and midnight, respectively, at the Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, at East Seventh Street (420-1590). Admission is $10.
LEAD: Mahler Score

LEAD: Some racially discriminatory laws imposed by South Africa on Namibia will be retained after the territory begins its transition to independence on Saturday, its Administrator General said today.

LEAD: Midway Airlines, a big regional carrier based here, said today that it would buy 37 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 series long-haul aircraft over the next five years at a cost exceeding $900 million and had taken options for another 37 planes. The investment is large for a carrier the size of Midway, which has a fleet of 42 older aircraft.

LEAD: The United States premiere of ''Messa per Rossini,'' world premieres by Roger Kellaway and David Del Tredici, the Philharmonic debut of the soprano Gabriela Benackova, and two performances of Mahler's ''Songs of a Wayfarer'' by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau are among the highlights of the 1989-90 New York

LEAD: Bob Waters of Western Carolina once said he had to keep coaching football to fight amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the incurable degenerative nerve and muscle affliction known as Lou Gehrig's disease. But school officials reassigned him yesterday.
LEAD: Lee Atwater, the South Carolinian who managed President Bush's 1988 campaign, stated the principle late last year with his usual pithiness.
LEAD: After just three days of testimony, the defense in the trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom rested today without calling either agent to testify.
LEAD: In moving against a large money-laundering operation Wednesday, the Justice Department began using a new Federal law meant to help the Government seize the proceeds of illegal drug sales.

LEAD: Murphy's Law, a rock bank, will be headlining a quadruple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). The program also includes Lost Cause, Sock of It All and Underdog, and begins at 10 P.M. Tickets are $14.50.
LEAD: Dr. Morris Orgel, a retired dentist, died of cancer Monday at his home in Plantation, Fla. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: Hurricane Carter's Life

LEAD: As the decades of the 20th century rolled by and other states in the Northeast gave in and enacted income taxes, Connecticut held firm to the old image of small-government New England, where the state's business was to mind its own business and keep taxes low. The income tax is still the issue on which all candidates must make their stand known, and in many towns, sworn opposition has become almost a requirement for election.

LEAD: Any Robinson Crusoe movie that takes more than five minutes to get Crusoe onto his desert isle is in big trouble. Caleb Deschanel's ''Crusoe,'' opening today at the Paris, not only takes 10 to 15 minutes, but it also goes out of its way to give Crusoe spurious social relevance.
LEAD: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $150 million worth of 10 percent notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: When Anthony Gourdine, the pop-soul singer better known as Little Anthony, performs his show-stopping rendition of the Temptations' hit ''Shaky Ground,'' he punches out lyrics that describe the treacherous pitfalls and illusions of pop stardom with a special urgency.

LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., is considering proposing a significant change in the financing of the Bush Administration's savings and loan bailout plan, the Banking Committee's chief of staff said today.

LEAD: Hill & Knowlton and Burson-Marsteller again finished first and second, respectively, in the annual ranking by size of public relations agencies by O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms, the influential industry directory.

LEAD: New works by a dozen Israeli and American Jewish composers will be presented Sunday, Monday and Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, and at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The festival, Counter Harmonies: Jewish Experience in 20th-Century Music, is being presented by the National Foundation for Jewish Culture, and will also include master classes, lectures and panel discussion.
LEAD: Although wholesale prices are surging, inflation at the consumer level is not following suit, primarily because of the resistance of buyers to higher prices.

LEAD: A proposal to build a jail for 1,000 inmates in the Rossville section of Staten Island was approved last night by the Board of Estimate, despite vehement opposition from residents of the area, who said they would fight the proposal in court.

LEAD: Harry Leichter, who ran a news service for newspapers and news agencies in New York City for 36 years, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at the Grotta Rehabilitation Center in West Orange, N.J. Mr. Leichter was 72 years old and lived in Cedar Grove, N.J.
LEAD: Rebellious inmates today ended a five-day uprising that left at least seven people dead and trapped hundreds of women and children inside the prison here.
LEAD: Addressing Brazil's growing environmental problem, President Jose Sarney appealed today for foreign aid, but rejected foreign supervision.

LEAD: Because there are virtually no gaps in the Alaska oil slick, scientists fear unusually persistent poisonous effects. The chairman of Exxon said part of the problem was a delay in permission for cleanup efforts, but officials disputed that contention. Page A12.
LEAD: Bernard Blier, a popular French film actor, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: The Michigan man, class of 1964, had several reasons to arrive here Wednesday. He is attending the annual convention of the National Association of Basketball Coaches, and now, for the first time in 13 years, he will have the chance to watch his school play in the Final Four.

LEAD: * Art Ross has joined Pancom International Corp., a New York ad agency, as executive vice president and director of creative services.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he would tell President Bush that he is ready to propose elections for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, but only after the violence there ends.
